webTitle: Rail powers plan starts border row

fields.headline: Rail powers plan starts border row
fields.trailText: May 16 2000: A row over whether Whitehall or Holyrood has the final say over train services north of the border threatens to trigger a fresh dispute over devolution.
fields.body:
A row over whether Whitehall or Holyrood has the final say over train services north of the border threatens to trigger a fresh dispute over devolution.

An alliance of Labour, Liberal Democrat and Scottish National Party MPs are opposing moves by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, to hand ultimate control to the London-based strategic rail authority.

The MPs, supported by Strathclyde passenger transport authority, claim the plan undermines assurances given two years ago. Michael Moore, Lib Dem transport spokesman, said: "It is bizarre that in a dispute a quango in London would be able to dictate to elected ministers in Scotland.

"I think that's patently against the spirit of devolution."

Under the transport bill the strategic rail authority, chaired by former Eurotunnel boss Sir Alastair Morton, could overrule the decisions of Edinburgh's elected ministers. The MPs believe Holyrood, not the strategic rail authority, should have the final word on timetables and fares of services running exclusively in Scotland.

They point out that former Scottish minister Henry McLeish, now a member of the Scottish executive, told the Commons in 1998 that post-devolution Scotland's ministers would be able to "instruct" the authority.

Mr Moore accused the government of flouting the undertaking and is seeking to have the bill amended.

Peers are threatening to challenge the powers of the rail authority when it is debated in the Lords. Mr Prescott has already suffered an embarrassing Commons revolt over plans to part-privatise air traffic control.

Passenger Transport Executives in six English conurbations are also concerned about the role of the rail authority.

Rail is a "reserved" power but the London government's remit was expected to stretch only to services in England and Wales, plus those connecting with Scotland.

fields.headline: Al Jarreau
fields.standfirst:
Hammersmith Apollo, London
•••
fields.trailText: Al Jarreau's name is often left out of the jazz histories because of his pop/crossover flirtations: he is the only singer to have won vocalist Grammys in the jazz, pop and R&B categories, which has led the hardcore to deem him short of the right stuff. When he has appeared in jazz books, there have been hints that his broad appeal to youth in the 70s and 80s would wane as middle age overtook him.
fields.body:
Al Jarreau's name is often left out of the jazz histories because of his pop/crossover flirtations: he is the only singer to have won vocalist Grammys in the jazz, pop and R&B categories, which has led the hardcore to deem him short of the right stuff. When he has appeared in jazz books, there have been hints that his broad appeal to youth in the 70s and 80s would wane as middle age overtook him.

But in his 60th year Jarreau is resoundingly defiant. His Apollo audience was multi-cultural and multi-generational, and loved him. He is on the road to promote a new disc, Tomorrow Today, his first studio album for six years, but most of the songs here ended up as uptempo ensemble jams. His music clung to a streamlined funkiness, but was full of the vocal pyrotechnics that first marked him out. Jarreau's range has a romantic lightness and bluesy grittiness, his scatting reflects the agility of his first jazz model, Jon Hendricks, and his mimicry of instruments is extraordinary.

Accompanied by an excellent septet, Jarreau worked up a ferocious stomping funk worthy of a finale within the first 20 minutes, delivered a duo improvisation with his saxophonist on How High the Moon that dismissed the reservations of the jazz police, and ran through a mix of old and new, fast funk and Latin pieces that kindled rather than diminished his energies as the show went on. The shape of the pieces was a little repetitive, and Jarreau is perhaps more of a dazzling than a moving singer. But it was a heartening show - for him and the crowd, by the look of it.

fields.headline: Sounds barrier
fields.standfirst:
Leftfield
Academy, Manchester
***
fields.trailText: Anyone moaning that today's young people don't benefit from the character-building war and pestilence of earlier generations should pay a visit to the modern endurance test of a Leftfield concert.
fields.body:
Anyone moaning that today's young people don't benefit from the character-building war and pestilence of earlier generations should pay a visit to the modern endurance test of a Leftfield concert. The crowd is such a mass of dangerously flailing limbs that negotiating it should be rewarded with a Victoria Cross, while the ear-demolishing noises from the quadrophonic bass bins have some audience members crying out in agony. In recent interviews, former punks Leftfield have expressed a yearning for the experimental heyday of dance, where the bass was "so powerful it made you shit yourself". It's a measure of their success that the toilets are kept remarkably busy all night.

Inflicting such torture on their audience reflects Leftfield's desire to regain an underground credibility, five years after their mega-selling classic Leftism and merely months after Phat Planet (from their inferior second album, Rhythm & Stealth) appeared in that Guinness advert. What this also means is a near-absence of hits - no Open Up or Original - and an anonymity about proceedings that gives their first tour in years a non-mainstream feel, but makes it less of an event.

Backed by a stream of meaningless projections (shapes, ripples), Neil Barnes and Paul Bailey are determinedly low-key. Any crowd-pleasing is left to the stupendous drummer, who restores the Glitter Band influence to trance music. If the intent is to focus attention on the music, it works. Closing with a pulverising Phat Planet, Leftfield gradually up the tempo to remind us why they are seminal figures in dance music.

Ninety minutes of largely instrumental tribal trance might not please Leftfield's more commercially minded fans, but I won't hear a word against them. Admittedly, following the gig, I can't hear anything at all.

Leftfield play Rock City, Nottingham (0115-941 2544), tonight, then touring.

fields.headline: Thomson falls to £1.8bn Preussag bid
fields.trailText: Thomson Travel succumbed to a £1.8bn takeover by Germany's Preussag yesterday - despite six weeks of negotiations with a rival.
fields.body:
Thomson Travel succumbed to a £1.8bn takeover by Germany's Preussag yesterday - despite six weeks of negotiations with a rival.

The merger will create the world's largest travel company, but prompted uncertainty about the fate of Thomson's high-street rival Thomas Cook, in which Preussag holds a controlling stake.

The deal with Preussag brings together mass market holiday brands such as Thomson in the UK with Preussag's TUI in Germany and Thomson's high-end Magic group with Germany's Robinson.

The 180p a share offer finally drove Thomson Travel's share price above the 170p at which it made its stock market debut two years ago.

To appease competition regulators, who last year blocked Airtours from buying First Choice, Preussag will sell its stake in Thomas Cook, probably to Carlson of the US, which already owns more than 20% of Thomas Cook.

The deal shuts out C&N Touristic, which had a 130p offer in early April rejected by Thomson as too low. But the C&N board appeared last night to be pinning its hopes of of eventual victory on the chance that Preussag's bid might be blocked by regulators.

However, Preussag - which has transformed itself from a heavy engineering business to one of Germany's leading travel companies - has won the backing of almost 35% of Thomson's shareholders. These include the 22% owned by the founding family, whose pledge to sell its shares to Preussag is binding even if a higher offer appears.

In another apparent attempt to deter counter-bidders, Thomson Travel has agreed to pay a £16m fee if the sale to Preussag is not completed.

Under the terms of the acquisition, which was hastily put together over the weekend, Thomson Travel will continue to operate under its own brand and with the existing management, including chief executive Charles Gurassa, in place.

Mr Gurassa, who was parachuted into the role at the end of last year, described the deal with Preussag as a "great fit". He acknowledged his relief that the deal had been struck above the 170p at which Thomson Travel was floated two years ago. Since then the share price has followed a tortuous path, at one stage falling to 69p. The shares closed last night at 172p.

Preussag was apparently forced into the fight after Thomson admitted on Friday it was in talks with C&N at 160p, more than 25p above the price at which discussions began six weeks ago. To pay for Thomson Travel, Preussag, whose shares fell 5% in Germany yesterday on fears the price tag was too high, will float half of its Hapag-Lloyd tour business. It will also issue 10% of its equity through a rights issue in the next eight weeks.

The City is now waiting to see whether C&N Touristic, after losing the race for Thomson, turns its attention to another UK operator, such as First Choice.

webTitle: Free slice of Egg for workers

fields.headline: Free slice of Egg for workers
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Egg's 1,400 employees will receive £100 free shares and £900 in options when the banking arm of Prudential is floated on the stock market next month.
fields.body:
Egg's 1,400 employees will receive £100 free shares and £900 in options when the banking arm of Prudential is floated on the stock market next month.

In addition to the windfall, employees will be allowed to buy shares in a company which is being valued at between £1.5 and £2bn - half the price mooted last year when Prudential indicated its intention to sell a stake in the telephone-cum-internet bank.

In a letter to staff, Mike Harris, the chief executive of Egg, explained that the decision to float the business would give it a "currency" for expansion and also allow Egg to attract and retain staff.

"Flotation represents the most effective way to maximise the growth potential within Egg plc by creating a currency for domestic and international acquisition and expansion as well as allowing Egg to attract and retain outstanding talent," Mr Harris, who founded the bank two years ago and who is to become executive vice chairman in January 2001, wrote.

The free shares and grant of options will be made to employees of Egg and the Pru's own-branded banking operation. Other Prudential staff will be entitled to apply to buy shares.

The 1m customers of Egg, unless they are employees, will not receive any free shares but they will be the only retail investors offered the opportunity to buy shares in the lossmaking operation.

While the details of the free share offer to staff have started to emerge it is not yet clear to what senior executives, incld ing Mr Harris, will be entitled. Those details are expected to be contained in the prospectus for the flotation, which is due to be published next week before the shares are priced early next month. The City expects the allocation of shares to be generous.

While Egg has said that it has not lost any key staff, Jonathan Bloomer, Prudential's chief executive, admitted last week that the flotation would make it easier to prevent staff deserting to rival dot.com operations which have been offering attractive share incentives to new employees.

The City expects about 100 senior staff to be offered ad ditional incentives and share offers. The share option scheme for employees is expected to run over a three-year period.

Customers of Egg and Pru bank will be limited to buying £1,000 of shares, as will any employees deciding to buy shares.

To avoid the problems incurred by Lastminute.com when the travel and shopping website floated, misjudging both the demand for and the price of the shares, Prudential, which is being advised by Goldman Sachs, will offer shares only through the internet and will take money from customers' current accounts only once the shares have been allocated.

fields.headline: Romany divas delight
fields.standfirst:
Vera Bila/ Esma Redzepova
Barbican, London
****
fields.trailText: The penultimate night of the Barbican's celebration of Gypsy music and arts features two Romany divas. Macedonian-born Esma Redzepova sings with a silvery voice and operatic intensity, wringing every last ounce of emotion from the music, at one point donning a black lace veil and affecting guttural yet musical sobs.
fields.body:
The penultimate night of the Barbican's celebration of Gypsy music and arts features two Romany divas. Macedonian-born Esma Redzepova sings with a silvery voice and operatic intensity, wringing every last ounce of emotion from the music, at one point donning a black lace veil and affecting guttural yet musical sobs.

The headliner, Vera Bila, was recently laid low with a bout of pneumonia and nearly didn't make it. Born in poverty-stricken Slovakia, Bila has been dubbed the Ella Fitzgerald of Gypsy music. She and her band Kale sing of the trials and tribulations of Gypsy life, combining Eastern European folk with smooth Latin rhythms.

Tonight, dressed in a sombre black dress, Bila is fluid but muted in her approach. She is obviously not 100% better. The first half of the set is restrained and static, the guitar-based quartet holding back so as not to stretch their leading lady too much. Despite rich harmonies, their music has an unfortunate resemblance to the Gypsy Kings, whose cocktail pop has been piped so relentlessly through bars and shops, it has become debased currency.

The show peps up halfway through, when Bila disappears backstage and returns in a red dress and black lace gloves. With this visual transformation, her voice emerges with its full power. At last we get a glimpse of why she is the Gypsy Diva, as she sings a frenetic folk tune with biting magnificence. As Kale's music speeds up, Bila becomes more animated, embellishing the stomping rhythm with piercing notes.

The set concludes with a song sung in lush a cappella harmony. But although Bila and Kale rally at the end, it is the support act Redzepova who really steals the show.

fields.headline: Meandering meaning
fields.standfirst:
Radamisto
Grand Theatre, Leeds
*
fields.trailText: Radamisto was first performed in 1720; in the current Handel revival it has tended to be overshadowed by the later masterpieces. Whatever the shortcomings of the new Opera North show, the performance does demonstrate that such neglect is unjust - Radamisto contains the same quota of great numbers as its better-known siblings.
fields.body:
Radamisto was first performed in 1720; in the current Handel revival it has tended to be overshadowed by the later masterpieces. Whatever the shortcomings of the new Opera North show, the performance does demonstrate that such neglect is unjust - Radamisto contains the same quota of great numbers as its better-known siblings.

Even by Handelian standards the plot, based upon Tacitus, is complicated: the titular hero is at war with the villainous Tiridarte, who lusts after Radamisto's wife Zenobia but is married to his sister Polissena. It's an opera with plenty of meaty roles, and though few of the Opera North cast are baroque specialists, guided by the experienced conducting of Harry Bicket their singing is decent. Some is very fine, especially from Alice Coote as Zenobia, who, like David Walker, the counter-tenor who sings Radamisto, gained in authority as the opening night wore on.

Tim Hopkins's production, though, goes from merely ponderous in the opening scenes to woefully inadequate by the end. The tone of Charles Edwards's rather Bauhaus monochrome designs hardly seems to fit here, and some of the wigs are startling. Radamisto suffers under a pudding-basin cut, while his father Farasmane (Bruce Budd) is got up like a shaggy refugee from a heavy-metal band; when everything is so self-consciously intended to be meaningful such details are bewildering. And when they are not flailing at the walls or making semaphoric gestures, the cast walks very slowly around the stage, as if the director had watched too much Robert Wilson at an impressionable age. Individual characterisation is negligible, and so, dramatically, is the final result.

Further performance on May 26 and 30 (box office: 0113-222 6222), then touring.

fields.headline: Flawless form
fields.standfirst:
Guangdong Modern Dance Company
Corn Exchange, Brighton
***
fields.trailText: Guangdong was China's first modern dance troupe to emerge from the Cultural Revolution; even now its policy of assimilating international dance trends to a modern Chinese sensibility is all but unique in the country. Surprisingly, Guangdong's first visit to the UK reveals very little about what the style and politics of a new Chinese choreography might be. The company's mixed programme (including work by UK choreographers Becky Edmunds and Charlie Morrissey) feels like a sampler of last century's international fashions - post-Butoh, postmodern, post-expressionist.
fields.body:
Guangdong was China's first modern dance troupe to emerge from the Cultural Revolution; even now its policy of assimilating international dance trends to a modern Chinese sensibility is all but unique in the country. Surprisingly, Guangdong's first visit to the UK reveals very little about what the style and politics of a new Chinese choreography might be. The company's mixed programme (including work by UK choreographers Becky Edmunds and Charlie Morrissey) feels like a sampler of last century's international fashions - post-Butoh, postmodern, post-expressionist.

It would have been a disappointment had the dancers themselves not proved so exceptional. Outstandingly supple and strong technicians, they have a mesmerising command over their movements. In A Tacit Assembly, Edmunds and Morrissey milk this quality, coaxing the dancers through meditative solos that pause in vertiginously stretched balances. The dancers' bodies remain poised, as if docile to the choreographers' demands, yet their lively faces stare quizzically at each other in a comical assertion of their own independence.

In Folding, created by company member Shen Wei, the dancers assume a deliberate remoteness, as if posing as an alien life form. Their exposed flesh is powdered white, and in Butoh style they drift in exquisite slow motion. This trance state is punctuated by brief displays of physical origami, in which the dancers form and deform their limbs into sculpted poses. Beautiful, but very slow.

The choreographed struggle between gravity and flight in Xing Liang's I Want to Fly veers close to emotional and muscular cliche, but soloist Li Hong Jun gives it a breathtaking urgency. He is gifted with a flawless instinct for line, and in his remarkable body the solo becomes a riveting image of the basic drama of dance -raw energy in dialogue with pure form.

At the Playhouse, Newcastle (0191-230 5151), tonight, then touring.

The choreographed struggle between gravity and flight in Xing Liang's I Want to Fly veers close to emotional and muscular cliche, but soloist Li Hong Jun gives it a breathtaking urgency. He is gifted with a flawless instinct for line, and in his remarkable body the solo becomes a riveting image of the basic drama of dance -raw energy in dialogue with pure form. At the Playhouse, Newcastle (0191-230 5151), tonight, then touring.

fields.headline: Standard Life battle begins
fields.standfirst: Claims and counter-claims fly as life insurer tells policyholders they will be worse off if company floats
fields.trailText: Standard Life yesterday fired off its first salvo against carpetbaggers, claiming that new policies would pay out less than existing ones and that many policyholders would receive windfalls of only a few hundred pounds if it was forced to float.
fields.body:
Standard Life yesterday fired off its first salvo against carpetbaggers, claiming that new policies would pay out less than existing ones and that many policyholders would receive windfalls of only a few hundred pounds if it was forced to float.

In the first direct communication to policyholders in its battle against demutualisation, the insurer cited statistics showing some customers paying into Standard Life pensions would be more than £12,000 better off if it retained its mutuality.

Scott Bell, managing director of the 175-year-old insurance group, insisted the fight against Fred Woollard, the Monaco-based carpetbagger who is leading the flotation lobby, was worth waging.

Mr Bell said he was "very encouraged" by letters he had received from some policyholders and from independent financial advisers who had told him they believed that if Standard Life was forced to demutualise, all the remaining mutuals would follow.

"They'll have no yardstick against which to compare other companies. We are held up as a company against which to compete," Mr Bell said.

However the document, which is the first of two that will be sent to policyholders before the June 27 demutualisation vote, prompted an angry response from Mr Woollard. Disputing Standard Life's claims about its performance, Mr Woollard quoted statistics from the personal investment authority (PIA), the city regulatory body being merged into the financial services author ity (FSA), which he said showed its policies did not beat its plc rivals.

"There are big differences. If you go to Legal & General you are going to have income 17% higher than people who go to Standard Life. These are not my numbers. They are PIA numbers," Mr Woollard said.

The calculations refer to a 25-year with-profits policy with a payment of £60 a month.

Standard Life, which argues Mr Woollard's fight for demutualisation is based on greed rather than a strong business case, in turn produced an illustration that showed a £150 monthly contribution into a 25 year fund could take 0.75% off its returns, the equivalent of £12,000, if it was demutualised.

Mr Bell said he wanted to stress the "essence of mutuality" and that Standard Life had a £10bn capital base, which had grown from £3m in 1925, because of its mutual status. He said the one-off windfalls were of uncertain value and that less than half the eligible members would receive less than £2,500 in windfalls. He cited the case of other demutualisations, such as that of Bradford & Bingley Building Society, whose members had expected a £1,000 windfall when they voted for demutualisation. They are now in line to get between £350 and £700.

The insurer is to embark on an advertising campaign to ensure members send back their voting forms, which they will receive in two weeks time, ahead of the June 27 vote.

fields.headline: Lambchop
fields.standfirst:
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText: "I just don't get it. Maybe I'm not supposed to." Kurt Wagner, leader of Nashville's alt-country/soul wonders Lambchop, sits stunned by the audience's ecstatic reaction. Bizarrely, he doesn't think he's any good. This is despite writing and singing the songs for a 20-piece band who are reinventing American music right before our eyes.
fields.body:
"I just don't get it. Maybe I'm not supposed to." Kurt Wagner, leader of Nashville's alt-country/soul wonders Lambchop, sits stunned by the audience's ecstatic reaction. Bizarrely, he doesn't think he's any good. This is despite writing and singing the songs for a 20-piece band who are reinventing American music right before our eyes.

Wagner and co's performance unveils a new twist on the old "quiet storm", a term invented by black American radio in the 70s to describe all those seduction songs by the likes of Al Green, Isaac Hayes and Luther Vandross that revel in a restrained eroticism. Despite coming from a supposed indie-country background, and looking like the PTA committee at some hicktown school, Lambchop use strings, horns and ageing keyboards to produce a graceful soul sound that whispers sweet nothings into your ear. Moving from gruff whisper to girlish falsetto, Wagner offers an extraordinary brand of conversational poetry - squabbling neighbours, apologies to long-suffering lovers - that celebrates the supposedly dull and downtrodden masses with a wry and profane wit.

Pulled from this year's Nixon album, the live versions of The Old Gold Shoe and Up With People make recorded songs sound like demos. The crowning glories are versions of Curtis Mayfield's Give Me Your Love and Teddy Pendergrass's Love TKO, soul classics that your average white band would either castrate or camp up. But Lambchop are special, a labour of love hewn from a music lover's modesty. Kurt is right - if he got it, his ego would get in the way of this inspirational magnificence.

webTitle: When a lazy colleague earns more

fields.headline: When a lazy colleague earns more
fields.trailText: 16 May: I don't know where to begin. I do more than I was ever employed to but a girl on the same level gets away with the absolute minimum and still gets paid more.
fields.body:
The problem

I don't know where to begin. There is a girl at my place who seems to get everything. She strolls in late and does no more than her job. I on the other hand, do more than my job. When I first came to the company I was a typist but now I deal with sales reps, clients' enquiries, and on one occasion found us new premises, refurbished them and moved us all in. I make the office run like clockwork.

Finally the girl I mentioned before is on more money than I am. They tell me she has been in the profession for longer than I have (20 years to my two) but we are employed to do the same job. I love my job but I feel I am being treated unfairly and I don't know how to deal with it.

The solution

Wow - you sound like a real asset to any company. And, quite clearly, you seem to be worth your weight in gold - you certainly seem worth more to your company than you are currently being paid. However, the issue here seems to be your feelings at being paid less than your colleague, rather than you wanting more because you are worth more. I always advise people seeking pay-rises to divorce any feelings about what other people are paid from their own argument for a rise. What your colleague is getting, whether she is worth less or not pulling her weight - these are issues that you need to draw a line under since they are about her, not you.

Having said all that, you do have a good case for seeking a rise on your own merit. Prepare a case, based on all the extra tasks you have taken on and include costings of the money you have saved the company. Put it all in a written report and arrange a meeting with your boss. Don't mention your colleague. Simply ask for an increase based on your own worth.

And if you don't get it? Then you'll have to decide whether to put up and shut up until you are qualified, or get out now. My advice? You love your job, so I suggest you put your frustration about your colleague to the back of your mind and get on with it.

Dr Sandi Mann is author of Psychology Goes To Work and Hiding What We Feel, Faking What We Don't

webTitle: Francis finds four into three goes pear-shaped

fields.headline: Francis finds four into three goes pear-shaped
fields.standfirst: Barnsley seize initiative as City manager tinkers with defence
fields.trailText: Birmingham 0 - 4 Barnsley
fields.body:
Shocks do not come much greater than this, even in the notorious play-offs. Neither manager quite believed it and one ecstatic Barnsley follower promised on a radio phone-in to dress up his missus as "Harry" Bassett in celebration.

The result effectively puts Barnsley a single game away from returning to the Premiership and leaves Birming-ham with only pride to play for in the second leg. It lands Sky with a dead-looking duck on Thursday.

Birmingham's collapse was the last thing anticipated by Dave Bassett, who remains on course for a record eighth promotion. "I don't think anyone in football would have predicted this result," he said. "Birmingham have let in just 16 goals in 23 games at St Andrews all season, and I don't know the last time they conceded four at home."

It was certainly more than four years ago, before Trevor Francis took over as manager. That is why Francis resembled a man whose cat had swallowed his winning lottery ticket.

"It was an awful day but how do you legislate for such a result?" he said. "Unfortunately the pressure got to several Birmingham players who could not respond to the situation. I never thought it possible that any of my teams, which have been built on a solid back four, would concede four goals at home in such a vital game."

There, indeed, is the rub. It was not a usual Birmingham back four who were taken apart but the unfamiliar back three which Francis sent out after the interval.

City had served notice of defensive frailties as early as the 12th minute, when Darren Purse failed to clear and Neil Shipperley fired home via the goalkeeper Thomas Myhre's right-hand.

Worse was to follow after Purse departed at half-time. Gary Rowett and David Holdsworth parted like the Red Sea and Barnsley's substitute Bruce Dyer skipped through to add a second.

Similar indecision resulted in the same player scoring the third following a glorious through-ball by Eric Tinkler and, although there was a suspicion of offside in the build-up to the fourth, which Craig Hignett converted from 10 yards, it hardly mattered by then.

Chances have to be converted and Barnsley, the most prolific scorers in the country after Manchester United, have players who can take them. Shipperley's goal took his total to 15 for the season, Hignett now has 20 and Dyer, who took his brace with aplomb, looks in the sort of ominous form to ring alarm bells at Bolton and Ipswich.

So does Barnsley's solid defence, which restricted the hosts to two long-range shots, both of which were spectacularly but expertly saved by the former Birmingham goalkeeper Kevin Miller.

For the time being, though, Bassett, out of bitter experience, is dismissing all thoughts of Wembley. "I've had two experiences that have taught me to take nothing for granted in football," he recalled. "I was manager at Sheffield United when we looked certain to stay in the Premiership five minutes before the end of the season and were then relegated.

"I was also in charge of Crystal Palace and preparing for a penalty shoot-out in the play-off final when Leicester's Steve Claridge shinned home the winner."

"Strange things can happen in football," he added, but surely not as strange as Birmingham rescuing this tie at Oakwell.

fields.headline: Fans despair at vibrant Owls
fields.trailText: Sheff Wed 4 - 0 Leicester
fields.body:
On an afternoon that had the home fans ripping their hair out in frustration Sheffield Wednesday bowed out of the Premiership in style.

This eye-catching win was achieved with poise, passion and no little skill but left the Hillsborough faithful questioning why it took a meaningless end-of-season match to inspire such a display.

"It was a bit late in the day but that was as comprehensive a passing display as you will see," said Wednesday's caretaker manager Peter Shreeves. "It's a pity everything's tinged with sadness."

Some fans had planned to boycott this game in protest at the crises rife in the Hillsborough boardroom but the 21,656 present gasped at the vibrancy of the home side's attacking play. On this performance it seemed perverse that the Foxes will be competing in the Uefa Cup next season while the Owls make do with the Nationwide.

The embodiment of the home side's long-term hopes, young Alan Quinn, started the rout. The winger retained the club's player of the month award before kick-off and celebrated by running at the defence with purpose in the 14th minute. With no challenge materialising, he scuffed a low shot into the right-hand corner.

The home side then spurned numerous chances before Andy Booth planted Niclas Alexandersson's whipped cross emphatically beyond Pegguy Arphexad to extend their advantage.

Leicester threw on Steve Walsh and Stefan Oakes at the interval but it did little to stem the blue and white tide. Five minutes after half-time De Bilde's teasing cross found Alexandersson and the Swede calmly turned inside before firing into the roof of the net.

Next it was the Belgian's turn as Kevin Pressman's long kick was flicked on by Booth and De Bilde shot in off the far post.

"I have no complaints. We have no energy at all," said the Leicester manager Martin O'Neill. "They proved they have some really talented players here. Perhaps they'll have to ask themselves why they've gone down."

Unfortunately this Wednesday line-up is unlikely to grace Hillsborough again. Seven first-team regulars are expected to leave next month.

fields.headline: Coventry confounded by travelling conundrum
fields.trailText: Watford 1 - 0 Coventry
fields.body:
A rare Watford league victory, only their sixth this season, was not enough to prevent them finishing with the lowest points total since the Premiership began - but at least they can say they won away from home during the campaign. Coventry cannot.

Gordon Strachan's 19th and final attempt to secure a victory on the road before his charges boarded the bus for the beach was denied by Heidar Helguson's spectacular overhead kick two minutes before the break.

That brought about Coventry's ninth consecutive away defeat and their third in succession in which they failed to score. The contrasting home and away shades of the Sky Blues are summed up by their performances over yesterday's opponents: a win by four goals at Highfield Road, disappointing defeat here.

Watford at least had the right result to round off their party. The club that never really considered itself Premiership material decided to "celebrate" relegation with balloons, bunting and an increase in noise levels. In the sunshine of Vicarage Road it was all a bit surreal.

Graham Taylor's team have been heading downstairs for some time now but their departure from the top table will be for only one season, according to Mr Voluble on the microphone. "Bring on the Golden Boys" he roared before the start, which begged the question as to how this bunch of players would have been acclaimed had they won a few more matches.

"With the atmosphere that surrounded us... it was very important that we focused in and ended with a win," said Taylor.

That aim was achieved after much activity in front of Magnus Hedman had brought no initial reward. Helguson saw a header turned aside but from the corner the Golden Boys found goal. Tommy Mooney returned the ball into the heart of the goalmouth, where Darren Ward won a header to set up Helguson's mid-air acrobatics.

The victory margin would have been greater had Uriah Rennie not turned a blind eye when the Icelander tumbled in the area after having gone round Hedman.

Coventry saw much of the ball and came close several timesbut their goal tally on the road stuck stubbornly in single figures.

fields.headline: Bradford's sweet relief
fields.trailText: Bradford 1 - 0 Liverpool
fields.body:
The banner inside Valley Parade read "Houdini lives in Bradford". If so, he should expect the freedom of the city. After this remarkable feat the Yorkshire club will celebrate survival as if they were Premiership champions tonight with an open-top bus parade and civic reception.

A rare but priceless goal from David Wetherall ensured Bradford will renew acquaintance with the Premiership next season while Liverpool must place their aspirations of Champions League football on hold once again.

This was Bradford's day. And who could blame them for milking the moment? Tens of thousands will converge on the city centre to usher in Paul Jewell's creaking assembly of thirty-somethings this evening. Whatever Chelsea or Aston Villa can muster after the FA Cup final, it will take something to top this.

The decisive moment arrived 12 minutes into an extraordinary afternoon that ended with Jewell swigging champagne on the pitch and supporters doing the conga. It was the type of set-piece goal that Gérard Houllier's team have worked tirelessly on snuffing out all season. But when it mattered most, too many of his players forgot their job descriptions.

After being fouled on the right touchline, the City full-back Gunnar Halle picked himself up and curved a free-kick high into a congested penalty area. As the ball dropped, Liverpool failed to react and Wetherall emerged through a cluster of defenders, powering a header into the top left-hand corner of Sander Westerveld's goal.

The centre-back broke from the party afterwards to say: "That's something I will remember for the rest of my life. They have been writing us off all season and it gives us such satisfaction to prove them wrong."

For Jewell, who was released by Liverpool as a player, it was too soon to make full sense of his emotions. "I can't really sum up what it means to stay up. It hasn't sunk in. But you could see what it meant to the supporters and the players.

"I said to them yesterday, 'Whatever happens tomorrow I'm proud to have been your manager.' There's been a lot of things said about us this season and, having put up with that, it just makes it nice that we stayed up."

That in doing so they recorded the lowest points total by a team avoiding relegation from the top flight since three points for a win came in 18 years ago bears testament to how near the drop they came.

Although Liverpool held the territorial advantage for long spells, their elaborate patterns were woven to little effect. Indeed, the only Liverpool move of any real potency during the opening 45 minutes arrived with the Bradford supporters whistling frantically for half-time. Emile Heskey's delicate flick sent Michael Owen scampering towards goal but Halle scrambled the ball past the near post after Matt Clarke had been rounded.

With Robbie Fowler conspicuous only by his absence, Owen's pace and purpose continued to look Liverpool's most incisive option in the second half. Twice he came close to wriggling free as Liverpool set about their task with greater industry, if not ingenuity. But, as events and goals at the Dell unfolded, Bradford knew from the euphoria of their crowd that, if they could hold on, they would be safe. At times they rode their luck but for all of Liverpool's possession it was Jewell's team who came closer to scoring.

The substitute Isaiah Rankin fluffed his lines after being left with only Westerveld to beat and Dean Windass followed with an audacious lob from just inside Liverpool's half that the Dutch goalkeeper did well to touch over.

By the end, however, it mattered not. Bradford's first pitch invasion was premature but after the supporters had been herded back off the field the referee Dermot Gallagher wet his lips for one final blow of the whistle and the party began.

"It's our finest hour," beamed the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond. "One of the greatest days in football."

He can look forward to another in the close season. Rodney Marsh, who pledged to become a baldie should Bradford survive, has agreed to come to Valley Parade and have his head shaved for charity. That is well worth staying up for.

This was Bradford's day. And who could blame them for milking the moment? Tens of thousands will converge on the city centre to usher in Paul Jewell's creaking assembly of thirty-somethings this evening. Whatever Chelsea or Aston Villa can muster after the FA Cup final, it will take something to top this. The decisive moment arrived 12 minutes into an extraordinary afternoon that ended with Jewell swigging champagne on the pitch and supporters doing the conga. It was the type of set-piece goal that Gérard Houllier's team have worked tirelessly on snuffing out all season. But when it mattered most, too many of his players forgot their job descriptions. After being fouled on the right touchline, the City full-back Gunnar Halle picked himself up and curved a free-kick high into a congested penalty area. As the ball dropped, Liverpool failed to react and Wetherall emerged through a cluster of defenders, powering a header into the top left-hand corner of Sander Westerveld's goal. The centre-back broke from the party afterwards to say: "That's something I will remember for the rest of my life. They have been writing us off all season and it gives us such satisfaction to prove them wrong." For Jewell, who was released by Liverpool as a player, it was too soon to make full sense of his emotions. "I can't really sum up what it means to stay up. It hasn't sunk in. But you could see what it meant to the supporters and the players. "I said to them yesterday, 'Whatever happens tomorrow I'm proud to have been your manager.' There's been a lot of things said about us this season and, having put up with that, it just makes it nice that we stayed up." That in doing so they recorded the lowest points total by a team avoiding relegation from the top flight since three points for a win came in 18 years ago bears testament to how near the drop they came. Although Liverpool held the territorial advantage for long spells, their elaborate patterns were woven to little effect. Indeed, the only Liverpool move of any real potency during the opening 45 minutes arrived with the Bradford supporters whistling frantically for half-time. Emile Heskey's delicate flick sent Michael Owen scampering towards goal but Halle scrambled the ball past the near post after Matt Clarke had been rounded. With Robbie Fowler conspicuous only by his absence, Owen's pace and purpose continued to look Liverpool's most incisive option in the second half. Twice he came close to wriggling free as Liverpool set about their task with greater industry, if not ingenuity. But, as events and goals at the Dell unfolded, Bradford knew from the euphoria of their crowd that, if they could hold on, they would be safe. At times they rode their luck but for all of Liverpool's possession it was Jewell's team who came closer to scoring. The substitute Isaiah Rankin fluffed his lines after being left with only Westerveld to beat and Dean Windass followed with an audacious lob from just inside Liverpool's half that the Dutch goalkeeper did well to touch over. By the end, however, it mattered not. Bradford's first pitch invasion was premature but after the supporters had been herded back off the field the referee Dermot Gallagher wet his lips for one final blow of the whistle and the party began. "It's our finest hour," beamed the Bradford chairman Geoffrey Richmond. "One of the greatest days in football." He can look forward to another in the close season. Rodney Marsh, who pledged to become a baldie should Bradford survive, has agreed to come to Valley Parade and have his head shaved for charity. That is well worth staying up for.

fields.headline: They said what?
fields.standfirst: The season's choice quotes
fields.trailText: The season's choice quotes.
fields.body:
 "I wanted to go abroad and I thought Sheffield was the perfect place to be" - Gerald Sibon on joining Wednesday in July.

 "It was a difficult situation, but every player has been through it, when they feel they want to rip somebody's head off" - Trevor Sinclair on Sunderland's Alex Rae.

 "I'd have given my right arm to be a pianist" - Bobby Robson on what he'd have done if he hadn't been a footballer.

 "Apart from the three goals I though we were the better team" - Swindon's Jimmy Quinn after a 3-1 defeat at Nottingham Forest.

What a season it's been. Clogger for one has been kept amused by its three outstanding themes: cheating, beatings, and Watford being crap.

Talking of cheating, the Most Outrageous Penalty Claim (Successful) award goes to Leeds' Harry Kewell, for a match-winning effort at Derby back in December. "It's the thing he does best," said an unrepentant David O'Leary after the game, and you've got to agree. It therefore gives us great pleasure to also give Kewell the I Never Did it Honest Guv award for unfair punishment, for his red card against Galatasaray. Couldn't have happened to a nicer guy.

The Frank Dobson Award for Battling Gamely in the Face of Adversity Pretending That You're Going to Win is won by Graham Taylor, whose Watford side became the first in the country to be relegated (in mid-September, basically).

Meanwhile the Curse of Old Trafford award for, well, being cursed at Old Trafford goes to Andy "how many yellows?" d'Urso, who Roy Keane intimidated so much when he gave a penalty to the other side that he's been trying to prove his manhood ever since. So the big question for next year is: will he ever recover? We think not.

But the one occasion that Clogger truly can't wait to see next season is the draw for the first group stage of the Champions League, which Uefa's general secretary Gerhard Aigner conducted with such charm this term. Which is why, although he may be young, Clogger is ready to reward his endeavour with a Lifetime Achievement Award for Services to Football. That's the thing about the Champions League, you see - the competition gets worse, but the draws just get better. David Davies, you have a long way to go.

 "Qualification for the Champions League at a club like this should be automatic." David Seaman objects to the pesky Premiership.

webTitle: Juninho ensures Everton pay for their safety

fields.headline: Juninho ensures Everton pay for their safety
fields.trailText: Everton 0 - 2 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Everton's season which, in tangible terms, brought them only a new owner and Premiership survival ended in something akin to disarray when they were overrun by a team of similar competence - and limitations. It was an expensive defeat, dropping them down three places and costing them £600,000 in prize-money.

Things have gone pretty well for Everton over the past 10 months or so and, despite defeat, there was an almost palpable sense of content ment. The primary, possibly sole, objective of preserving their current status was attained so far ahead of schedule that the more gullible among their number briefly flirted with the idea of talking up the possibility of European qualification.

And so everything was set fair for one of those curtain-lowering afternoons when the brass band plays, the balloons climb enthusiastically into cloudless skies and, of course, the opposition meekly succumb.

That was the plan anyway. Sadly for Everton, Middlesbrough were in decidedly frisky, almost belligerent, mood and had not been informed that here was the deadest of dead rubbers.

They snarled, they kicked and they got themselves booked at regular intervals - four in eight tempestuous first-half minutes - not that getting cautioned is particularly difficult when Rob Harris is the referee. He crowned a dreadful performance shortly before the interval when, unable to persuade the Middlesbrough wall to retreat the full 10 yards as Everton prepared to take a free-kick, he simply moved the ball back a couple of yards. It was astonishing.

Harris apart this was unspeakably dull fare as two abrasive midfields locked horns and studs in the middle to squeeze the afternoon dry of any potential.

Everton never looked like scoring, which meant that one successful thrust by Middlesbrough was always going to prove decisive. They provided two, the first coming after eight minutes when Brian Deane comfortably outjumped the ungainly Richard Dunne at the far post to head home Steve Vickers's cross.

The ground was fast emptying when they struck again, Juninho exchanging passes with Deane before converting with cool efficiency. It may just be enough to secure the on-loan Brazilian's future in English football.

Middlesbrough's manager Bryan Robson confirmed afterwards that, after taking his squad to Libya for a friendly, he will fly to Madrid at the end of the week for talks with Atletico Madrid in an attempt to negotiate a permanent deal.

"Juninho has been positive about his future, I believe he wants to stay," he said. "But I will have to go to Madrid to discuss the situation and see exactly where they are coming from."

The clubs have agreed a £5.9m fee although Robson is confident he can persuade Atletico, relegated from Spain's top division, to cut their price.

webTitle: Flo and Co stake final claims

fields.headline: Flo and Co stake final claims
fields.trailText: Chelsea 4 - 0 Derby
fields.body:
Gianluca Vialli must hope next Saturday's Wembley weather matches the Mediterranean-like heat here yesterday because his Chelsea team, playing with the sun on their backs, also performed with a smile on their face. And much to the manager's delight he could have filled buckets with the sweat shed by his men after this unceasing effort.

Vialli will not replicate yesterday's selection - at least five players were on a proving ground - and all bar one of them will have slept more easily last night. Not so Albert Ferrer, who nursed a painfully twisted ankle which prompted his departure just past the half-hour. With that may also have gone the Spaniard's chance of a first, perhaps only, FA Cup final.

Nobody persevered more than Tore Andre Flo, whose chances have been restricted by 19 substitute appearances. While others would have lost their cool in the face of Mart Poom, Derby's goalkeeper and player of the year, he combined calm and audacity in back-heeling the fourth and most deserving goal in injury- time.

With that flourish Flo also reasserted himself as Chelsea's leading scorer - by one goal - over Gustavo Poyet, who also struck and deepened the feeling that he, too, will start against Aston Villa. The Uruguayan was substituted 10 minutes after his goal, almost certainly to save his energy and spare a slight ankle injury.

If Didier Deschamps has been a symbol of his club's under-performance in the Premiership, then the midfielder could hardly be faulted for application now, striving to make this his penultimate rather than final Chelsea appearance before leaving this summer.

Similar reservations have been held about Roberto di Matteo but, like Flo, he persevered and was rewarded with a late goal, a volley that Poom could only help into the net. And Celestine Babayaro must now be at least on equal terms with Jon Harley for the other full-back place.

fields.headline: Dons' five-goal flourish
fields.trailText: Aberdeen 5 - 1 Kilmarnock
fields.body:
Aberdeen finally had the kind of night when everything went right as the Scottish Premier League's bottom club thumped Kilmarnock 5-1.

The Kilmarnock goalkeeper Marshall let a long-range effort from David Rowson to go through his legs at 1-1 just before the half-hour mark after which Aberdeen were always in charge.

The Dons, who had lost six of their last seven games, moved ahead after only five minutes through Hicham Zerouali's hooked volley. Kilmarnock defender Jim Lauchlan levelled with a 25th-minute header but Marshall's mistake was the platform for Aberdeen to seize control with an Eoin Jess effort on half-time.

With no relegation at stake because of Falkirk's failure to meet SPL stadium criteria, this game had little at stake.

Aberdeen went 4-1 up through a Thomas Solberg penalty, which also saw Kilmarnock's Sean Hessey sent off. In the 89th minute the substitute Robbie Winters scored from a yard out to give the Dons their biggest win of an often miserable campaign.

webTitle: Time bomb leaves Stoke feeling hurt

fields.headline: Time bomb leaves Stoke feeling hurt
fields.trailText: Stoke 3 - 2 Gillingham
fields.byline: Jeremy Alexander at the Britannia Stadium
fields.body:
Gillingham have been warned. "We will meet them with full force and a strong attitude," said Gudjon Thordarson of Wednesday's second leg. And he said it with feeling, like a geyser about to erupt.

Stoke's manager was unhappy about Gillingham's goal in the 95th minute that rebalanced the tie. "The referee told the players there were three minutes of injury-time, the fourth official held up a board indicating four and, when they scored, my watch showed four minutes 56 seconds." He had the watch with him, as if it were proof of injustice.

In fact Mike Dean, not unreasonably, played another minute after that to accommodate Stoke's injury-time wasting, in itself a puzzling ploy with home advantage. Thordarson rumbled on: "If referees can change what they've said, that is unacceptable."

He pondered basketball's "active time". Saturday ended with a rash of inactive time that next season's innovation - six seconds for keepers, microwave pingers for referees - would hardly have solved. At all events, Andy Hessenthaler's 20-yard diagonal strike was worth waiting for. "The team are happy they lost by just one goal," said Peter Taylor, Gillingham's manager. "We clawed our way back."

They needed to. Taylor must have felt the referee started the match too soon. Gilling ham could not get their bearings. Stoke's state-of-the-art stadium might have been lowered from the galaxy into a lunar landscape - and a Second Division moon to boot. No wonder the Icelanders fancied it - some corner of a foreign field and all that. The match was live on Iceland television.

Gillingham, picking up where they finished against Manchester City at Wembley last May, were a goal down in 25 seconds, two down in eight minutes. They had come out in moon boots or a daze of nightmarish memories. When they found their feet, they looked more poised than their opponents in a game of skill and flow, fun and fluctuation.

Where Stoke came in dangerous surges from midfield, Gillingham were never in a hurry, building through Junior Lewis - Carlton Palmer with control - until there was support for Iffy Onuora up front.

They needed a hand from Stoke to get into the game - a case perhaps of Icelanders melting in the sun or, as Thordarson put it: "We sat back, invited them in and lost shape." But, having ended the first half strongly at 1-2, they let Stoke dictate again. Peter Thorne headed against a post before tucking in his 30th goal of the season as Vince Bartram parried James O'Connor's header.

Stoke, rebuilt since November, left the First Division two years ago. Gillingham, recast in under-21 style by Taylor this season, have never been as close to it as they were a year ago, denied in injury-time. If it comes to that this week, and the saga goes against Stoke, expect the geyser to blow its top.

fields.headline: Good will hunting
fields.standfirst: Charities may be missing out on a whole sector of givers - the dead.  Nicola Hill  reports on legacies from beyond the grave
fields.trailText: Charities may be missing out on a whole sector of givers - the dead. Nicola Hill reports on legacies from beyond the grave
fields.body:
Eight out of 10 people give money to charity during their lifetime but at "deathtime" only 5% leave money to charity in their will. Are fundraisers doing enough to plug this gap? Or are they going to miss out on the potential offered by the ageing population?

Nina Botting, a planned-giving manager at the Tate Gallery says one of the reasons why fundraisers haven't converted more lifetime givers into so-called "deathtime" givers is because they are worried about the taboo of dying: "Fundraisers haven't wanted to upset loyal supporters by asking them about a legacy." But Botting warns this is short-term thinking. "A charity's supporter database is its best prospect for legacies and fundraisers shouldn't be so backward in coming forward."

The challenge is on for fundraisers as the number of people who could leave a legacy increases. The market is set to expand as those born in the post-war baby boom become potential legators. There are currently 9.8m people over the age of 60. In 30 years' time this figure will have increased to 20m. Not only is the ageing population increasing but they are generally wealthier than their forebears.

However, Kevin Waudby, legacy marketing manager at the Imperial Cancer Research Fund (ICRF), says it is difficult to predict what impact the ageing population will have on legacies. "Unlike their parents, baby boomers don't see charitable giving as a civic duty." He claims that fundraisers will have to work harder to appeal to the feel-good factor which motivates baby boomers to give.

Smee and Ford is a company specialising in legacy information. Its director, Richard Radcliffe, points out that some of the wealth may be eroded by the high cost of nursing care.

But it is not just external factors which fundraisers need to heed. Some fundraising techniques are putting people off leaving money to charities. "Direct marketing, telephone fundraising and approaching people on the street can make them change their wills." Radcliffe's research also revealed that people make false pledges, pretending to fundraisers that they have left money in their will. In a recent focus group, 90% of pledgers admitted that they had not pledged, even though they said they had.

Radcliffe believes legacy fundraising needs to be much friendlier and less intrusive. In fact he advocates not even asking people to leave a bequest. "The key to fundraising is the 'ask' but in legacy fundraising this shouldn't happen." Radcliffe thinks fundraisers, or preferably volunteers, should spend time trying to understand the motivations of potential legators.

Stephen Lee, senior research fellow in fundraising at South Bank University, also thinks the approach should be subtle. He says the fundraising approach should be face to face and part of encouraging committed support rather than focusing on the writing of a will. "If a charity's legacy leaflet arrives on the doormat, out of the blue, people see it as information about writing a will, not giving to a charity."

At the ICRF, legacy income accounts for £47.5m, over half of ICRF's annual revenue. So its approach is crucial. Waudby says the charity is targeting legacy prospects "more tightly" than before.

ICRF sends out direct marketing to find out who might be interested in leaving a legacy, and then follows up with face-to-face fundraising. The charity employs four regional legacy advisers.

Botting of the Tate agrees that fundraisers should be concentrating on current supporters but says fundraisers still haven't cracked the conundrum of reaching a wider range of people. "Roughly 70% of people who leave a legacy to your charity won't have been committed givers in their lifetime. They felt they had an affinity with your charity but you didn't know who they were."

So for fundraisers, the challenge over the next 30 years is three-fold. To turn lifetime supporters into "deathtime" givers. To find those who have genuinely written a will in the charity's favour and convert them into lifetime donors. And, in as subtle a way as possible, to make the most of the rising death rate.

fields.headline: Stewart assumes double responsibility
fields.trailText: Bolton 2 - 2 Ipswich
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin at the Reebok stadium
fields.body:
After three seasons of heartbreak Ipswich must at last feel someone upstairs is smiling on them. From 2-0 down yesterday they salvaged a draw and the explosion of relief from the away end at Marcus Stewart's second goal was entirely understandable.

After 28 minutes the chances of an Ipswich appearance at Wembley had looked faint, as a fourth successive play-off failure looked certain.

But far from cursing their luck and wondering about hoodoos, George Burley's players kept their cool and fought back. Showing the greater quality and composure for much of the match, they deserved this result. It was not, though, achieved without its worrying moments.

Had chances been taken, the result could have been 6-6. But there was plenty to make Burley think that a deserved change of fortune beckons. "There's no doubt we are recognised as a very good footballing side," the Ipswich manager said. "But we showed the other side of our game here, our battling qualities, desire and commitment. We did well to come back and in the end I'm disappointed not to have won."

Ipswich certainly controlled long patches of the game, performing as if they had failed to spot this was not Portman Road. But on the counter- attack Bolton were always dangerous. Sam Allardyce could rue the chances missed by Allan Johnston and Claus Jensen to make it 3-1.

Early on, though, Bolton were clinical. From Jensen's corner in the fifth minute Dean Holdsworth headed them in front at the near post. Saturday was a miserable afternoon for Holdsworth's brother David, part of the Birmingham side hammered 4-0 by Barnsley, but the family fortunes appeared to have changed.

All the more so when Eidur Gudjohnsen added No2, picking up a Jensen pass and sending a low shot past Richard Wright. At that point Bolton's supporters must have been contemplating dusting off the Wembley T-shirts. Losing play-off finalists to Watford last season, they were also beaten there by Aston Villa in the FA Cup semi-final last month.

But gradually Ipswich clawed their way back. The loss of Johnson in the 33rd minute with a neck injury that makes him doubtful for Wednesday could have been disastrous. But far from hampering them it appeared to help.

His replacement Martin Reuser had an energetic, influential game in midfield, setting up Stewart's equaliser and having two shots saved. Stewart, without a goal since mid-February, thrived on the added responsibility.

His first strike was a gem, a fierce first-time shot from almost 30 yards into the top corner. And after chances had come and gone at both ends, among them his own wild miss, he coolly added the second from Reuser's pass. A £2.5m signing from Huddersfield, Stewart will cost an extra £250,000 if he helps Ipswich into the Premiership. It is a cheque all at Ipswich would gladly sign.

Bolton have already failed in two semi-finals this season, going out on penalties to Villa and losing to Tranmere in the Worthington Cup. But Allardyce preferred to look on the bright side.

"We are disappointed but it's not the end of the world," he said. "In the play-offs this weekend only Stoke managed to win at home and our away form is as good as our home form." And they beat Ipswich at this stage a year ago.

fields.headline: Gabbiadini packs a punch
fields.trailText: Hartlepool 0 - 2 Darlington
fields.body:
It is amazing what a win can do. Darlington's manager David Hodgson was remarkably serene for a man who had been hit by a coin, abused, spat at and seen his striker Marco Gabbiadini punched by a Hartlepool supporter.

Perhaps such incidents are easier to accept after a victory that leaves your team with a decisive advantage. Gabbiadini, however, was not in a conciliatory mood after being hit as he made his way off a pitch lacking the protection of an extending tunnel, such as those in use at many Premiership grounds. Darlington should install one before Wednesday's second leg.

"Marco took a fair whack on the jaw and naturally he's not happy," said Hodgson. "He wanted some action but I said we should shut the door on it. Hopefully he's calmed down. Good luck to the police if they want to pursue it, but I'm not getting this club involved. There's always one individual who wants to do something silly, but I'm not interested."

Hodgson spoke with one eye on the second leg and an acceptance that the rivalry between the two sets of supporters makes these matches comparable to any Premiership derby. "There may be 50,000 fewer fans but the feelings are just the same," he said. "We have to play it cool. It's absolutely vital that nothing goes off in the return match."

At least Darlington's two-goal lead means the second leg is unlikely to possess the same intensity as here, where a crowd of 6,995 - three times the average - was entertained in a vibrant manner that should tempt back a number of the irregulars next season, even if Hartlepool stay down.

Darlington's first break came when Craig Liddle, later to score the opening goal, escaped a red card after fouling James Coppinger in the fifth minute. "Liddle could have gone," said Hartlepool's captain Michael Barron. "It looked like James was clean through and he was the last man."

The visitors scored the crucial second from the spot and Hartlepool were again aggrieved because Glenn Naylor appeared to be offside before Martin Hollund pulled him down. The goalkeeper was dismissed and Gabbiadini drove the penalty past Andy Dibble.

Hartlepool, prompted shrewdly by Paul Stephenson, hit the post through Ian Clark in the first half and Craig Midgley squandered a marvellous chance in the second. Now they face probable disappointment and the certainty of FA action.

fields.headline: Clarke settles family debate
fields.trailText: Barnet 1 - 2 Peterborough
fields.byline: Mark Redding at the Underhill stadium
fields.body:
The net curtains were twitching, the phone lines trembling with gossip. It was time to lift the veil on the furtive swapping going on in one of London's primmest suburbs.

Meet John Still, who was once wed to Peterborough before he fell into the arms of Barnet; Barry Fry, who lifted Barnet out of non-league obscurity before finding happiness with Peterborough; Ken Charlery, who had three spells with Peterborough before settling down with Barnet; and finally Andy Clarke, whose roving eye took him from Barnet to Wimbledon before he teamed up with Fry once more at Peterborough.

Clarke it was whose sharp piece of opportunism settled a fast and exciting game when he hit an angled shot into the corner of the net in the 68th minute. With so many old flames reigniting, the game could have been consumed by sentimentality but Clarke quickly put the mockers on that idea. "It didn't make me sad, it's just a job at the end of the day," he said. "You're always having to go back to clubs you've played for."

The 33-year-old striker consistently put the spice into Posh, and he would have had a double had not his team-mate Dave Farrell put a toe to his goalbound shot in an offside position, ensuring it was ruled out.

That prompted Fry into a trademark ranting dash along the touchline that left him and Farrell shouting obscenities at each other. "The tie's not over yet," Fry promised. "Barnet are quite capable of coming to London Road and beating us."

But on this evidence the Bees will struggle to score enough goals, particularly in open play. Their equaliser, which came after Jason Lee had put the visitors in front on five minutes, was unsurprisingly from a set-piece, Mark "Pearl" Arber smuggling the ball over the line from a corner.

Considering this was possibly the last game to be played at Underhill, which falls short of Football League standards, Barnet's manager Still was defiantly upbeat. "I love going to Peterborough, I've got a lot of friends there," he said, "and, if we score first, it will be a different game."

Meet John Still, who was once wed to Peterborough before he fell into the arms of Barnet; Barry Fry, who lifted Barnet out of non-league obscurity before finding happiness with Peterborough; Ken Charlery, who had three spells with Peterborough before settling down with Barnet; and finally Andy Clarke, whose roving eye took him from Barnet to Wimbledon before he teamed up with Fry once more at Peterborough. Clarke it was whose sharp piece of opportunism settled a fast and exciting game when he hit an angled shot into the corner of the net in the 68th minute. With so many old flames reigniting, the game could have been consumed by sentimentality but Clarke quickly put the mockers on that idea. "It didn't make me sad, it's just a job at the end of the day," he said. "You're always having to go back to clubs you've played for." The 33-year-old striker consistently put the spice into Posh, and he would have had a double had not his team-mate Dave Farrell put a toe to his goalbound shot in an offside position, ensuring it was ruled out. That prompted Fry into a trademark ranting dash along the touchline that left him and Farrell shouting obscenities at each other. "The tie's not over yet," Fry promised. "Barnet are quite capable of coming to London Road and beating us." But on this evidence the Bees will struggle to score enough goals, particularly in open play. fields.headline: Tourists go on the defensive
fields.standfirst: Johnson shines in final hit-out before Lord's
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe 315 & 75-0 Essex 249 Match drawn
fields.body:
There was a Christian rally in the park over the river from the County Ground yesterday. Games were played in the afternoon heat, songs were sung and there was some talk of salvation. Evidently nobody thought of popping over the bridge for some missionary work by trying to save this sleepy cricket match, which needed nothing less than divine intervention.

And so the modest crowd, who had little else to do by all accounts, suffered in silence. They will get their reward in heaven. In these days of bribery and match-fixing allegations, the phrases "collusion" and "contrived finish" are on a par with "confidence trick" and "card-sharp". You wouldn't touch them with Darren Gough's spare thigh pad.

So once the first day of this match and much of the second had been washed out, the chances of anything more meaningful than mere pre-test practice for the tourists completely disappeared.

Last year Essex collected £1,000 per man from the Vodafone award scheme, the bonuses given to counties who beat the tourists, when they ambushed New Zealand. Yesterday they settled for splitting £2,750 as the match ended in a predictable draw with Zimbabwe 75 for none in their second innings.

Except for the Zimbabwean openers Grant Flower and Trevor Gripper, who were just starting to fill their boots against some indifferent bowling, the end came not a moment too soon.

But the tourists have gained some positives from the weekend. Neil Johnson made 83 and then took three wickets with his seamers to collect the man of the match award. Guy Whittall, competing with Stuart Carlisle for a test spot, made 54 and took two cheap wickets including that of the England captain Nasser Hussain. And Henry Olonga, once regarded as the rabbit's rabbit, somehow contrived to make a career-best 45.

Olonga's bowling too was sharp, albeit relatively expensive, on a pitch that remained helpful throughout. He will form a testing partnership with Heath Streak, who has been netting gingerly and seems certain to play at Lord's.

Of most interest, though, was the bowling of Pommie Mbangwa, who took two for 47 from 30 overs. He runs in busily and delivers briskly rather than fast, but swung the ball away late at times to a disciplined line of off-stump to a deep-set field.

It is this which could produce stalemate cricket at Lord's. In the winter, Hansie Cronje needed little bidding to set such fields once the shine had gone from the new ball, hoping for an indiscretion.

England, and Hussain in particular, would have little to do with it then, and yesterday Hussain showed he has lost none of his own discipline. He took 20 minutes to add to his overnight 17 and batted 12 minutes short of three hours for 33, before heaving wildly at another wide one and getting himself caught behind. Zimbabwe will not find him so accommodating come Thursday.
