webTitle: Toughing it out as anarchy looms at home

fields.headline: Toughing it out as anarchy looms at home
fields.trailText: Politics almost drove Zimbabwe's cricketers home, but as the first test looms they have found new strength as Donald McRae discovered.
fields.body:
They sat together in a raggedy circle near the middle of an empty cricket ground in Chelmsford. Fifteen Zimbabwean cricketers looked down and fiddled with their boots or picked at stray tufts of grass as they listened to the urgent voice of the man they had gathered around one afternoon last week. Andy Flower spoke with a stony hardness which once, in more ordinary times, might have seemed incongruous when set against his pretty surname.

Yet Flower is not a man given to soft prattling on even the happiest of occasions - and these are bleak days for Zimbabwe and their lost cricketers. On a sunlit field in Essex, 6,000 miles away from the farms and cities of a darkening country they still call home, the need for blunt talk was paramount.

Flower scanned the lowered heads of the 11 white and four young black men who make up his squad. He knew them inside out. Starting with his brother, Grant, the 32-year-old captain's gaze moved to his deputy, Heath Streak, who was one of six in the forlorn party to come from a farming background. Streak had arrived in England a few days after the others.

The big fast bowler and his father, Denis, had been forced to draw up contingency plans for the terrifying event of further trouble on their cattle farm 45 miles outside Bulawayo. Although Denis Streak had managed to "placate the 20 or so invaders" who arrived at their gates in mid-April, a fourth Zimbabwean farmer had been murdered the previous Sunday.

Even Streak's jocular fast-bowling partner, the dreadlock-swinging, opera-singing Henry Olonga, was bowed and silent. Olonga and Streak, the black and white icons of Zimbabwean cricket, had known each other since they went to the same junior school.

"I don't sing as well as Henry," Streak told me, "but we've come a long way together. As a kid he was shy and reclusive - not that you'd believe that now."

Sitting alongside him, 16-year-old Tatenda Taibu was half the age of his captain. He and Flower both played for the same club in Harare, the quaintly-named Old Winstonians.

Even though Olonga had been Zimbabwe's first black Test cricketer, the cherubic Taibu insisted that "I only have two heroes. As a batsman I love Sachin Tendulkar. I model myself on him because he is also very short. I want to break all his batting records. But as a wicketkeeper and a Zimbabwean I can only see an idol in Andy Flower. We have something between us. The first day he saw me play he gave me his gloves. He's been my teacher ever since."

Taibu had also told me that "the stuff at home is difficult for the other guys. But I'm only 16. I've got nothing to do with all these problems. I just want to focus on cricket."

It was a simple message which Flower, in the centre of his fraught ring, used to underpin his passionate speech. His words were plain but forceful. After the pain which had trailed them for two months, they knew each other's strengths and weaknesses better than ever before. Doubt and fear had split a once united team. It was time to seal the cracks.

There was no need even to mention David Lloyd. Three years ago, after a drawn series in Zimbabwe, the former England coach had made his notorious "we flippin' murdered 'em" comment. Life and death in Zimbabwe had become too serious to reach for glib cricketing jibes. It was time to look forward. Slowly, the heads began to lift.

Within 10 minutes, just like any other team intent on delaying a return to fielding practice, they were running and whooping as a frenetic game of eight-a-side football reeled across Essex's county ground. Their skill in controlling a cricket ball with their feet might have been suspect but the old camaraderie was unmistakable.

Jeff Thomson, the great Australian fast bowler, tossed his silvery mane as the helter-skelter game swept across the outfield. When he joined Zimbabwe as their specialist bowling coach a week earlier, Thomson had grunted that "they're tough buggers. In the same circumstances an English or even an Australian team would've packed their bags and gone home..."

The team manager Dan Stannard had spent the entire tour rejecting each new headline which suggested that the Zimbabweans were actually about to board the next plane to Harare. At the same time, he fought hard to stay relentlessly cheery, for his own son worked on a farm in Zimbabwe.

"We've turned things around," Stannard stressed. "There's no point denying the team were down. They were disappointed in the West Indies and some returned to Zimbabwe for a few days. Others flew straight here. We came to England as a very fragmented unit."

Against Hampshire in their first match, not even rain could dampen a sparkling partnership between Alistair Campbell, who made 150, and Taibu, whose 36 runs were a glorious cameo of youthful assurance. Yet afterwards, to share a few days with the Zimbabweans in Canterbury, where they were humiliated by Kent, was to witness a team facing ruin. Flower even made a grim admission. The tour was on the brink of collapse.

"It was bitterly cold in Canterbury," Stannard agreed, "and our minds were elsewhere. There were also some internal problems in the squad. The players had been under real strain. But we sat down and talked about the situation in a very transparent way. The mood is now upbeat. We're in England until late July and we're determined to make this a winning tour."

A more reliable guide as to how they might fare against England in the first test at Lords on Thursday can be found in their recent West Indian trials. "It was a strange tour, and the first Test was the strangest time of all," explained Neil Johnson, Zimbabwe's best player alongside Flower. "For four days we really hurt the West Indies. They were on the rack. We only needed to score 99 in our second innings to win.

"We knew it would be hard on that track with Curtly Ambrose and Courtney Walsh steaming in. So the plan was that I would attack them from the start. But I hit a long-hop straight to point. They didn't bowl a bad ball after that. We were all out for 67.

"It was disheartening because we had outplayed them for so long. Even in the second test we scored 300 in the first innings and had them rocking at 120 for 5. But a few decisions went against us. We should have won that series 2-0. It just went wrong."

Olonga's dreads flapped in agitation. "It was terrible! The news in Zimbabwe turned bad as soon as we arrived in the Caribbean. The atmosphere became pretty sour. Things are better now, but it's often hard to find motivation. Cricket is just a game - what's happening at home is serious."

Yet even political gravity could not curb Olonga. "This is still a cricket tour. It has the same old routine: get on the bus, go to the ground, practise or play, get back on the bus and arrive at a new hotel which looks the same as the one you'd left that morning. It kills me!"

Olonga had hit his high-camp stride. "I paint, I draw, I sing. I've done drama. I've enjoyed a multi-faceted life and, for some, this makes me a weirdo. But I have the ability to be more than just a cricketer. It all began when I was 14 and [was] offered a minor role as a girl in Oklahoma.

"They told me I was the ugliest girl the world of theatre had ever seen. I vowed from then on to only go for the good-looking parts. The next time they were looking for a lead it turned out that I could reach all the high notes. I could sing."

"But I'm not sure where this opera thing comes from. I can learn an Italian aria but, to be honest, I don't even know five operas. I want to move into R 'n' B and pop. I've got the groove."

According to the Zimbabwe coach Andy Pycroft, Olonga has also found his bowling groove. "Henry used to be wild, like a spray-gun, but his control now matches his incredible strike-rate. He's a gifted feller. Youngsters like Tatenda Taibu are following him. A quarter of this squad is black - and that's on merit.

"Soccer might be more popular in Zimbabwe, but cricket is closing the gap. Black kids are taking up cricket in vast numbers. We're the only Zimbabweans playing sport at the highest level and have a great chance to lift the whole country. We're not here to compete under duress. We're here to win - starting at Lords."

Johnson has particularly fond memories of the St John's Wood ground where, in the World Cup, he scored 132 not out against Australia. "Lords is huge," Johnson marvelled. "I take photographs whenever I visit the place. We've been waiting to take on England for a long time there. They're not so patronising now - they also expect a real contest. They know we can shock anyone."

Heath Streak ambled over, his eyes alight at the prospect. The meaty farming man rubbed his injured knee in real hope that he too might play his part. "It's still swollen," he sighed, "but I'd better make it. My family are coming over specially to watch us at Lords. It'll be good to see them again. Even though we try to keep in touch it's not the same as seeing them safe and sound.

"They're still on the farm. We try not to worry but I'd be lying if I said it was ever far from our minds. A lot of us, both black and white, have been through terrible pain in Zimbabwe. All we can do is hope and pray that peace will eventually return. The country deserves it. Until then, we just have to stay tough on this tour. After all, we're the lucky ones. We're the guys who, once in a while, get a chance to just think about cricket..."

webTitle: Singalonga Olonga worthy of place in the pantheon of painful pop

fields.headline: Singalonga Olonga worthy of place in the pantheon of painful pop
fields.trailText: The week's wackiest combination of music and haircut belonged to Henry Olonga, Zimbabwe's first black cricketer, a guest on John Inverdale's On Side - television's first attempt, I believe, to combine a chat show with the Crystal Maze.
fields.body:
Strange the potency of cheap music, as someone (it might have been Tony Blackburn) once said, and as the BBC proved in Match of the Day - The Musical yesterday morning.

Pavarotti, for instance. At this remove, his Nessun Dorma, played to death and scuffed and worn like a pair of old shoes at the back of the cupboard, might sound a little cheesy, but seeing again the montage sequence with which the BBC tied up their coverage of the 1990 World Cup, it was clear that this was nothing less than the rebirth of soccer; and without the soundtrack it was nothing.

More than Sky, more than the refreshing of our old stadiums, more than the influx of foreign stars, we have Puccini to thank for the robust and wealthy state of our national game.

The Italia 90 re-run was part of a montage of montages dug up by the BBC to fill the Match of the Day Sunday morning repeat slot in the absence of any Premiership action from Saturday. While most of the goals, saves and fluffs were achingly familiar, it was interesting to note how the influence of Sky, whose closing musical sequences are often the best part of their Premiership coverage, has swung the BBC away from the classics towards rather dreary Britpop.

Maybe it is an age thing with me, but the more recent medleys - Manchester United's treble, a celebration of Brazilian football - seemed to have been cut to some relatively undistinguished pop music with which I was not familiar, while the BBC's greatest hits enjoyed the better tunes - C'est Si Bon for David Ginola, Mad About The Boy for Michael Owen, I'm Gonna Wash That Man Right Out Of My Hair for a bad haircut selection from the 1994 World Cup.

The week's wackiest combination of music and haircut, however, belonged to Henry Olonga, Zimbabwe's first black cricketer, a guest on John Inverdale's On Side, television's first attempt, I believe, to combine a chat show with the Crystal Maze.

The On Side set, clearly designed by people who find the paintings of Salvador Dali rather too literal for their taste, seems to grow each time I watch the show. The effect is that guests, as they wander down the long corridor to join Invers, to the accompaniment of some spooky guitar music, now seem to be trapped in Ikea. "I've bought a lampshade, I've eaten the meatballs. Let me out," you half expect them to shout.

What Olonga did was even stranger. He sang opera, a capella. To realise how weird this was, you have to know a little about Olonga's appearance. The bowler manages to combine the speaking voice of Ralph Fiennes with the looks of, well, I hardly like to say. Golden dreadlocks perched somewhat uncomfortably atop smooth, brown, finely chiselled features; it's the love child of Victor Lewis-Smith and Grace Jones, if that is not too terrible a thought for a family newspaper on a Monday morning.

Olonga's ditty was called Tristesse, an Italian song he apparently heard on a Jose Carreras album. He just stood up and started singing - the whole thing - while Inverdale listened. It is not easy being sung to, as anyone who has ever appeared in a musical will attest, but Invers made a reasonably good fist of looking enraptured, whereas a lesser man might have told Henry to sit down and shut up.

Just to add to the oddness of it all, Inverdale was sporting a black eye, which I suspect he did not receive in the course of his chat-show duties. He is geniality itself, and even Stan Collymore, another of last week's guests, seemed unlikely to bop him one.

Inverdale went over familiar Stan ground - Ulrika, the fire extinguisher, the incident with the concrete mixer (actually I may have imagined one of those) - which the striker spoke about entirely in footballer-speak. Describing his decision to seek professional help, he said: "I hadn't been going as well as I should have done, as a person." Interesting. Perhaps it's all part of the therapy.

Collymore had left by the time Olonga went into his party piece, and it is possible I misread Invers's expression as, "Where is Stan with a fire extinguisher when you really need him?" Pity he wasn't booked for Stockholm.

All right, I know the Eurovision Song Contest is not strictly speaking a sporting occasion, and more expert eyes will no doubt be cast over the event elsewhere in the newspaper, but given the imminence of Euro 2000, I thought it might be worthwhile in the cause of research to see how we interact with our European neighbours in a competitive context. Also, my new rule is that any event on which you can bet should be classified as a sport.

I backed Holland - the only way a music lover can find Eurovision tolerable is to have a financial interest - and I still refuse to accept they were beaten by a Danish duo who looked like Kenny Rogers and his older brother, by a song from Ireland that included the lyric "I made a candle in a dream I thought I heard" and by a German entry entitled Wadde Hadde Duddle Da (I am not making this up). A stitch-up, I'd say. This cheap music was not so much potent as putrid.

At this remove, his Nessun Dorma, played to death and scuffed and worn like a pair of old shoes at the back of the cupboard, might sound a little cheesy, but seeing again the montage sequence with which the BBC tied up their coverage of the 1990 World Cup, it was clear that this was nothing less than the rebirth of soccer; and without the soundtrack it was nothing. The Italia 90 re-run was part of a montage of montages dug up by the BBC to fill the Match of the Day Sunday morning repeat slot in the absence of any Premiership action from Saturday. While most of the goals, saves and fluffs were achingly familiar, it was interesting to note how the influence of Sky, whose closing musical sequences are often the best part of their Premiership coverage, has swung the BBC away from the classics towards rather dreary Britpop. Maybe it is an age thing with me, but the more recent medleys - Manchester United's treble, a celebration of Brazilian football - seemed to have been cut to some relatively undistinguished pop music with which I was not familiar, while the BBC's greatest hits enjoyed the better tunes - C'est Si Bon for David Ginola, Mad About The Boy for Michael Owen, I'm Gonna Wash That Man Right Out Of My Hair for a bad haircut selection from the 1994 World Cup. The week's wackiest combination of music and haircut, however, belonged to Henry Olonga, Zimbabwe's first black cricketer, a guest on John Inverdale's On Side, television's first attempt, I believe, to combine a chat show with the Crystal Maze. The On Side set, clearly designed by people who find the paintings of Salvador Dali rather too literal for their taste, seems to grow each time I watch the show. The effect is that guests, as they wander down the long corridor to join Invers, to the accompaniment of some spooky guitar music, now seem to be trapped in Ikea. "I've bought a lampshade, I've eaten the meatballs. Let me out," you half expect them to shout. What Olonga did was even stranger. He sang opera, a capella. To realise how weird this was, you have to know a little about Olonga's appearance. The bowler manages to combine the speaking voice of Ralph Fiennes with the looks of, well, I hardly like to say. Golden dreadlocks perched somewhat uncomfortably atop smooth, brown, finely chiselled features; it's the love child of Victor Lewis-Smith and Grace Jones, if that is not too terrible a thought for a family newspaper on a Monday morning. Olonga's ditty was called Tristesse, an Italian song he apparently heard on a Jose Carreras album. He just stood up and started singing - the whole thing - while Inverdale listened. It is not easy being sung to, as anyone who has ever appeared in a musical will attest, but Invers made a reasonably good fist of looking enraptured, whereas a lesser man might have told Henry to sit down and shut up. Just to add to the oddness of it all, Inverdale was sporting a black eye, which I suspect he did not receive in the course of his chat-show duties. He is geniality itself, and even Stan Collymore, another of last week's guests, seemed unlikely to bop him one. Inverdale went over familiar Stan ground - Ulrika, the fire extinguisher, the incident with the concrete mixer (actually I may have imagined one of those) - which the striker spoke about entirely in footballer-speak. Describing his decision to seek professional help, he said: "I hadn't been going as well as I should have done, as a person." Interesting. Perhaps it's all part of the therapy. Collymore had left by the time Olonga went into his party piece, and it is possible I misread Invers's expression as, "Where is Stan with a fire extinguisher when you really need him?" Pity he wasn't booked for Stockholm. All right, I know the Eurovision Song Contest is not strictly speaking a sporting occasion, and more expert eyes will no doubt be cast over the event elsewhere in the newspaper, but given the imminence of Euro 2000, I thought it might be worthwhile in the cause of research to see how we interact with our European neighbours in a competitive context. Also, my new rule is that any event on which you can bet should be classified as a sport. I backed Holland - the only way a music lover can find Eurovision tolerable is to have a financial interest - and I still refuse to accept they were beaten by a Danish duo who looked like Kenny Rogers and his older brother, by a song from Ireland that included the lyric "I made a candle in a dream I thought I heard" and by a German entry entitled Wadde Hadde Duddle Da (I am not making this up). A stitch-up, I'd say. This cheap music was not so much potent as putrid.

fields.headline: PR takes a bow
fields.standfirst: Suddenly fair votes look more attractive
fields.trailText: For more than a year after its publication, Lord Jenkins's 1998                                                    essay on electoral reform languished. That formidable political                                                    artist had produced a plan as readable as it was do-able. But it                                                    was not just Tony Blair's vacillation that put it out of sight and                                                    out of mind. Proportional representation (PR) had too little                                                    bearing, it seemed, on decisions affecting public welfare. Then                                                    came devolution.
fields.body:
For more than a year after its publication, Lord Jenkins's 1998 essay on electoral reform languished. That formidable political artist had produced a plan as readable as it was do-able. But it was not just Tony Blair's vacillation that put it out of sight and out of mind. Proportional representation (PR) had too little bearing, it seemed, on decisions affecting public welfare. Then came devolution.

In the past 12 months PR, in fact Lord Jenkins's preferred marriage of territorial representation and top-up lists, has been tried and found flavoursome. People can handle it. In Scotland, Northern Ireland, Wales and London electors have confronted PR's allegedly intractable forms. As a result working administrations have been formed, ministers appointed and - compared with Westminster (not exactly the acme of fair, open and honest governance) - the public business carried on. To judge the various assemblies is to judge the attempt to make representation fairer.

Of course it is early days. But there in Scotland's new parliament last week, standing in for Donald Dewar as first minister, was Liberal Democrat leader Jim Wallace - showing that PR can produce civilised, reasonably effective inter-party administration. Will those words come to be applied to London with its double cohabitation between mayor and assembly and, within the assembly, between political rivals? Paul Murphy, Welsh secretary, said on Friday that because PR had sacrificed "stability" in Cardiff - for which presumably read Taffia hegemony - few would favour it for Westminster.

His was a warning shot as manifesto-writing season approaches - it needs to be read along with Robin Cook's equally vehement conclusion in the other direction. Meanwhile, first-past-the-posters have lost their trump card, the overwhelming results of the 1997 Westminster election. It is time to revisit the Ashdown-Blair rhetoric of the summer of 1997: PR could deliver a Commons that better reflected voters' preferences and delivered progressive, left-liberal government. Paul Whiteley's 1999 survey of Labour activists showed a majority favour reform. Some big unions - flexing their muscles in the run up to the national policy forum taking place in a month or so - are dead against. It is time to hark again to the oracle. Now we have dense experience against which to measure Lord Jenkins's prescriptions.

fields.headline: The making of a manifesto
fields.standfirst: The Guardian is creating a manifesto for Britain's future - and wants readers to help write it. Jonathan Freedland explains
fields.trailText: The Guardian is creating a manifesto for Britain's future - and wants readers to help write it. Jonathan Freedland explains
fields.body:
Labour is already working on it. All through the summer, the party's highest officials will debate and draft the document which will present the government to the nation. It is the Labour manifesto for a second term, and few texts could matter more as a guide to the future of our country. For in that document Labour will not only seek to win power. It will also lay out its plan for the next five years - explaining what Britain needs to do next.

Starting today, the Guardian will do the same. Over the next four months, in the pages of the newspaper and here on Guardian Unlimited, the Guardian will set out on its own road to the manifesto. It will be a task for the writers of this newspaper - and for its readers.

Each week, Guardian specialists will set out their vision for their area - beginning with John Carvel's plan for education. These will be big-picture, "blue-sky" sketches of what should form Labour's programme for the coming five years.

The next step will be what the politicians call "consultation". We urge those with a direct interest - in the first case, parents, students and teachers - as well as general readers to add their thoughts to the ideal sketched out here. That might consist of letters to the editor or messages posted on the manifesto threads on our talkboards.

Those will then be assessed, along with the piece published here, by the former Whitehall mandarin, Sir Peter Kemp. A veteran of the top echelons of both the Treasury and the Cabinet Office, he will submit our Guardian wishlists to a "reality check" - and seek to reconcile one departmental demand with another.

Over the summer, we will go through an experience usually confined to Britain's most senior politicians - and we will do it in the open. In time for Labour's annual conference in September, the Guardian - writers and readers together - will have drawn up its own manifesto for Britain's future.

webTitle: Vision for a more prosperous society

fields.headline: Vision for a more prosperous society
fields.standfirst: Road to a manifesto
fields.trailText: When Tony Blair named his top three priorities as education, education and education, he did so for a reason. Education was the most important policy for the nation's economic survival and social cohesion. He was right - and he still is.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair named his top three priorities as education, education and education, he did so for a reason. Education was the most important policy for the nation's economic survival and social cohesion. He was right - and he still is.

That belief led him to make this promise ahead of the last general election in 1997: "Education will be our number one priority, and we will increase the share of national income spent on education as we decrease it on the bills of economic and social failure."

Was that promise kept? In a sense. Over the last three years of this parliament there will be record real terms growth in spending on state schools. But this follows two years of sticking to Conservative plans with only marginal adjustments upward. The result is that spending over the lifetime of Mr Blair's government will probably average a lower percentage of GDP than John Major's. This is not good enough.

So the first commitment should be to repeat - and honour - that 1997 funding pledge. And it should be made clear that, in the next term, secondary schools, further education colleges and universities will get a fairer share of resources. Until now the rewards for improving quality have gone disproportionately to primary schools.

If there is one promise people remember from the last election it is to "cut class sizes to 30 or under for five, six and seven-year-olds by using money from the assisted places scheme". Now that promise to reduce overcrowding should go further. The obvious place to start is a maximum class size of 30 for eight to 11-year-olds. It seems daft that classes of 30 seven-year-olds should reassemble into larger groups for their final years of primary school.

So far ministers have resisted making a promise in this form. They think it would be expensive and impractical to build more classrooms in popular primaries on cramped sites. We need early figures from them so we can have a public debate. At least there should be a cast-iron commitment that every class over 30 has at least one fully-trained classroom assistant as well as the teacher. The aim is an adult-pupil ratio no worse than, say, 1:17.

There should also be the offer of a free nursery place for every three-year-old whose parents want it, providing at least five half-days a week of pre-school education - as offered in Wales in 1999.

For the same reason, ministers should resist the temptation to raise targets for 11-year-olds in national tests. It will be a great achievement if, as is likely, 80% reach the required standard by the summer of 2002. For the next phase, the goal should be to raise the performance of under-achieving primary schools and education authorities, rather than to reach a more ambitious national average.

Parents express concern that David Blunkett's targets for under-11s cause stress and stand in the way of creativity. Fear of lost childhood is a backlash waiting to happen. If he feels naked without targets, let him concentrate on the wilderness years between 11 and 14.

There is a more general point. A catchphrase of education policy in Labour's first term was "intervention in inverse proportion to success". It has not felt like that. If Labour ministers want us to believe they are succeeding, they should be promising to reduce their interventions, not increase them. That should mean less prescription from Whitehall, a less confrontational attitude from Ofsted, and more discretion for headteachers.

The huge disparity of funding between schools must be addressed, but not by further emasculating local education authorities; if they work well, they can help their schools more appropriately than distant Whitehall. It is time to stop bashing them.

Time too to concentrate on the morale of teachers. In time many will come to ac cept performance-related pay, but they are more concerned about their workload than their income. Administrative support on a large scale, proper photocopying facilities, free laptops and a properly-funded system of sabbaticals would ease the recruitment crisis.

Even bigger money will be needed to repair buildings. In 1997 Labour estimated the cost was £5bn-£6bn and by the election the government will have tackled only about half the job. On the current expenditure side, there will be mileage in extending the popular Excellence in Cities programme to help stressed schools. No government will now suggest directing children to particular schools to tackle the problems of polarisation identified in the recent Guardian series by Nick Davies. But any government should provide the resources to alleviate or remedy acute social disadvantages that stand in the way of learning.

Since league tables have become a fixation, let them measure how good schools are instead of reflecting the relative privilege of their intake. Pupil identification numbers will be needed to measure the progress of individuals through the system to show the value added at each stage. The system - with protection of civil liberties - should be put in place during the next parliament.

And - as is usual for manifestos - that leaves too little space for further and higher education. A huge increase in students has contributed to a drastic reduction in money available for each one. Classes and tutorial groups have swelled in number and lecturers have an increased workload and a real-terms cut in income. This does not help deliver a quality service. Ministers must promise to implement the Bett report to improve pay at the top and bottom end of the university scale and eliminate gross gender discrimination. They must give similar attention to further education.

With the sum of all this as the vision, Britain can look forward not only to a better educated population but a more prosperous, more civilised society. We should aim for nothing less.

Do you think John Carvel has got it right - or is there more that should be done in the second term? Send your thoughts to our letters page, or join the debate on our talkboards

fields.headline: Prescott wants £19bn for housing
fields.trailText: John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, is pressing for a huge investment in public housing by allocating an extra £19bn over the next five years to renovate estates around the country.
fields.body:
John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, is pressing for a huge investment in public housing by allocating an extra £19bn over the next five years to renovate estates around the country.

The Department of the Environment has told the chancellor, Gordon Brown, that unless more funds are put aside in the forthcoming comprehensive spending review, by 2010 tens of thousands of properties could be written off as beyond repair.

Mr Prescott is linking his demand to the Treasury with a commitment to hive off most council houses to new social companies which, unlike local authorities, will be able to borrow on the open market, using projected income from rents as security for loans.

In effect, the deputy prime minister is promising to extend his much-vaunted public-private partnership approach into social housing - although he totally rejects the view that this is an attempt to privatise council housing by the back door.

Although 400,000 council houses, mainly from smaller authorities, have so far been hived off to housing associations and new companies, plans are now in hand for the biggest transfer so far.

This financial year, councils are due to lose another 280,000 (including Birmingham's entire stock of 93,500 homes), provided tenants approve in a series of ballots.

Mr Prescott's plan is given support today by Cambridge University's property research unit. In a report for the charity, Shelter, it argues that sufficient investment will only be forthcoming if councils hive off their housing stock.

The report will be presented to the housing minister, Nick Raynsford, at a conference today. It calculates an extra £6.9bn annually is needed to provide lower cost homes, particularly in the booming south-east where people on average incomes cannot afford mortgages.Although much of the cash would come from the private sector, the report says the government would have to provide another £1.4bn.

It warns that Britain faces an "unprecedented housing crisis", with 700,000 families in bad housing or technically homeless - and a further 85,000 annually facing a similar fate. To meet demand, building in the green belt, particularly in the south-east, may have to be considered.

webTitle: British troops back Sierra Leone anti-rebel effort

fields.headline: British troops back Sierra Leone anti-rebel effort
fields.standfirst: Read Geoff Hoon's statement in full
fields.trailText: Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, today told the Commons that the rebels in Sierra Leone were "on the back foot" as the UN and the government took the initiative, backed by British troops.
fields.body:
Geoff Hoon, the defence secretary, today told the Commons that the rebels in Sierra Leone were "on the back foot" as the UN and the government took the initiative, backed by British troops.

Mr Hoon gave an account of the British presence that went well beyond its original mission of evacuating foreign nationals from the former British colony in west Africa.

But he reiterated that British troops would not be deployed in a combat role with UN forces, adding that Britain would withdraw its contingent when the UN mission reached its full strength of 11,500.

Prime Minister Tony Blair has said that British troops would stay in Sierra Leone no longer than the middle of June. Iain Duncan Smith, the shadow defence minister, criticised the government for being "less than frank" throughout the whole deployment, pointing out that the operation, initially for seven days, had now slipped to a month.

But as long as British troops were there, he said, the government should provide clearer "rules of engagement" so that they would not be "locked into an artificial self-defence mandate" that repeated the mistakes of Bosnia and Sierra Leone itself.

In his statement, Mr Hoon made clear that British forces had the firepower to "respond robustly" if attacked. He claimed that the deployment of 600 British troops had been an "outstanding success", evacuating 450 people and helping to stabilise the situation.

While the evacuation was Britain's primary goal, Mr Hoon acknowledged that British troops were now providing technical advice to UN forces in Sierra Leone. "Our presence has contributed to the stabilisation of the situation," he said, prompting Mr Duncan Smith to make the accusation that Britain is in effect running the UN mission.

But the prospect of Britain joining the UN mission held no terror for the Liberal Democrats. Earlier, Menzies Campbell, the Lib Dem foreign affairs and defence spokesman, said British troops should become part of the UN force in Sierra Leone.

In becoming the first main party spokesman to suggest a broader role for UK forces, Mr Campbell said: "I see absolutely no reason why British forces should not be in blue berets. They are in blue berets for all practical consequences at the moment and there is absolutely no reason why we shouldn't bring to the whole of the United Nations force formally the kind of stability and effect we have been bringing informally since our troops arrived there last week."

Soldiers from the 1st Battalion of the Parachute Regiment have been guarding positions around the capital Freetown and Lungi airport, as well as giving military assistance to government troops fighting rebels from the Revolutionary United Front, who are thought to be holding hundreds of UN peacekeepers hostage.

Mr Campbell added: "I think the British government should be willing to contribute a force for some considerable time as long as we can do that consistent with our other responsibilities, as long as that force has sufficiently robust rules of engagement and a sufficiently effective mandate from the United Nations..."

In his Commons statement, Mr Hoon said Britain had received reports that a number of UN personnel had been released and British officer Major Andrew Harrison was fit and well and under the protection of the Indian Battalion in the east of Sierra Leone.

Liberia's president, Charles Taylor, said last night that more than 130 out of 500 UN peacekeepers held captive by Sierra Leone's rebel movement had been released into Liberian custody.

Mr Taylor said 15 of the 139 freed captives were flown by a government-chartered helicopter to Liberia's capital, Monrovia, on Sunday evening while the remaining 124 were waiting to be evacuated from the Liberian border town of Foya, some 130 miles to the north.

Earlier, Menzies Campbell, the Lib Dem foreign affairs and defence spokesman, said British troops should become part of the UN force in Sierra Leone. In becoming the first main party spokesman to suggest a broader role for UK forces, Mr Campbell said: "I see absolutely no reason why British forces should not be in blue berets. They are in blue berets for all practical consequences at the moment and there is absolutely no reason why we shouldn't bring to the whole of the United Nations force formally the kind of stability and effect we have been bringing informally since our troops arrived there last week." Soldiers from the 1st Battalion of the Parachute Regiment have been guarding positions around the capital Freetown and Lungi airport, as well as giving military assistance to government troops fighting rebels from the Revolutionary United Front, who are thought to be holding hundreds of UN peacekeepers hostage. Mr Campbell added: "I think the British government should be willing to contribute a force for some considerable time as long as we can do that consistent with our other responsibilities, as long as that force has sufficiently robust rules of engagement and a sufficiently effective mandate from the United Nations..." In his Commons statement, Mr Hoon said Britain had received reports that a number of UN personnel had been released and British officer Major Andrew Harrison was fit and well and under the protection of the Indian Battalion in the east of Sierra Leone. Liberia's president, Charles Taylor, said last night that more than 130 out of 500 UN peacekeepers held captive by Sierra Leone's rebel movement had been released into Liberian custody. Mr Taylor said 15 of the 139 freed captives were flown by a government-chartered helicopter to Liberia's capital, Monrovia, on Sunday evening while the remaining 124 were waiting to be evacuated from the Liberian border town of Foya, some 130 miles to the north.

webTitle: Unionists fail to take a bow

fields.headline: Unionists fail to take a bow
fields.standfirst: The IRA's latest move on guns should boost Trimble and the Unionists, not wrongfoot them, says Observer Northern Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald
fields.trailText: The IRA's latest move on guns should boost Trimble and the Unionists, not wrongfoot them, says Observer Northern Ireland correspondent Henry McDonald.
fields.body:
The arrival of the two international observers tasked with inspecting IRA arms dumps is the culmination of four months of secret talks between republicans and their main international heroes - the African National Congress.

At the end of February the prospects for progress in the peace process looked gloomy. The republican movement was furious that Peter Mandelson suspended the power-sharing executive at the bequest of the Ulster Unionists. As Sinn Fein and the IRA searched for way out of the post-suspension mess, they sought advice from the ANC. For decades the IRA looked upon the South African liberation movement as a template for political success and power. One of those leaders the republican movement talked with after suspension was Mac Maharaj, the former number three in the ANC's military wing who only called off armed attacks on the South African defence forces after the personal intervention of Nelson Mandela.

Maharaj is the model of the new ANC elite: a former Communist militant who is now a banker. Back in February Maharaj met secretly with the IRA leadership in Belfast including fellow Marxist Brian Keenan, the most sceptical member of the Provos' Army Council and a very public opponent of any compromise on decommissioning. Instead of berating the British and the Unionists, Maharaj urged the IRA to "be creative" and seize the iniative to break the decommissioning deadlock. The advice to the IRA was invaluable and helped convince the Army Council to look for a way forward.

The plan - to put their weapons beyond use and to allow outsiders to inspect their sealed arsenals for the first time in Irish history - does two things. Firstly, it allows the IRA to sell a deal to their supporters and volunteers which is not tantamount to surrender. There will be no public hand-over and televised destruction of arms. Republicans like to believe that the IRA is an undefeated army. Not so much the illusion of victory but of stalemate.

Secondly, it may just be enough, despite recent prevarications, for David Trimble to sell to his party, that in effect the IRA's war really is over for good.

Some unionists will portray the IRA offer as another sell-out, that it does not entail the hand-over of illegal guns and explosives. But the deal itself is probably a better means of confirming the end of war than a few rusty World War Two machine guns being cut in half for the benefit of the cameras.

They should listen to the arguments of republican dissidents who see the IRA offer as the beginning of the end of the movement founded in 1969, the Provisional IRA.

Tommy McKearney almost died on hunger strike in 1980. A former IRA prisoner, McKearney describes the latest IRA plan as "decommissioning by other means." In fact he contends the opening up of arsenals for inspection marks a serious break in republican tradition. In the past only IRA volunteers held the keys to the bunkers and the weapons dumps. He points out that tampering with IRA dumps would have resulted in death not very long ago.

The irony is that even though Trimble and the UUP have pushed the IRA into making an historic concession, they are failing to sell it as a major achievement. But if Trimble can gain enough clarification from the two governments and the two international observers, the ANC's Cyril Ramaphosa and the former Finnish President Martti Ahtisaari, then he might still have time to trumpet to his party that their persistence on the decommissioning question has paid off. The unionists have forced the IRA to publicly admit their war is over, yet they don't seem to know it.

fields.headline: Global warming will cost UK 'billions'
fields.trailText: Defences against rising seas caused by global warming could cost £1.2 billion over the next 50 years, the government warned today.
fields.body:
Defences against rising seas caused by global warming could cost £1.2 billion over the next 50 years, the government warned today.

Following the publication of a government commissioned report warning that preventative measures could be far cheaper than the cost of doing nothing, the Environment minister Michael Meacher said the government recognised the importance of global warning.

"What we need to do is sensitise public opinion, business opinion and government opinion to ensure we make the maximum effort in this country to reduce emissions, to minimise the effects and adapt to those that are irreversible," he told a London news conference. "That's the message."

Mr Meacher warned that the cost of climate change would gradually mount and could reach the same budget levels as health or education spending. "We are talking sizeable expenditure in which we have no choice because climate change is happening and we have to defend ourselves."

The minister said work on adapting to climate change was at an early stage throughout the world but the UK was as far ahead as anywhere.

The government has already taken action by requiring water companies to submit 25-year water resource plans that take climate change into account and incorporate estimates of sea level rise into guidance on project appraisal for sea defences.

Other priority areas - building and infrastructure, habitats and species and planning, all most likely to be affected over the next 30-50 years - were identified by the report for the first time.

On water, ways must be found to reduce demand, with more efficient domestic appliances, more meters, recycling and changes in behaviour. To deal with flooding there must be better flood defences and on building and infrastructure, new ways of designing. The electricity supply network should be able to withstand climate changes.

In the regions, the vulnerable areas include the estuaries of the Mersey, Ribble and Arun. The low-lying Gwent levels, Somerset levels, Morecambe Bay, North Kent coastline and the ports of Heysham Harbour and Dover are also vulnerable. Transport links around the Dawlish and West Cumbrian coasts may be affected.

Landscapes and wildlife could change forever in the Hampshire Downs, South Downs, New Forest, Welsh Uplands, the Lake District and Cairn Gorms. Flowers such as the Snowdon lily, and birds such as the dipper and snow bunting and arctic alpine species could disappear.

But some species, including the kingfisher and nightingale and butterflies such as the Adonis blue, speckled wood and comma, could all prosper with the rise in temperatures.

webTitle: Why red is no longer the colour for Ken

fields.headline: Why red is no longer the colour for Ken
fields.standfirst: London's new mayor is no doubt planning his office carefully. But he must avoid cacti or a drinks machine.  Hilary Whitney reports
fields.trailText: London's new mayor is no doubt planning his office carefully. But he must avoid cacti or a drinks machine. Hilary Whitney reports
fields.body:
Like anyone with a new job, Ken Livingstone will be eager to stamp his mark on his office. As London's first elected mayor, this will mean rather more than unpacking a grubby Garfield mug and selecting an amusing screen-saver. As well as finalising who will make up his administration, he needs to work out who will do it, as the office support staff he recruits will have an enormous hidden influence.

Many staff are already in place. The Greater London Assembly liaison team has set up the infrastructure for the mayor's office over the past year, building in flexibility so that the new incumbent is able to make the changes he feels necessary to enable him to work effectively. The current staff is made up of people with a variety of backgrounds, from both the private and public sector, but many are temporary positions and recruitment has only just begun in earnest.

Nevertheless, anyone nursing a burning ambition to become Ken's PA and right-hand person will be disappointed. He has brought his PA with him, which indicates that he appreciates how important it is to have the right person for such a pivotal role. Recruitment for other secretarial posts began in January and is now complete, although GLA's human resources department points out that new organisations are subject to rapid change, especially in the early days, and no one is able to predict what staff might be needed in even the very near future.

The GLA is housed in Romney House, a gloomy 1930s building that has never fulfilled its original purpose as a hotel. But in spring 2002 staff will move to the peculiarly named More London Bridge, adjacent to London Bridge. This largely transparent building will not only give employees a fantastic view, but also allow Londoners to see their elected assembly at work. In keeping with the democratic flavour of the building, there will be a flexible public space known as "London's Living Room" which can be used for exhibitions, and a roof terrace, open to the public, giving an unparalleled view across London.

So what should Livingstone consider when planning his new office? Kenny D'Cruz of the Feng Shui Partnership suggests that he needs to think carefully about the office environment. Red Ken will need to work with politicians of all colours, so he may not wish to choose scarlet for the walls of his office. He should avoid spiky plants or cacti, says D'Cruz, because these generate attacking energy and if they are in his Helpful People corner (the northwest corner of a room) he might find himself, metaphorically at least, being stabbed in the back. Nor should he put anything to do with water, such as a drinks machine or even a seascape, in the southern part of his office. This is his fame and achievement area which is represented by fire and can thus be doused by water. Which wouldn't do at all.

One of the first things the new mayor did in his new office was to hang on the walls a favourite painting of communist Cuba. Should he find himself with a few more blank walls, Andrew Hutchinson from Art for Offices suggests an anomorphic portrait on glass of Tony Blair. An anomorphic image is one that is in focus when viewed from the side but distorted or out of focus when viewed straight on, and thus Ken could enjoy glancing up and seeing the PM in endlessly different ways, depending on which spot his eyes are focused at the time.

Finally, if his PA wants to ensure a harmonious working relationship, she could do worse than buying some peace lilies. According to Kenny D'Cruz, electrical pollution from anything from computers to telephones generates stress and loss of temper, but a nice bunch of peace lilies should keep everything sweet. Flower power may yet become an influential political force once more.

fields.headline: Not up to Calibra
fields.standfirst: Road test:  Vauxhall's latest models - the Astra Coupe and Agila minicar - offer no surprises, says  Simon Hacker
fields.trailText: Road test: Vauxhall's latest models - the Astra Coupe and Agila minicar - offer no surprises, says Simon Hacker
fields.body:
Even minus the PR bumf, most launches offer too much slack and more than enough time to drive. You end up all numb and mesmerised by the soft-eject cupholders; it's not proper work. So it made good sense for Vauxhall to launch two new models at the same time. The Astra Coupe and Agila are, respectively, Luton's effective replacement to the Calibra and an attempt at the minicar market.

First, the Agila. There's something burlesque about this sort of top-heavy car; anyone who invests therein would have to have unshakeable self confidence. For me, the first person to shout "Oy, Noddy!" would have me weeping with shame. Yet if you judge the Agila strictly as what it hopes to be - a jaunty little runabout with lots of room shoehorned into an upright, boxy frame - and it's not bad.

The car is solidly built and has a pleasant, clunky quality. It's only when you test the guff about "large-car specification in a small-car package" that it wobbles. The Mini was genius because it never pretended to be anything more than a humble dashabout; the Agila is yet another "less-is-more" sleight of hand. On the motorway its diminutive frame shrinks and trembles in the wake of surly lorries.

Back in town it regains its composure. Despite the roofline and the lofty seats, the car is surefooted and more inclined to squat on a sharp bend than veer through it. Inside, you'll find plenty of space for four and a fair bit of boot space. Ahead of your toes, you get one of two engine options - a struggling 1.0 and a much perkier 1.2. The latter, when driven hard, is competent, but a strange, gravely drone feeds up from somewhere under the ashtray as the revs get higher. Equipment includes airbag, electric mirrors, radio cassette, power steering and immobiliser. Not bad for the price, kicking off at around £7,000.

The Astra Coupe, despite being billed as a car to take up the Calibra story, is a sore disappointment. If the car is an exercise in preaching to the converted, the Coupe will score a direct hit on the Gareth Cheeseman market. It could have been like the Calibra - a stunning new shape, a bit of road-going, affordable porn. But it looks horribly respectable. It's not a bad drive - sturdy and competent - but for a 2.2 it feels dull. Under a firm foot, it fails to deliver any excitement at any one point in the torque curve; as far as performance goes, I've had better moments in a Fiesta.

Its key crime, however, is styling. The car is a Bertone project and is put together for Vauxhall in the stylist's Turin plant. That alone, if you know your motors, sounds impressive, but the fact only serves to reinforce the degree to which this is a missed opportunity. Where coupe variants of the Peugeot 406 and Renault Megane have struck out to look different, the Astra Coupe explores the fine line between coupe and saloon - and then parks squarely over it.

Add an interior that groans with age-old familiarity and you have a car that slipstreams into the growing coupe field with all the fervour of a lame sheep.

So if you're waiting for our friends in Luton to strike out with a tarmac-trembler you'd best wait until September, which brings the VX220 sports car. Then at least, Vauxhall might surprise us.

webTitle: 'I never intended to go round the world...'

fields.headline: 'I never intended to go round the world...'
fields.standfirst: She popped out to see some friends off at a classic car rally. Next thing she knew, Julie Holdcroft was racing a 90-year-old Rolls-Royce with a man she'd never met before.  Emma Brockes  hears her story
fields.trailText: She popped out to see some friends off at a classic car rally. Next thing she knew, Julie Holdcroft was racing a 90-year-old Rolls-Royce with a man she'd never met before. Emma Brockes hears her story
fields.body:
Have you ever be on a routine journey somewhere and, as you've neared your destination, been seized by the sudden, devastating impulse to disown your life and just keep going? When Julie Holdcroft left her house two weeks ago, she had a definite purpose: to go to London Bridge and see-off friends participating in the Classic Rally Associations round the world rally. It was not an ambitious plan. She had a nine-year-old son, Tyler, at home in Bexhill, and a part time job as a hairdresser. She was not having a nervous breakdown. She was not wanted for murder. She was simply a woman enjoying a day out.

At 10am, she stood on the bridge with 5,000 other spectators, cheering on a fleet of old cars as they prepared to embark on their 80-day odyssey. At the head of the rally stood a seven-and-a-half litre Rolls-Royce, a 1913 Silver Ghost given pole position for being the oldest car in the race. As the crowd clapped and whistled and the engines roared, it became apparent that something was wrong. The Rolls wouldn't budge; the cars behind it couldn't pass. As the air cooked with petrol fumes, a feeling of panic entered the atmosphere. In agitation, the car's driver appealed to the crowd for help. He was a crew member down and couldn't set off unless he replaced him. Julie Holdcroft, 40 years old, felt the irresistible tug of destiny. "You have to do it, you have to grab it," she thought, and sailed out of the crowd towards the vehicle. Ten hours later, she was in France.

Since returning from her adventure, Holdcroft has been compared to Shirley Valentine, the middle aged heroine of Willy Russell's film about a woman who goes on holiday and never returns. Holdcroft rejects the image. "Somebody said, you're like Shirley Valentine and I thought, oh crumbs, I'm not trying to escape a boring life, I love my life!" Her flight was a realisation of a common fantasy of taking a break from ourselves by doing something weird and irrational. "I didn't surprise myself," says Holdcroft. "I thought, if you're not hurting anyone, why not?"

Besides, when she jumped into the driver's seat, she only intended to go as far as Dover. She had no passport, no jacket, no provisions. It was a Monday morning and she had a week of perms and tints in front of her. In three weeks she would sit her final exams in art and design at college in Hastings. This was no time for taking off round the world with a man she had never met before. But the momentum of the adventure got into her bloodstream and she couldn't let it go. When she and her driver Terry Maxon, an American in his 60s, reached Dover, they sailed through passport control without a worry and it seemed to Julie Holdcroft that the only proper thing was to go on.

Holdcroft is not by nature a cautious woman. She and her son live in a cottage two miles from the East Sussex coast. She has artistic flair, she says, and arty people are known for their impulsiveness. The day she left England, her son was staying with her ex-husband and one phone call ensured that he would be well looked after. She judged that the revision could wait, the dog could be fed by neighbours and all that stood in her way was the hairdressing. She was resolved not to sacrifice the dream for the sake of a few highlights.

It was dark when she and Maxon arrived in Calais. The car was so noisy they had to yell at one another, and by Dover she hadn't made out Maxon's character. To Holdcroft's relief, it emerged in the quiet of the ferry that Maxon was as laid back as she was. "I would have turned back if he'd been the sort of man to get uptight when we broke down," she says. "And we did break down an awful lot." By the time they reached France, word had also gone round that a woman had joined the rally on impulse and Holdcroft was flooded with offers of clean knickers and woolly jumpers. News had even reached California, where friends had rung up Maxon's wife and demanded to know if she was aware that her husband was cavorting around Europe with a mystery blonde. "She was amused rather than alarmed," says Holdcroft.

Early on Tuesday morning, the car set off in the direction of the Alps. Outside Dijon, it started to slip behind the rest of the rally. Maxon and Holdcroft, caught up in the excitement of their own story, determined to catch up. I had never tried to bribe anyone before, and when I did, they were deeply offended. It was a disaster. 'This is a very good man,' they kept saying, 'He cannot do it because he cannot do it. On the third day, Maxon and Holdcroft faced a new danger: hairpin bends. The wheels on the Rolls Royce are made of wood, with narrow tyres. With the lights on, the car wouldn't run. As they struggled along, modern cars started escorting them, lights flashing, before and aft, waving and cheering them on from stage to stage. "People were so kind and lovely. That was the best thing about it."

They were heady with fatigue and excitement. At one stage, says Holdcroft, they drove past a gathering of "tiny, toothless Italian women" dressed in black at the roadside. "Do you know who this is?" Maxon yelled at them as they passed. "This is the inspiration to all womankind!"

Somewhere in the middle of Greece, her phone rang. "It was one of my customers, demanding to know why I wasn't at her house, doing her blow-dry."

Hairdressing seems -" she pauses, "oh, maybe I shouldn't say, but it seems somehow small by comparison."

Her reception in Bexhill has been loud and enthusiastic, except for a curt note from tutors reminding her that, when she has finished capering about the world, she has exams to concentrate on. Friends, meanwhile, have urged her to return to the rally if she wants to. But she doesn't. She has had her moment.
fields.bodyText: Have you ever be on a routine journey somewhere and, as you've neared your destination, been seized by the sudden, devastating impulse to disown your life and just keep going? webTitle: Me and my motor: Gloria Gaynor

fields.headline: Me and my motor: Gloria Gaynor
fields.trailText: What are you driving?
fields.body:
What are you driving?

Jaguar, Vanden Plas, 2000 in cream.

What does that say about you?

I know how to spend hard earned money wisely.

What do you like about it?

It's comfortable and has lots of space in the rear for my passengers.

What kind of driver are you?

Careful and considerate.

Any bad habits?

I become heavy footed on the accelerator when there's no traffic.

What was your first car?

A 1978 Monza.

Have you ever crashed/got a speeding ticket/got any points?

I've been rear-ended twice, resulting in serious physical injury. I've never had a ticket or any points.

Have you experienced roadrage?

I once looked in my rear view mirror and saw an angry lorry driver approaching me with a large wrench in his hand. He had been honking at me while I waited for on-coming traffic so that I could make a left turn into my driveway. He was angry because he couldn't pass me. I was able to move just in time.

What sort of state is your car in?

Showroom condition inside and out.

What's in the boot/glove compartment?

Glove compartment: lotion, deodorant, cleaning tickets, photo development claim checks. Boot: umbrella, cloth cleaner to wipe dirty hand prints or spills from the leather interior.

Have you ever had sex in a car?

No - but several midnight picnics with my husband at the beach.

What do you listen to on the road?

Gospel, Whitney Houston, prospective recordings for myself, George Gershwin.

What would be your dream car?

I have it - it's the best.

Who would be your dream passenger?

Nat King Cole. He could sing to me and make me enjoy tailbacks.

webTitle: Paddington survivor calls for rail boycott

fields.headline: Paddington survivor calls for rail boycott
fields.trailText: A survivor of the Paddington train crash today called for a national passenger boycott on June 6 to protest against the state of Britain's rail network, as an inquiry began hearing a second week of testimony into the incident that killed 31 people.
fields.body:
A survivor of the Paddington train crash today called for a national passenger boycott on June 6 to protest against the state of Britain's rail network, as an inquiry began hearing a second week of testimony into the incident that killed 31 people.

"The purpose of this boycott is to raise awareness of rail safety and make sure everyone knows, including the rail industry, how shoddy the rail system is," Claire Jones said. "Since the crash eight months ago I have become quite angry at the way in which it has taken such a long time to make a stand and for things to happen."

Her statement reflected the anger among many survivors and relatives of the victims. The inquiry is due to end later this year, but already the survivors and families of the dead are furious that no one is likely to face legal action.

Before the inquiry started, the crown prosecution service said there was not enough evidence to secure the conviction of any individual or company over the head-on collision between a Thames Trains commuter service and a Great Western express on October 6.

The rail infrastructure provider Railtrack said last month the number of trains going through red signals had risen in March for the first time since the Paddington crash. Railtrack said 52 trains passed danger signals in March - four times more than in the same period of 1999.

Last week, the Cullen inquiry heard the Paddington disaster happened when the Thames train passed a red signal, moments before ploughing into the Great Western carriages, sparking an intense fire.

The inquiry today heard more vivid testimony from survivors of Britain's worst train crash in a decade. Philip Scotcher, 24, told of how he saved a badly burned and horrifically injured fellow traveller. Mr Scotcher had escaped from coach B in the wrecked Great Western train when he came across Michael Adams "sitting right in the middle of a pool of fire".

Mr Scotcher said he helped drag Mr Adams to safety and then stayed with him, comforting him until medical experts arrived. Mr Scotcher, from Tetbury in Gloucestershire, said Mr Adams was so badly burned he could not tell the colour of his skin. In trying to drag him to his feet, Mr Scotcher had put his hand on an "horrific" back injury of Mr Adams.

A letter written by Paul Lukins to the Great Western company the day after the accident was read to the inquiry. Mr Lukins had been travelling in coach C on the Great Western train and suffered whiplash injuries and a bruised bottom when he fell on the track after escaping from the train.

In his letter, he said that doors were locked and it was not immediately clear how to open them. Passengers also faced a steep and difficult drop from the train to the ground below. Mr Lukins suggested that train companies supply emergency ramps such as airlines do and also provide easily accessible tools to use in the case of an emergency.

In another testimony, a train manager who helped passengers after the crash told the public inquiry that he received more emergency training under British Rail than under privatisation. Mike Thomas, who works for Virgin Trains and was on the Great Western train in the crash, said: "I had much more frequent training under British Rail than I have had since privatisation."

Mr Thomas added: "It doesn't matter so much to me because I have had a lot of experience to build on. But new people coming into the industry - I am not sure they have the training they need."

He went on: "I am not sure I would have been so competent and confident (at Paddington) if I had recently joined the railway. You could never create a situation in training such as we encountered at Paddington, but training is better than no training. If staff get minimal training, they have not the confidence. They are running around like headless chickens."

Mr Thomas said that in the old BR days staff "were often taken away on courses, spending days in a hotel doing exercises."

fields.headline: Duwayne Brooks
fields.standfirst: Duwayne Brooks was live online on Monday April 3 to answer questions on the murder of his best friend, the black teenager, Stephen Lawrence. Duwayne gave his views on the Macpherson report, and discussed his personal encounters with the police expectations for the future. This is an edited transcript of the discussion; click here to read the full debate and have your say.
fields.body:
afouche: Have you found that your memories of that night affect your day to day life?

Duwayne Brooks: Dear afouche, the incident on April 22 has now passed me, but I've not forgotten. This is what inspires me to continue to be firm when everybody is out to get me.


afouche: Have you developed a prejudice as a result towards white people?

DB: As regards to prejudice against white people I have respect for everybody regardless of colour, creed or religion. We are all of one blood, no matter what anyone wants to say. A lot of people have suggested that I may have a thing against white people. May I just say now to get the record straight my solicitor is white, many important friends are white, and if I never trusted white people these people would not be in my life.


jonifame: I was shocked and angered by the story of how the police are treating you. If stop and search and police harassment are normal for young black men in London, and you say things aren't getting better through the government, do you think there could end up being riots etc again?

DB: Hello Jonifame. If the government allows the police to continue on this downward trend, breaking all ties with ethnic minorities, the only result will be to alienate themselves and create total anarchy.


Gwladys28: Have you faced any kind of police harassment since the collapse of the case last week?

DB: Dear Gwladys28, how d'you pronounce your name? Well, in the last two weeks, I've been stopped once outside the premises I was staying at while I was on bail. Since the case was thrown out of court, there has been a major incident outside my bail address. The police instigated hourly patrols for our protection. Ironically, Duwayne Brooks, who the police were supposed to be protecting, was the first person to be stopped and questioned. Is this harassment or just the police doing their job? What d'you think?


Morcheeba: What did you think of the Macpherson report? Do you think there is any real will on the part of the government to shake up the police and justice system, or is it all going to get forgotten?

DB: Hello Morcheeba. I think the Macpherson report was a good thing at the beginning. Since then I've had grave reservations on what its real purpose is. Is it really a watershed for race relations or does it just give the police reason to blame more black people for the increase in street crime? Or to stop us when we are going about our daily business? If change was really supposed to happen why have no officers been disciplined, and why have there not been any changes in the way police deal with ethnic minorities during their everyday duties. The inquiry only touched on the surface of how deeply, institutionally racist public bodies like the police are.


whit73: In your opinion, how do you feel the British police can ever genuinely reform itself to become less institutionally racist?

DB: Hello, Whit73. While police investigate police there is no hope for the police to change. We as taxpayers pay their wages so we should be entitled to discipline and regulate them when they step out of line. Until this happens, we will be stopped and searched unnecessarily, maliciously prosecuted and, worst of all, there will still be unaccountable deaths in police custody.


bat0181: What do you think of John Grieve, head of the Met's new race crimes unit?

DB: Hello, Bat. I think John Grieve is the best talker in the Met, and that's why he is where he is. I have met Mr Grieve on a number of occasions and all he does is talk, talk, talk. I have yet to see any action on anything he has said to me over the past 12 months. I appreciate his work on the Menson case, but why has there been no investigation into the failure of the police to treat this as a serious murder case?


H Mayor: Have you experienced first hand the kind of intimidating prejudice which was demonstrated by the hidden cameras in the homes of those implicated in this crime?

DB: In my everyday life as a service engineer, spending 95% of my time in offices owned by white people I never get that sort of direct abusive racism. What you do get is a form of indirect racism which could be down to the background of the person or just pure ignorance.


JSwan: How do you think we can promote greater racial tolerance and understanding?

DB: Hello JSwan. First of all, better education during our teenage years. I remember when I was in primary school I didn't know anything about racism. We were all friends in our class, black, white and Chinese. I first experienced racism in secondary school. This is where the education needs to start, when we are at an age to understand other people's cultures, needs and religions. When we can understand fully all these things, then and only then will we be able to live together in unity.


Meatloaf: Duwayne, what are your impressions of the coverage Stephen's case received in the media, particularly post-Macpherson? After the accusations of institutional racism, the papers launched a defence of the police - which happened to coincide with lots of talk of Yardies - some of the most racist stuff there has been in the media for some time.

DB: Hello, Meatloaf. Well we know the police have friends in high editorial places. For instance, when I was arrested and charged with attempted rape it appeared in the Sun newspaper the next day, despite the fact that I wasn't charged till after midnight. Then when they dropped the attempted rape charge, who bothered to report that? Regardless of whether the people are black or white, whenever the police are on the backfoot they always produce stories in the press to justify their actions, or to draw attention away from bad news. I thought it was strange that the same day my case was dropped the police announced new arrests in the Lawrence case.


Bat0181: Duwayne, you've recently decided to tell the public your side of the story via the media (eg the Guardian interview, this online chat thing). I was wondering what prompted this decision on your part - how did you weigh up the risks of further hassle against the benefits of setting the record straight?

DB: Dear Bat0181, I had hoped other people in higher positions than me would have foresaken political careers and financial gain and highlighted the problems that young black men have.


DB: Thank you everyone for posting your messages. Let's hope the Guardian ain't using us just to boost newspaper sales. I hope to be back here soon. If you want to email me send messages on to simon.hattenstone@theguardian.com and he will pass them on. (I hope)

I was wondering what prompted this decision on your part - how did you weigh up the risks of further hassle against the benefits of setting the record straight? DB: Thank you everyone for posting your messages. Let's hope the Guardian ain't using us just to boost newspaper sales. I hope to be back here soon. If you want to email me send messages on to simon.hattenstone@theguardian.com and he will pass them on. (I hope)
