fields.headline: 'It's been a terrible week for newspapers'
fields.standfirst: Two adverse judgments in a row for Piers Morgan from the press complaints commission, yet still he clings to the editor's chair at the Mirror. Is newspaper self-regulation really working?  Matt Wells  reports
fields.trailText: Two adverse judgments in a row for Piers Morgan from the press complaints commission, yet still he clings to the editor's chair at the Mirror. Is newspaper self-regulation really working? Matt Wells reports
fields.body:
"You lot may just as well be on a different planet," said a senior television executive to a newspaper journalist the day after Piers Morgan was censured by the press complaints commission. "Press self-regulation is just a joke."

It's not difficult to appreciate his point. When Carlton television was found guilty of faking a documentary on the drugs trade, the company was fined £2m by the independent television commission. When the press complaints commission (PCC) decided that the Mirror was guilty of a serious breach of its code of conduct, and Morgan as editor was personally responsible, all it could do was state plaintively: "In view of the unsatisfactory state of affairs revealed by this episode, the commission decided formally to register its concern about the general application of the code in this area with the management of Trinity Mirror." Different planets indeed.

Nevertheless, Thursday's judgment against Morgan was a defining moment in the recent history of newspaper regulation. It was only the second time that the PCC had found against the editor of a national newspaper (Morgan being the subject of the first censure as well), and the language used was clear and direct: "The editor's conduct in this case... had fallen short of the high professional standards demanded by the code." Lord Wakeham, the chairman of the PCC, declared there had been a "climate of slack, it was all gay abandon". And Morgan himself is understood to have felt particularly chastised - splashing the entire PCC judgment across two pages of his own newspaper took self-flagellation to a new extreme.

So why is it, then, that there is a gnawing feeling of dissatisfaction, a feeling that somehow what the PCC said was not quite strong enough, that Morgan has got away with a slap on the wrist, that there is something unsatisfactory about the whole business of self-regulation?

Back to our television executive. He just can not get his head round the fact that the editor of the second biggest-selling national daily paper could get away with profiting from shares in companies whose stock market value was directly influenced by what his columnists wrote - and not only that, he still survives a stinging criticism from the organisation that regulates his industry. This particular executive, a BBC man, pointed to the piles of ring-binder files labelled "producer guidelines" which govern what he can and can not get away with. They are an imposing sight - especially when you consider that you can fit the PCC code on the back of a large envelope.

So why should readers, government and the industry itself be satisfied by what we have got? Roger Alton, the editor of the Observer, says that the PCC is far from a toothless tiger. Its rulings are feared by editors and journalists alike, and every effort is made to comply with the (albeit brief) code. "To underestimate what journalists and editors feel about what the PCC says is a great mistake. I get a lot of stuff from the PCC, investigating complaints, after almost all of which we are exonerated. But we spend a lot of time working on each one, speaking to the journalists, writing letters, compiling documents. We don't want to lose a PCC adjudication. It is a very important thing."

David Yelland, the editor of the Sun, and Morgan's main rival, agrees that an adverse PCC judgment is an editor's nightmare. "If you are on the end of one, it is a painful experience. I was very uncomfortable when Lord Wakeham was on the steps reading the Sophie [Rhys Jones] ruling. I can't imagine what Piers must be feeling."

Alton believes that the PCC decision is a sobering moment for the newspaper industry as a whole: "The nature of this ruling is astounding. It will make newspaper editors redouble their efforts not to cross the PCC." Clearly, the board of Trinity Mirror feels the same way. The statement issued after Thursday's ruling was measured and contrite, expressing "regret" that Morgan had breached the code.

Yelland makes a clear distinction between the conduct of Morgan and the implications of the PCC ruling. The actions of Morgan were unforgivable, and he is lucky to have survived, he says. "It has been a terrible week for newspapers. We have all been harmed by this, because the public doesn't necessarily realise that this was only going on among a small group of people at the Mirror. We have all made mistakes - I made mistakes over the Sophie pictures which didn't help the business - but this is far more serious."

And while newspapers themselves have suffered, the affair has been a disaster for the Mirror, he says. "It has been a bloody awful week for the Mirror. They can never question fat cats again. They are so weakened, and I think they didn't realise how serious a situation they got themselves into until the PCC published its judgment on Thursday."

If the Mirror handled the situation badly, the PCC under Lord Wakeham once again rode to the rescue of self-regulation. Since the former Thatcher confidant took over at the commission in 1995, replacing Lord McGregor of Durris, he has transformed the organisation into a highly sophisticated political animal. He has said the things that politicians and the public want to hear, when they want to hear it. His pronouncements over coverage of the young members of the royal family struck a chord, and his ruling against Yelland on the publication of topless pictures of Sophie Rhys Jones were also in tune with the public mood.

Yelland says: "The job that Lord Wakeham and director Guy Black have done at the PCC is one of the greatest achievements of the last few years. Their most important achievement has been to create a level playing field." So when paparazzi photos of Prince William snogging a young beauty land on the picture desk, tabloid editors can turn them down safe in the knowledge that rivals will do the same. "The commercial pressure has been lifted," Yelland says.

Alton says that the PCC has to work, because the alternative - a legal framework imposing tough privacy laws - would place damaging restrictions on a press that already has to battle against a panoply of restrictive legislation. "There was clearly a problem. They were using Mirror readers to ramp up the share price, and that was wrong. But I do think we should defend the PCC. The alternatives are just too horrible to contemplate."

So why are newspapers so determined to be seen to take the PCC seriously? For a start, says Peter Cole, former editor of the Sunday Correspondent and now professor of journalism at the University of Central Lancashire in Preston, they are all signed up to it. They can hardly break away when it doesn't suit them. "There is to a certain extent a sort of tacit conspiracy between the editors and the PCC. The PCC knows it is only there because things had come to such a pass before. The creation of the PCC was a strategic avoidance by the newspaper industry of privacy legislation at the point it came into being. It is in the interests of both parties to be seen to be taking it seriously.

"The PCC has always been seen to be the lesser of two evils. Some editors firmly believe in it, but there are others - and they probably tend to be at the tabloid end of the market - who support it through gritted teeth. The price of that is that if it is the editor who is the subject of a judgment, he or she has to go along with it." Cole agrees with Yelland's analysis of the present chairman's tenure. "Lord Wakeham has a strong sense of political sophistication. His political antennae are as sharp as they were when he served Thatcher."

That, of course, is all very well, says our television executive. But Morgan has still got his job, despite having clocked up two PCC judgments against him. The received wisdom is that Morgan is a strong editor who has turned an ailing newspaper into a proper tabloid again, with a fiery mix of showbiz nonsense and hard news. "I think he is a fantastic editor, tremendous. I think he has done a wonderful job," says Alton. Cole agrees: "If a proprietor had wanted to fire him, this PCC ruling would have been manna from heaven."

But Peter Oborne, the Express commentator, who is close to the Trinity Mirror chairman Victor Blank, says it is inconceivable that Morgan should remain as editor, after he "tolerated and even fostered a culture of greed and corruption". No matter that Morgan is good at his job, he says. By not sacking Morgan, Blank - a man of honour in his other business dealings - has applied "one set of standards for his own business and another for the great newspaper group he has the honour to chair", he wrote on Friday. The survival of Morgan has weakened that great group. "And he has perpetuated the shameful notion that there is one set of standards for newspapers and newspaper journalists, and another for everybody else."

In a strong pay-off, he concluded: "Damn you, Victor Blank. By failing to sack Morgan you have brought disgrace on a great and honourable calling."

The words will have thundered around Canary Wharf. They are a telling indictment, from an analyst who has no particular axe to grind, of the conduct of Trinity Mirror. Add to that the growing unease about Blank's handling of the situation among the City pundits of the financial pages, and Morgan's situation suddenly looks far shakier. "Blank will go before Piers will go," says Yelland, "because he is an honourable man. When people like Peter Oborne and the Telegraph financial page commentators are starting to criticise Mirror Group's reputation, I can't tell you how bad that is."

Press excesses: a decade of last chances

1989: Calcutt inquiry set up by Thatcher government after such tabloid outrages as the Sun's blaming of Liverpool fans for Hillsborough. Home Office minister David Mellor says the press is "drinking in the Last Chance Saloon".

1990: Calcutt recommendations fall short of expected statutory regulation and/or privacy law. Backs replacement of Press Council by press complaints commission (PCC) as the "last chance" for self-regulation, with tribunal headed by judge to take over if system breaks down. Also proposes introduction of new criminal offences of physical intrusion, but government decides not to implement.

1991: PCC starts work with Lord McGregor as chair. Commission mixes tabloid and broadsheet editors ("The pops all regard us as middle-class wankers," says Telegraph editor Max Hastings. "We sit there thinking, 'What are we doing with all these animals?'"). In first year it upholds complaints against News of the World from Clare Short and against People over nude photo of Princess Eugenie. Praises press for cleaning up its act, and threat of statutory regulation recedes.

1992: General election passes without tabloid misconduct. But fallout from Andrew Morton's Diana biography revives hand-wringing over privacy, with McGregor, unaware that Diana was involved in book and that Palace gave misleading briefings, attacking "odious" royal stories for "dabbling their fingers in the stuff of other people's souls". Press back in Last Chance Saloon as - 10 days before the People discloses his affair with Antonia de Sancha - Mellor recalls Calcutt to review self-regulation.

1993: Calcutt II criticises PCC and backs statutory tribunal and code of practice, and new tort of infringement of privacy. Government warns PCC to get its act together, or regulation will be imposed. PCC tightens code. Transcript of Camillagate tape and Diana gym photos cause controversy, with Mirror Group briefly quitting PCC over rap for latter.

1994: Government white paper on privacy law expected but postponed. PCC censures photos of Edward kissing Sophie, clears Sun day Times of entrapment in cash-for-questions row. Lord Wakeham chosen as McGregor's replacement.

1995: Watered-down white paper rejects statutory regulation, proposes tighter code, and says no consensus for civil privacy law. News of the World's Piers Morgan spanked over report on Earl Spencer's wife. Wakeham warns press not to harass Prince William.

1996: Wakeham agrees that "toothless watchdog" now has teeth. Rules on public interest defence of intrusion tightened. Tabloids caned for anti-German headlines during Euro 96. Gerald Kaufman calls Wakeham "a eunuch trying to do the best in the circumstances".

1997: Death of Diana causes outcry over paparazzi. Editors agree to tighten privacy code, some vow to ban paparazzi photos. Government plans to incorporate European convention on human rights into UK law; Wakeham condemns as erosion of freedom of press.

1998: Debate continues over prospect of "back-door privacy law" via judges using Lord Irvine's Human Rights Bill. Stories involving private lives of Robin Cook, Nick Brown, Peter Mandelson and Jack Straw's son prove embarrassing in this context.

1999: Blairs protest successfully over story about daughter's school and photo of son. PCC raps Sun over the topless Sophie photo, and criticises News of the World "conviction bonus" to Gary Glitter trial witness.

2000: Piers Morgan receives another PCC six-of-the-best over Mirror's City Slickers column and share dealings.

fields.headline: Sour sources
fields.standfirst: Refusing to disclose informants is an honourable custom, but not when journalists use it as ploy to print mischief.Roy Greenslade on the stitching-up of Alastair Campbell
fields.trailText: When the Mirror and the Daily Express both ran editorials advising their readers to vote Tory in the London mayoral election, many commentators were surprised. Why should these avid supporters of Tony Blair's New Labour switch allegiance to the old enemy at the same time?
fields.body:
When the Mirror and the Daily Express both ran editorials advising their readers to vote Tory in the London mayoral election, many commentators were surprised. Why should these avid supporters of Tony Blair's New Labour switch allegiance to the old enemy at the same time?

It could have been a coincidence, of course. After all, the papers published quite separate reasons for their decisions to abandon the Labour candidate, Frank Dobson. But politicians and journalists dislike coincidences. They much prefer conspiracy theories. So the tongues started wagging and some of Westminster's finest came up with the answer. It must be the result of spinning. Tony Blair's own team had urged the two papers to back Tory candidate Steve Norris rather than Dobson. Why? Because they believed Norris might just conceivably be capable of beating their bete noire, Ken Livingstone.

Who was responsible? Logic suggested it must be none other than the man routinely referred to as the arch-spinner, Alastair Campbell, the prime minister's press secretary. From that speculative - and, as it transpired, totally false - hunch, the story just grew and grew, especially in the fevered minds of two Sunday Telegraph journalists, political editor Joe Murphy and his deputy, David Cracknell.

They discovered that a meeting had taken place at Downing Street the day before the Mirror and Express leaders appeared, which was attended by Campbell and Blair's political strategist, Philip Gould. The reporters picked up hints that there had been a discussion about private polling data which evidently showed Livingstone might be more vulnerable than other surveys had shown. They also obtained quotes from those most talkative, and reliable, of people known as "anonymous sources" in both Livingstone's and Dobson's camps. The jigsaw of their theory was fitting together nicely .

Campbell and Gould had betrayed their candidate, and their party, in order to stop Livingstone. They had their story and it duly appeared, taking up a full page in the first edition of last weekend's Sunday Telegraph. Purporting to tell "the inside story", the main headline read: "The day Labour backed Norris" and a secondary line asked rhetorically: "Was there a desperate Downing Street plot to stop Livingstone at any cost?"

It was laced with the kind of innuendo that placed Campbell and Gould at the heart of the conspiracy. Yet neither man was called before publication for their views on the story. The first Campbell heard about it was in a phone call at a north London party at 9pm on Saturday. After reading a faxed copy of the article, he immediately called the Sunday Telegraph and spoke to news editor Chris Boffey to make a vehement protest.

It was, he said, completely untrue and quite obviously libellous. He hadn't had to go very far for legal advice. His beloved football team, Burnley, had won promotion and the barrister brother of his partner, Fiona Millar, was celebrating winning his silk. The place was also full of lawyers.

Boffey, who has known Campbell for years, moved swiftly. With editor Dominic Lawson away, and acting editor Matthew d'Ancona having left for the evening, he rewrote passages in the article to take account of Campbell's complaint. But the story was so flawed, starting from a false premise and built up with a series of inaccuracies, that the remedial action wasn't enough to assuage Campbell's and Gould's understandable anger.

They knew that the story had been presented in a plausible fashion, with all sorts of details and quotes, so that most readers would have thought it true. It was written in such a way that it had the ring of veracity and was hedged by a get-out clause: "It is impossible to prove that No 10 brought any influence to bear on the two newspapers." These weasel words did nothing to mitigate the damage. So Campbell and Gould demanded an apology, which appeared in yesterday's Sunday Telegraph. The paper will pay a sum of money to charity.

It accepted that the article was "without foundation" and regretted that Campbell and Gould were not given an opportunity to respond to the allegations before publication. Boffey told me: "We admit we made a mistake. We rectified it as soon as we possibly could, probably within 15 minutes of Mr Campbell's call."

But my understanding is that, initially, Murphy stood by his story, claiming that his report was true. Reporters are always defensive when they make mistakes, and Murphy is generally regarded as having a good track record, but his refusal to back down shows how difficult it is for people to persuade even rational journalists to apologise.

It is known that Boffey and Lawson are very upset at what happened. One of their senior executives said: "They can't believe it happened. It's been a shock to their system. What should have been a subtle piece about the circumstances behind Livingstone's election turned into something completely different."

Indeed, the Sunday Telegraph's relationship with Downing Street has been quite warm in the past three years, much warmer than that of most other Sunday titles. It is known that Campbell and the rest of his press team have grown used to issuing a string of denials every Saturday night because of false stories in Sunday papers. A couple of weeks ago, of the first seven stories on a Sky TV news bulletin, five were effectively denials of articles running on the front pages of Sunday papers. Campbell has evidently grown so frustrated by such stories that he often lets them pass without comment. But he could see that the implications of the Sunday Telegraph story were so serious he had to take action.

It is only the second time he has demanded an apology. The other occasion was when the Daily Mail suggested his father had died when Campbell was a child. In fact, his father is still alive.

Campbell is not the only Blair aide who suffered at the hands of last weekend's papers. Jonathan Powell, Blair's chief of staff, was also accused of spin-doctoring. He has demanded an apology from the Mail on Sunday following an article by Julia Langdon in which she accused him of briefing against Dobson and Mo Mowlam.

According to the piece, he has been, "fingered as the man who poisons the well". But there appeared to be scant evidence for the allegation. No specific instances were detailed to support the assertion. It is known - naturally enough, by journalists - that the famously discreet Powell doesn't talk to journalists. So which reporters on which papers did Powell brief? The Mail on Sunday offered no clues.

Once again, we are confronted by the problem of writers being able to point to anonymous sources which, by tradition, they do not need to identify. That honourable custom is demeaned when it is used as a cover for politicians - not to mention partisan journalists - making mischief.

From that speculative - and, as it transpired, totally false - hunch, the story just grew and grew, especially in the fevered minds of two Sunday Telegraph journalists, political editor Joe Murphy and his deputy, David Cracknell. They discovered that a meeting had taken place at Downing Street the day before the Mirror and Express leaders appeared, which was attended by Campbell and Blair's political strategist, Philip Gould. The reporters picked up hints that there had been a discussion about private polling data which evidently showed Livingstone might be more vulnerable than other surveys had shown. They also obtained quotes from those most talkative, and reliable, of people known as "anonymous sources" in both Livingstone's and Dobson's camps. The jigsaw of their theory was fitting together nicely . Campbell and Gould had betrayed their candidate, and their party, in order to stop Livingstone. They had their story and it duly appeared, taking up a full page in the first edition of last weekend's Sunday Telegraph. Purporting to tell "the inside story", the main headline read: "The day Labour backed Norris" and a secondary line asked rhetorically: "Was there a desperate Downing Street plot to stop Livingstone at any cost?" It was laced with the kind of innuendo that placed Campbell and Gould at the heart of the conspiracy. Yet neither man was called before publication for their views on the story. The first Campbell heard about it was in a phone call at a north London party at 9pm on Saturday. After reading a faxed copy of the article, he immediately called the Sunday Telegraph and spoke to news editor Chris Boffey to make a vehement protest. It was, he said, completely untrue and quite obviously libellous. He hadn't had to go very far for legal advice. His beloved football team, Burnley, had won promotion and the barrister brother of his partner, Fiona Millar, was celebrating winning his silk. The place was also full of lawyers. Boffey, who has known Campbell for years, moved swiftly. With editor Dominic Lawson away, and acting editor Matthew d'Ancona having left for the evening, he rewrote passages in the article to take account of Campbell's complaint. But the story was so flawed, starting from a false premise and built up with a series of inaccuracies, that the remedial action wasn't enough to assuage Campbell's and Gould's understandable anger. They knew that the story had been presented in a plausible fashion, with all sorts of details and quotes, so that most readers would have thought it true. It was written in such a way that it had the ring of veracity and was hedged by a get-out clause: "It is impossible to prove that No 10 brought any influence to bear on the two newspapers." These weasel words did nothing to mitigate the damage. So Campbell and Gould demanded an apology, which appeared in yesterday's Sunday Telegraph. The paper will pay a sum of money to charity. It accepted that the article was "without foundation" and regretted that Campbell and Gould were not given an opportunity to respond to the allegations before publication. Boffey told me: "We admit we made a mistake. We rectified it as soon as we possibly could, probably within 15 minutes of Mr Campbell's call." But my understanding is that, initially, Murphy stood by his story, claiming that his report was true. Reporters are always defensive when they make mistakes, and Murphy is generally regarded as having a good track record, but his refusal to back down shows how difficult it is for people to persuade even rational journalists to apologise. It is known that Boffey and Lawson are very upset at what happened. One of their senior executives said: "They can't believe it happened. It's been a shock to their system. What should have been a subtle piece about the circumstances behind Livingstone's election turned into something completely different." Indeed, the Sunday Telegraph's relationship with Downing Street has been quite warm in the past three years, much warmer than that of most other Sunday titles. It is known that Campbell and the rest of his press team have grown used to issuing a string of denials every Saturday night because of false stories in Sunday papers. A couple of weeks ago, of the first seven stories on a Sky TV news bulletin, five were effectively denials of articles running on the front pages of Sunday papers. Campbell has evidently grown so frustrated by such stories that he often lets them pass without comment. But he could see that the implications of the Sunday Telegraph story were so serious he had to take action. It is only the second time he has demanded an apology. The other occasion was when the Daily Mail suggested his father had died when Campbell was a child. In fact, his father is still alive. Campbell is not the only Blair aide who suffered at the hands of last weekend's papers. Jonathan Powell, Blair's chief of staff, was also accused of spin-doctoring. He has demanded an apology from the Mail on Sunday following an article by Julia Langdon in which she accused him of briefing against Dobson and Mo Mowlam. According to the piece, he has been, "fingered as the man who poisons the well". But there appeared to be scant evidence for the allegation. No specific instances were detailed to support the assertion. It is known - naturally enough, by journalists - that the famously discreet Powell doesn't talk to journalists. So which reporters on which papers did Powell brief? The Mail on Sunday offered no clues. Once again, we are confronted by the problem of writers being able to point to anonymous sources which, by tradition, they do not need to identify. That honourable custom is demeaned when it is used as a cover for politicians - not to mention partisan journalists - making mischief.

fields.headline: Untold stories
fields.standfirst: Real news is being ignored in the US, where the media's aim is to entertain. One organisation wants to change all that.
fields.trailText: Real news is being ignored in the US, where the media's aim is to entertain. One organisation wants to change all that.
fields.body:
The awards are for outstanding, original, investigative reporting, but they are the prizes that no journalist really wants to win. They are the Project Censored annual awards for the best stories that never made the impact they deserved, and this year they are seen, in particular, as a warning sign of the effects of the increase in global, multi-media ownership.

Started 25 years ago and based in the sociology department at California State Polytechnic University in Pomona, Project Censored scans specialist journals, alternative weeklies, fringe publications, political magazines and the trade and medical press for stories that its team feels should have have received an airing in the mainstream press.

The first of the criteria for entry is that the story contains "information that the general US population has a right and need to know, but to which it has had limited access". The team, consisting of academics, media commentators and students, scans several thousand stories and produces a shortlist of around 200 which are then submitted to a judging panel.

The panel of around 20 judges this year included historian Howard Zinn, author Richard Barnet, journalist and author Susan Faludi and professors of journalism or communications from US universities. They chose the "top 25 censored stories" which are published this month in book format. Although the stories are not censored in the usual sense, the theme of the awards is that ignoring such stories amounts to a form of self-censorship by the major media outlets.

This year's collection contains a wide spread of stories, from an attack on the American Cancer Society in the International Journal of Health Services, to an article from Mother Jones magazine on the "unstable personnel" controlling US nuclear weapons; from the San Francisco Bay Guardian's report on the treatment of juvenile offenders to the Turkish government's destruction of Kurdish villages with US weapons, published in the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists. Five of the top 25 stories concern the US's role in Kosovo and elsewhere in the Balkans last year.

"It used to be just a list," says project co-ordinator Tricia Boreta of the awards. It has gradually expanded and the publication of the winners is now incorporated in a 350-page review of American journalism and watched with interest by those in the media. "The stories [that win] have become much more international in breadth."

Peter Phillips, the current director of the project, which involves 175 people in the monitoring and selection of the stories, says he was taught that a common mistake in English is to use the word "media" as a singular rather than a plural, but that increasingly "I find myself wondering if media isn't singular after all . . . it is singular in its methods of story editing and selection, focusing on entertainment value instead of newsworthiness." Phillips believes that the growth of media mergers means there is an increasing homogeneity in news coverage.

Even when events are given a large amount of coverage, Phillips suggests, the focus may often be unhelpful: "The entire corporate media coverage of the World Trade Organisation protests left most Americans wondering what the fuss was about, as the media focused on the minor vandalism and ignored the global socio-economic issues that drove 60,000 protesters to Seattle."

Certainly, many US journalists complain about what they see as a narrow focus of news in which one story, such as that concerning the Cuban boy, Elian Gonzalez, is dwelt on to the exclusion of others. But there is also concern about the growing tendency of media interests to merge, often creating regional monopolies. It is an issue addressed by commentator William Safire in the New York Times recently in connection with the dispute between Time Warner and ABC-Disney, which led to the former blacking out the programmes provided by the latter in a dispute over cable payments.

"The news has become a casualty of warring entertainment and information empires," wrote Safire, "and the conflict has escalated from one locality to the globe . . . Concentration of power over what we see in the news - and even if we see a competitor's news - is a danger to democracy."

One theme of this year's awards has been foreign coverage - or the lack of it. Number seven of the award winners is an article by veteran war reporter Peter Arnett in the American Journalism Review, in which he cites the sharp decrease in foreign coverage. "Today, a foreign story that doesn't involve bombs, natural disaster or financial calamity has little chance of entering the American consciousness," he writes. "Television news in the heyday of Walter Cronkite, John Chancellor and Frank Reynolds contained at least 40% international coverage. The figure today is 7-12% and dropping."

Arnett concludes that the country's newspapers, magazines and TV stations "seeking greater profits through larger audiences, fed the public a diet of crime news, celebrity gossip and soft features, choosing to exclude more serious topics that news managers feared would not stimulate public attention". Local TV news stations in Los Angeles, for instance, are legendary for concentrating on police chases, shootings, Hollywood openings and weather to the virtual exclusion of foreign news. One news station, KFWB, boasts "you give us 22 minutes and we'll give you the world", and then produces 22 minutes' worth of stories all of which are based in the US. Recent events in Zimbabwe have largely been covered on TV on the basis of whether it was safe for US tourists to continue with planned holidays to the Victoria Falls.

While there is an excellent and vibrant public broadcasting system, some beacons of excellence in the newspaper world and a vast repertoire of "alternative" news found everywhere from the internet to small local weeklies, it is the increased power of monopoly and cross-media interests that Project Censored feels is the latest threat to a proper dissemination of news. It is also worth pointing out that many American broadsheet journalists find much of the British press frivolous and partisan.

The Censored Project Book also contains another list of winners - the 10 "most obsessively over-reported stories of the year," chosen by the Organisation of News Ombudsmen. Winners for 1999 included: the sexuality of Tinky Winky of the Teletubbies whom rightwing evangelist Jerry Falwell suggested was sending a pro-gay message to children because he (Tinky Winky) was purple and had a purse; Y2K; the new Star Wars film; the death of John F Kennedy Junior; and Pamela Anderson's breasts.

The publication of Project Censored could not have come at a more pertinent time. This week, the publisher of the Hearst Corporation's San Francisco Examiner, Timothy White, is taking "an indefinite leave of absence" after suggestions that he had offered the city's mayor favourable coverage in last year's mayoral race if he would drop his public opposition to Hearst's proposed takeover of the San Francisco Chronicle (the city's morning paper, which shares a building and profits with the evening Examiner).

Meanwhile, what would the top 25 British nominations be?

Five issues that never made it

1 Corporation Crackdowns by Arvind Ganesan in Dollars and Sense, a Massachusetts-based magazine. This looked at the cooperation between multi-nationals and repressive governments in Burma, India and Turkmenistan.

2 Millions for Viagra, Pennies for the Poor by Kenneth Silverstein in The Nation. "In 1998 alone, over six million lives were lost while multi-national pharmaceutical companies catered to the vanity of Americans with lifestyle drugs such as Viagra and anti-wrinkle creams."

3 American Cancer Society - the world's wealthiest "non-profit" institution, by Dr Samuel Epstein in the International Journal of Health Services. Epstein argued that the organisation had become financially bloated and that of its $677m (£425m) budget in 1998, $360m went to "supporting services" including overheads, salaries and benefits; not enough, he suggested, was spent on actually tackling and preventing cancer.

4 An American Sweatshop by Mark Boal in Mother Jones. US military uniforms are being made in sweatshops for the Department of Defence by mainly women workers paid as little as $5.50 an hour.

5 Turkey's War on the Kurds, by Kevin McKeirnan in The Bulletin of Atomic Scientists. While 3,000 Kurdish villages were destroyed and 40,000 killed in forcible evacuation, the US assisted the repression for strategic reasons.

 Censored 2000, Peter Phillips and Project Censored, Seven Stories Press, 140 Watts Street, New York, NY10013

fields.headline: Lager without the lout
fields.standfirst: Britain's first new lager in a decade is launched this week with a multi-million pound campaign which aims to resurrect the heyday of the 80s ads.  Belinda Archer  samples the brew
fields.trailText: Britain's first new lager in a decade is launched this week with a multi-million pound campaign which aims to resurrect the heyday of the 80s ads. Belinda Archer samples the brew
fields.body:
Lager advertising is what made British advertising great. In the 80s, such brands as Heineken, Foster's, Carling Black Label and Holsten Pils all lent themselves to infinitely memorable campaigns that captured the public imagination. They boasted the biggest ad spends of the era and were the hottest creative brief for agencies.

In the 90s, the bubble seemed to burst, however, as lager fell out of fashion, spend dipped, and Guinness, John Smith's Bitter and other brews claimed the creative advertising crown.

But this week, Whitbread is launching an ambitious new lager, backed by a multi-million pound ad campaign, that it claims captures the cultural zeitgeist and will resurrect this particular advertising sector.

The product - the first new standard lager to launch in the UK in a decade - is called GB and is made exclusively from British ingredients. It is being aimed squarely at 18-24 year olds (who apparently account for a third of all lager drunk) and, with a 4.4% alcohol content, is positioned midway between the fuller flavoured, stronger premium lagers and the session standard lagers (the ones you can drink in large quantities without, well, getting too pissed).

The name reflects the entire concept behind the brand. GB is meant to be "a celebration of Britain at its best", and as with the great lager campaigns of the 80s, its advertising uses distinctively British humour to convey the spirit of the brand.

The humour here is very different from the past, however. Gone are the blokeish jokes, the cheap visual gags and football references, and in their place is a new subtlety. In short, the lager lad is dead.

Robert Saville, creative director of Mother, the agency behind the campaign, explains: "We wanted to create a campaign that was culturally relevant again, in the same way it used to be, but we had to move on. Different things are happening comedically, so instead of looking to Benny Hill we looked at newer, quirkier comedies such as the Royle Family, that are more observational and about relationships. You can't keep cracking the dead parrot gag or doing Terry and June again."

Mother hired Steve Bendelack, a seasoned director of such TV come dies as League of Gentlemen, Friday Night Armistice and even the Royle Family, to direct the ads.

Bendelack says: "The kind of advertising that Mother does coincides with comedy at the moment because it is not presenter-led and about quick laughs, it's about minutiae and nuance. Smack the Pony and the League of Gentlemen are all an accumulation of small performances."

As a result, the GB ads are not laugh-out-loud funny. There are no men dressed up as bears (think Hofmeister), no silly visual gags (remember Carling Black Label's bouncing bomb?), daft jingles (such as "Time for a sHarp exit") or celebrity frontmen (think Paul Hogan for Foster's). Instead there are low-key, almost sophisticated jokes that require more than one viewing to be fully appreciated, the theory now being that an ad becomes instantly disposable if you get it the first time.

The four spots, featuring a mix of 40-, 30- and 10-seconders, introduce a new, dysfunctional variation on the Oxo family, the Gibsons. Reminiscent somewhat of Bendelack's own Royle family, this bunch loaf about on a sofa and watch telly all the time, but in this case they are so fond of pubs that they have kitted out their front room like their local. The TV is on a bracket high in the corner of the room, while they also have a fruit machine installed in the corner with flashing lights, and a dartboard. The endline says it all: "Lager like us".

Each spot similarly shows the Gibsons playing out scenarios usually associated with life down the pub, such as mum cleaning up the room like a barmaid and dad having a croon on the karaoke machine.

"They don't look like any other lager advertising I've ever seen. Put Heineken or Foster's next to them - they've all got lots of lads with fast cuts to football tracks, but these have a really fresh, modern look. The best compliment would be if people thought no ad agency was involved," says Saville.

Whitbread has also spread this new style of humour right across the brand, embracing the packaging and presentation as well as the advertising. The logo, for example, is the GB sticker you see stuck on the back of the average family saloon motoring across to the continent. And instead of the usual bar pumps, GB will also be served through a giant chrome bathroom tap.

Not only has the brewing giant moved the tone and the humour on, it is also aiming its new product at women as well as men - the first time that women have ever been targeted in this way.

Sophie Spence, development brands director of Whitbread, comments: "Lager is important to women as an alcohol category. The national brewers have traditionally ignored females as part of their targeting, hence their sexist gag advertising, but GB is unisex in its appeal and is targeting both men and women with a unisex humour and cultural associations."

Amazingly, lager is the biggest alcohol category for women - 69% of women drink beer in pubs, compared with only 8% who drink wine, and beer drinking has particularly increased among younger women recently: over the past three years the number of young women regularly drinking draught lager has increased from 36.5% to 39%.

John Webster, executive creative director of BMP DDB and the creative brains behind George the Hofmeister bear, comments: "In the 80s there was a lot of money spent on lager and the whole tone of the advertising was about having a good time and getting away from the wife. The laddishness and chauvinism was part of what made it great and the thing to do was to get blokes quoting the campaign down the pub. But times have changed: ladies are the new lads now. They are rude, and all their icons, like Zoe Ball, drink pints, so it is valid to target them."

Whitbread is ambitious about its new product. It is investing a multi-million pound spend behind the TV, poster and cinema campaign, which begins in the Granada region tonight before rolling out nationally. Its plan is that when young folk go down the pub, they will specify "a pint of GB" when asking for lager, because research shows that around two thirds of lager orders are currently generic.

Whether the brewing giant succeeds in this mission will be up to the discerning youth of Britain, but either way, Mother would appear to have injected new life into what has been one of the nation's best-loved advertising sectors.

Five vintage lager campaigns from the 80s

Carling Black Label
Lager advertising possibly reached its zenith with the Carling Black Label Dambusters spot of 1990, featuring comedy duo the Oblivion Brothers.

Ranked 17 in the recent Channel 4 show 100 Greatest TV Ads, the commercial spoofed the famous war movie of the same name, involving two pilots of a Lancaster bomber dropping a series of bouncing bombs on a German dam and the sentry on duty catching them as they bounce towards him. One of the pilots retorts: "I bet he drinks Carling Black Label." It was probably one of the best-ever movie spoofs.

Hofmeister
A typically laddish lager campaign this, in which a short bloke (in fact he was played by a Hungarian dwarf) dressed up as George the Hofmeister bear in a pork pie hat and yellow jacket and strutted down the street, pursued by a gormless following of sexist male hangers-on. "Follow the bear" was the slogan, and the campaign, which ran from 1983 until 1988, simply brought that to life. Unfortunately, however, George was deemed to encourage laddish, anti-women behaviour and he was axed.

Heineken
This campaign introduced the ultimate advertising slogan "Heineken refreshes the parts other beers cannot reach". It launched in 1974 and there were over 100 ads in the campaign, which won over 300 creative awards along the way.

The slogan gained official approval in 1998 when it was included in the Oxford Dictionary of Modern Quotations. Many of the ads became comedy classics, such as the Wordsworth execution, in which inspiration for the bard was elusive until he swigged a Heineken. "I walked about a bit on my own" became "I wandered lonely as a cloud" after a can of Heineken.

Harp
Similarly juvenile antics combined with cheap visual gags for Harp with a campaign in which blokes extricated themselves from embarrassing situations with the line: "Time for a sHarp exit." One famous execution featured a young man on a first date arriving at the woman's flat. She has a particularly yappy dog which he tries to entertain by throwing a ball. A series of improbable ricochets make the ball bounce out of the window, however - with the dog jumping out in hot pursuit. Cue endline.

Foster's
Foster's advertising between 1984 and 1990 featured Oz comic Paul Hogan playing a predictably sexist, uncomplicated Australian bloke with his "pint of amber nectar". As such he led the way in Australian-style beer advertising (think also Castlemaine XXXX). The campaign kicked off with possibly one of the most memorable spots, in which Hogan goes to the ballet and is startled to see a male dancer in tights. The line "Strewth, there's a bloke down there with no strides on" subsequently entered the vernacular.

Reminiscent somewhat of Bendelack's own Royle family, this bunch loaf about on a sofa and watch telly all the time, but in this case they are so fond of pubs that they have kitted out their front room like their local. The TV is on a bracket high in the corner of the room, while they also have a fruit machine installed in the corner with flashing lights, and a dartboard. The endline says it all: "Lager like us". Each spot similarly shows the Gibsons playing out scenarios usually associated with life down the pub, such as mum cleaning up the room like a barmaid and dad having a croon on the karaoke machine. "They don't look like any other lager advertising I've ever seen. Put Heineken or Foster's next to them - they've all got lots of lads with fast cuts to football tracks, but these have a really fresh, modern look. The best compliment would be if people thought no ad agency was involved," says Saville. Whitbread has also spread this new style of humour right across the brand, embracing the packaging and presentation as well as the advertising. The logo, for example, is the GB sticker you see stuck on the back of the average family saloon motoring across to the continent. And instead of the usual bar pumps, GB will also be served through a giant chrome bathroom tap. Not only has the brewing giant moved the tone and the humour on, it is also aiming its new product at women as well as men - the first time that women have ever been targeted in this way. Sophie Spence, development brands director of Whitbread, comments: "Lager is important to women as an alcohol category. The national brewers have traditionally ignored females as part of their targeting, hence their sexist gag advertising, but GB is unisex in its appeal and is targeting both men and women with a unisex humour and cultural associations." Amazingly, lager is the biggest alcohol category for women - 69% of women drink beer in pubs, compared with only 8% who drink wine, and beer drinking has particularly increased among younger women recently: over the past three years the number of young women regularly drinking draught lager has increased from 36.5% to 39%. John Webster, executive creative director of BMP DDB and the creative brains behind George the Hofmeister bear, comments: "In the 80s there was a lot of money spent on lager and the whole tone of the advertising was about having a good time and getting away from the wife. The laddishness and chauvinism was part of what made it great and the thing to do was to get blokes quoting the campaign down the pub. But times have changed: ladies are the new lads now. They are rude, and all their icons, like Zoe Ball, drink pints, so it is valid to target them." Whitbread is ambitious about its new product. It is investing a multi-million pound spend behind the TV, poster and cinema campaign, which begins in the Granada region tonight before rolling out nationally. Its plan is that when young folk go down the pub, they will specify "a pint of GB" when asking for lager, because research shows that around two thirds of lager orders are currently generic. Whether the brewing giant succeeds in this mission will be up to the discerning youth of Britain, but either way, Mother would appear to have injected new life into what has been one of the nation's best-loved advertising sectors. Five vintage lager campaigns from the 80s Carling Black Label Lager advertising possibly reached its zenith with the Carling Black Label Dambusters spot of 1990, featuring comedy duo the Oblivion Brothers. Ranked 17 in the recent Channel 4 show 100 Greatest TV Ads, the commercial spoofed the famous war movie of the same name, involving two pilots of a Lancaster bomber dropping a series of bouncing bombs on a German dam and the sentry on duty catching them as they bounce towards him. One of the pilots retorts: "I bet he drinks Carling Black Label." It was probably one of the best-ever movie spoofs. Hofmeister A typically laddish lager campaign this, in which a short bloke (in fact he was played by a Hungarian dwarf) dressed up as George the Hofmeister bear in a pork pie hat and yellow jacket and strutted down the street, pursued by a gormless following of sexist male hangers-on. "Follow the bear" was the slogan, and the campaign, which ran from 1983 until 1988, simply brought that to life. Unfortunately, however, George was deemed to encourage laddish, anti-women behaviour and he was axed. Heineken This campaign introduced the ultimate advertising slogan "Heineken refreshes the parts other beers cannot reach". It launched in 1974 and there were over 100 ads in the campaign, which won over 300 creative awards along the way. The slogan gained official approval in 1998 when it was included in the Oxford Dictionary of Modern Quotations. Many of the ads became comedy classics, such as the Wordsworth execution, in which inspiration for the bard was elusive until he swigged a Heineken. "I walked about a bit on my own" became "I wandered lonely as a cloud" after a can of Heineken. Harp Similarly juvenile antics combined with cheap visual gags for Harp with a campaign in which blokes extricated themselves from embarrassing situations with the line: "Time for a sHarp exit." One famous execution featured a young man on a first date arriving at the woman's flat. She has a particularly yappy dog which he tries to entertain by throwing a ball. A series of improbable ricochets make the ball bounce out of the window, however - with the dog jumping out in hot pursuit. Cue endline. Foster's Foster's advertising between 1984 and 1990 featured Oz comic Paul Hogan playing a predictably sexist, uncomplicated Australian bloke with his "pint of amber nectar". As such he led the way in Australian-style beer advertising (think also Castlemaine XXXX). The campaign kicked off with possibly one of the most memorable spots, in which Hogan goes to the ballet and is startled to see a male dancer in tights. The line "Strewth, there's a bloke down there with no strides on" subsequently entered the vernacular.

fields.headline: Sing and the world hums
fields.standfirst: Eurovision may be a national joke but all around the world it's the media event of the year
fields.trailText: Just under 1,000 media people were in Sweden on Saturday night, cramming the restaurants and rooms in the press centre at the giant Globen dome, where an efficient team headed by blonde Asa Wahlbom, who would not have looked out of place in Abba, organised the hundreds of sound booths, computer terminals, pigeonholes, modem sockets and interview cubicles.
fields.body:
Just under 1,000 media people were in Sweden on Saturday night, cramming the restaurants and rooms in the press centre at the giant Globen dome, where an efficient team headed by blonde Asa Wahlbom, who would not have looked out of place in Abba, organised the hundreds of sound booths, computer terminals, pigeonholes, modem sockets and interview cubicles.

Even her Scandinavian calm was affected by the extraordinary demand for press passes. "We hoped to give access to anyone who wanted to cover the event," she said, "but we've had to stop issuing accreditation because all the space is occupied." It's like feeding an army of ants.

Around 300m viewers watched The Eurovision Song Contest. I've been attending it for six years, as the BBC music executive responsible for the UK's annual entry, and the most fascinating aspect has always seemed to me to be the enormous and varied media attention it attracts. Whether at home in Birmingham, as it was in 1998 after we had won the contest with Katrina and the Waves the previous year (each year's victorious country hosts the next year's contest), or in Stockholm last weekend, the phenomenal number of journalists, TV crews, radio interviewers and commentators is staggering.

I've covered American presidential conventions and worldwide charity concerts. I've been to key sporting events and vast festivals. I've coped with producing big TV programmes such as The Brits and The Record of the Year Show. But Eurovision is the one event that constantly astonishes me by the size and spread of intense interest.

You cannot hope to have a quiet meal or a peaceful night out in the city without bumping into teams of foreign reporters. If you wear your badge (and there are seven different colours allowing access to all the areas of the show, from backstage to on stage), you can guarantee that during the evening several people will come up to you and introduce themselves as writers for the Croatian Gazette or the Cypriot Star.

Well, look at it this way. Twenty four countries, for a start, with three or four newspapers, a couple of TV networks and half a dozen radio stations each. They all attend the event, hoping that a little local teenager will become, thanks to Eurovision, the next Madonna and give them a great regional interest story at the same time. And let's be honest, kids having their hearts broken because of the lack of taste of the global televoters provides an equally lively headline. Twenty three out of the 24 entrants are losers, after all.

Then throw in the global fascination. America has dozens of representatives - California alone sent several TV crews this year. Fred Bronson, Billboard's veteran reporter, regards it as the music event of the year and flies in from Hollywood every May to cover it.

Australians are always there. Likewise, the obligatory Japanese (is there anything they don't cover?). This year, I met a journalist from Taiwan, a TV crew from China and two radio hosts from a small station in Vietnam. I've obtained the official list of the 987 media members. This includes Duane Zigliotto from Sydney, New South Wales (I'd have guessed Naples), Emir Hacimic from Bosnia Hercegovina, Jegors Jerohomovics from Latvia (made-up name?), Alexei Smirnov from Russia (ditto), and Angel Galleco-Vega from the United Kingdom (who are you fooling, Angel, why not just admit Puerto Rico?).

The last two names on the list, for some reason, are Bruce, Ken and Wogan, Terry. Never heard of them.

And Eurovision never lets its audience down. Even those ghastly rightwing religious fascists in Jerusalem last year could grin with delight when transsexual Dana International tripped on her high heels and sprawled all over the stage in front of hundreds of millions. God got his own back, they decided. But Dana didn't mind. She takes herself considerably less seriously than her opponents do.

So why is it that the ancient, non-credible, localised phenomenon of Eurovision has become the global magnet for virtually every media representative?

I think it's because it's so good- hearted. There really is a terrific feeling of bonhomie. Nobody can take pop music that seriously. By definition it's fun, superficial, transitory and frothy. Nobody's dying. There are no wars or famines. It doesn't elect leaders or praise greatness. It's an evening of laughter and joy and frivolity. Which, after all, incorporates the essence of humanity.

Eurovision attracts the media people for exactly the same reasons that viewers love it. We all love a trip to somewhere different, a few days not having to concentrate on heavy issues, an excuse to giggle and gossip and laugh. I reckon that if you polled the greatest news gatherers in the world on their favourite event of the year, Eurovision would come out on top. And quite right too.

fields.headline: Maggie Brown's diary
fields.trailText: • A tale of reform this week to make the heart sing. The 30 Club, a 50-year-old media dining group, has voted in principle to let women in, and on only the third attempt! The occasion was marked last Tuesday with a dinner - at Claridge's - where members including Guardian Media Group's chief executive Robert Phillis (who is of course a stalwart campaigner for change) brought along female guests including Christine Walker, Liz Forgan and Sue Farr. Their, er, reward? To listen to Ann Widdecombe. Well, forewarned is forearmed.
fields.body:
 A tale of reform this week to make the heart sing. The 30 Club, a 50-year-old media dining group, has voted in principle to let women in, and on only the third attempt! The occasion was marked last Tuesday with a dinner - at Claridge's - where members including Guardian Media Group's chief executive Robert Phillis (who is of course a stalwart campaigner for change) brought along female guests including Christine Walker, Liz Forgan and Sue Farr. Their, er, reward? To listen to Ann Widdecombe. Well, forewarned is forearmed.

 What's in a name? In the wake of the Flextech merger with Telewest, the two outfits reckoned they must have a new name to symbolise their union. Something buzzy. So chief executive Adam Singer engaged a firm of consultants. After much thought and a fat fee they came up with name, Yo Yo TV. And were swiftly shown the door.

 Greg Dyke's vision for a happy and united BBC has come a cropper in the drama series department, home of the "popular" stuff. The diary has received a forlorn memo circulating among staff and now heading upwards to executives, listing the experienced producers and directors who have gone missing, and complaining about the style of chief Mal "Malodrama" Young - ranging from his "destructive meddling in scripts", to a predilection for eliminating "wit and subtlety in favour of blandness". The subtext is that Young's three-year contract is up for renewal soon, but the problem for rebels is that despite the Harbour Lights flop, he has delivered with Holby City and Doctors - rumoured to be recommissioned for up to 100 extra episodes. Perhaps the drama department would care to produce its own soap?

 Delicious reports of people behaving badly from the Montreux Comedy Festival. Clearly enjoying the hospitality, Michael Barrymore was much taken with the children's TV stars Ant & Dec and visibly disappointed when they were ushered away by ITV press minders, refusing to be consoled by the sight of the stars of Channel 4's Spaced performing handstands in the corner.

But the press pack's fun was spoiled by Nicola Methven, TV editor of the Mirror, who broke the rather quaint "gentleman's agreement" not to spoil the fun by filing exclusives. The Mirror ran two: Harry Hill had signed a £3m deal with ITV (well, he'd had lunch with David Liddiment but who knows where that will lead?) while Carol Smillie did slightly less well with just £1m from the BBC (well, she's filming a pilot for BBC Scotland). The diary applauds enterprise at its favourite tabloid. Keep at it, Nicola!

 The Guardian is currently recruiting student brand managers to promote the newspaper on and around campus. Successful applicants will receive £200 a term, and the opportunity to earn further bonuses. Phone 0870 240 2817 for an application form before May 31.

fields.headline: Far-sighted Auntie gets her man
fields.standfirst: The BBC will ride out the criticism over its new political editor, as it always does, writes media correspondent Matt Wells
fields.trailText: The BBC will ride out the criticism over its new political editor, as it always does, writes media correspondent Matt Wells
fields.body:
Tories accuse BBC of bias. Now where have we heard that one before?

The weekend announcement that the BBC's new political editor is to be Andrew Marr, a known supporter of the New Labour cause, prompted the entirely predictable outcry from Lord Tebbit and his cronies. The former Tory chairman even dismissed the appointment as irrelevant, because the BBC was so bound up with New Labour that it would not make any difference. Today's Daily Telegraph leads with the story.

There is a problem, however, with all the hyperbole. It is hard to criticise Marr on his record, because he is a respected political commentator. True, he takes a left-of-centre perspective, but then the incumbent at the BBC, Robin Oakley, came from a more rightwing background at the Times. (Incidentally, Oakley vehemently dismisses any suggestion that he had Tory sympathies before he took the job.) Even Conservative central office has been reluctant to be drawn into the discussions, preferring to judge Marr on how he performs.

It is also difficult to criticise the appointment of a journalist with no television experience: both Oakley and his predecessor John Cole came directly from the print side of the fence.

So that leaves the BBC itself. Bashing the Beeb is almost a national sport, and a coherent argument can be made about the BBC's judgement. Clearly, appointing Marr, a former editor of the Independent, to the political top job would hand sections of the media and certain politicians a stick with which to beat it.

However, as with the appointment of Greg Dyke as director general, the corporation believes that it has got the right man for the job, and is sticking by its decision in the (almost certainly correct) view that the storm will blow over.

Storms about the BBC tend only to last until the next one brews. The preoccupation with the televising (or not) of the army parade in honour of the Queen Mother is one such argument: even in a worst-case scenario, it can last no longer than July, when the parade itself is due to take place. The BBC takes a long view of these things, and more often than not - and to the frustration of its critics - it usually wins out in the end.

webTitle: Day six: Honest is honestly not all that bad

fields.headline: Day six: Honest is honestly not all that bad
fields.standfirst: Today, The Saints as sinners, Michael Flately's million-dollar feet, could Clooney launch a hair pomade revival? and Ismail Merchant hits out at critics. Fiachra Gibbons reports on all the latest  Cannes news
fields.trailText: The Saints as sinners, Michael Flately's million-dollar feet, could Clooney launch a hair pomade revival? and Ismail Merchant hits out at critics. Fiachra Gibbons reports on all the latest Cannes news
fields.body:
It is with the utmost regret that we report that the All Saints vehicle Honest - another bad girl heist movie set in swinging 60s London, is not nearly in the same class as Spice World. Dave Stewart's first film is in fact watchable, the Appletons can act, and the music isn't at all bad either. The script from Dick Clement and Ian LaFrenais is the sort of thing they toss off in their sleep, but Stewart has managed to make a commercial movie that will put bums on seats. While far from an embarrassment, it's hardly going to relaunch the genre, you'll be glad to hear. The All Saints themselves will be in Cannes tonight for the premiere.

The last hope then for crap celebrity-driven British movies falls to those flaming feet of Michael Flately. Newly insured for $40m (his feet that is), he's going to make a Gene Kelly-style film, called - you've guessed it - Lord of the Dance.

Meanwhile in the world of real film-making the Coen brothers' homage to Homer's Odyssey, O Brother Where Art Thou? starring George Clooney and John Sarturro went down very nicely. It's not their best, but it's certainly their most commercial film to date. Clooney, playing an escaped southern convict is a dead spit for Errol Flynn. Given his character's love of the gentleman's hair treatment 'Dapper Dam', this film might even launch a revival of hair pomade.

Back in the 19th century, Merchant Ivory reeled out The Golden Bowl, Henry James' most impenetrable novel. Critics were divided, but Ismail Merchant is personally prepared to wreck vengeance on anyone who calls it 'Another period piece'. "I'm just sick of you lazy journalists," he said. "It's about people, it's not about period."

Ismail cooked dinner at a star-studded party last night in the Cannes hills where Jane Birkin dolled out the spinach salad and Uma Thurman helped with the ciapattis. As Ismail says, "Merchant Ivory is all about that little bit 'of Indian magic'."

Liv Ullmann's Trolösa, from a script by Ingmar Bergman himself is a wonderful old-fashioned meaty Scandinavian classic about adultery, and the Russian film La Noce is another surprise crowd-pleaser.

Out of competition Girlfight, the American film which wowed Sundance has been a big audience hit. But the real find so far has been a little Mexican film about dogs - Amores Perros (Love's a bitch).

webTitle: Reviews: O Brother, Honest, Nurse Betty, Faithless

fields.headline: Reviews: O Brother, Honest, Nurse Betty, Faithless
fields.standfirst: The Coens tackle the Odyssey; Dave Stewart tries to get All Saints to act.  Peter Bradshaw  reports from the Cannes film festival
fields.trailText: The Coens tackle the Odyssey; Dave Stewart tries to get All Saints to act. Peter Bradshaw reports from the Cannes film festival
fields.body:
At the apex of the Cannes film festival's all-important first weekend, Joel and Ethan Coen's broad and hyperactive comedy of the deep south was unveiled. O Brother, Where Art Thou? is a zany Depression tale - claiming kinship with both Homer's Odyssey and Preston Sturges's Sullivan's Travels - about three Mississippi chain gang prisoners on the run and looking for buried loot. They meet a hitch-hiker called Tommy who claims to have sold his soul to the devil to play blues guitar, and together the outlaws cut a bluegrass record, which becomes a smash hit while the escapees hightail it across the swampy terrain pursued by the familiar lawmen with their traditional reflecting sunglasses and slobbering bloodhounds.

George Clooney is the ringleader, Everett Ulysses McGill, perpetually fussing with his pomade and hair net and sporting a raffish, faintly Mediterranean moustache. It is strange to see him in another three-guys-and-a-treasure-map movie so soon after Three Kings. He is maturing as a comic performer, however, and he carries the picture with virility and brio. Unlike many a TV-bred name, he has somehow developed the mass and dimensions of a big-screen romantic lead or action hero. But sadly John Turturro as Pete, one of his two sidekicks, is a bit dull and unresponsive, his face permanently stuck in a good ol' boy expression.

O Brother takes its Homeric duties fairly seriously, with sirens tempting our boys and Everett finally returning to his faithless Penelope, played by Holly Hunter. But the parallels don't add much and 30s Mississippi is a pretty dry comic landscape compared with, say, 1912 Dublin. The Coens' Sturges homage resides in the chain-gang details, and the moments in the picture show and old-time religion congregation, but it does not exactly match or develop Sturges's view of what real poverty is and what real film-makers can really do about it. That said, O Brother has enormous gaiety and a terrific soundtrack, and deserves its overwhelming position as the "choice of the Croisette" - Cannes's feelgood movie.

Nurse Betty by Neil LaBute is a comedy about a sweet-natured waitress who is unhinged by witnessing her corrupt husband's murder, and travels to Los Angeles to marry a handsome doctor in the hospital soap with which she is obsessed. Renée Zellweger gives a wonderfully warm performance as Betty, and her bewilderment when confronted by an obviously fake hospital set is a joy to behold, as is the lupine nastiness of Aaron Eckhart, her spouse. But TV's fake über -reality is a familiar theme, and this film has Morgan Freeman and Chris Rock stuck in a tiresome and underwritten comic subplot about Del's two killers. Nurse Betty is fun, but we were expecting something meaner and tougher from the creator of In the Company of Men.

Liv Ullmann's Faithless, from a screenplay by Ingmar Bergman, is an agonising anatomy of a failed marriage and could not be more vieux chapeau as far as this festival audience was concerned. Many was the rifle-crack of the raised seat as the hours crept past. And yet this compulsive searching of the wounds, containing extravagant fantasies of emotional cruelty, was still riveting.

The Wooden Spoon d'Or (if that isn't a contradiction) goes to Dave Stewart for Honest, a gangsta-gal movie shown out of competition, and resembling a Camden High School for Girls school play. Set in the swinging 60s, it stars All Saints as three feisty babes who rob banks - and who say their lines as if reading them off an optician's chart. For their capers, our heroines disguise themselves as chaps with fake chin hair etc, and then pointlessly wear masks. Tragically, this is scripted by the great Dick Clement and Ian La Frenais. Sitting there stunned in the auditorium, my facial expression resembled James Bolam in The Likely Lads.

fields.headline: Travolta rebuts 'scientology propaganda' claims
fields.trailText: John Travolta again faces accusations of peddling Scientology propaganda, this time through his latest film, the sci-fi folly Battlefield Earth
fields.body:
John Travolta again faces accusations of peddling Scientology propaganda, this time through his latest film, the sci-fi folly Battlefield Earth.

Entertainment Weekly reports that the cult-awareness group Cultwatch has charged that the movie, adapted from a novel by Scientology founder L Ron Hubbard, contains subliminal pro-Scientology messages, and that the controversial sect secretly financed the film.

Insists producer and star Travolta, "there's no correlation at all to Scientology. Even in the preface, Hubbard made it clear that this is simply a science fiction book."

Director Roger Christian chimes in, "I know there are wars going on against the church, and I knew we would be used for that... But when people have asked if there are subliminal messages, I've said, 'Yes, there are, because I've buried messages about Buddhism!' I'm basically a Buddhist and I'm at the helm of this thing, so if anyone should accuse the movie of promoting something, it should be my philosophy."

 The film opened in the US last Friday to some of this year's worst reviews so far.

webTitle: News: Off-licence writer wins blockbuster film deal

fields.headline: News: Off-licence writer wins blockbuster film deal
fields.standfirst:
Cannes festival official site

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: A former sales assistant at Threshers off licence is to see his tentative film script turned into one of the biggest all-action movie to be made in Britain for decades.
fields.body:
A former sales assistant at Threshers off licence is to see his tentative film script turned into one of the biggest all-action movie to be made in Britain for decades.

It is the sort of happy ending Stel Pavlou would never dream of writing for himself. For years he has been working in the Rochester branch of Threshers by day and writing by night.

Now the 29 year old is to see The 51st State, the first attempt to set a blockbuster buddy movie, in the style of Lethal Weapon, on this side of the Atlantic, start shooting in Liverpool with the American star Samuel L Jackson in October. Robert Carlyle, of Full Monty and Bond fame, is being pursued to play his white sidekick.

With a $30m budget, shoot-outs, car chases, stunts and "all the pyrotechnics of a Bond movie" culminating in a showdown in Liverpool's Anfield stadium, it is certainly the most expensive British debut ever.

It is also a huge gamble for Momentum Films, the new British distributor which launched yesterday in Cannes, pledging to fill the gap left by Polygram, the major player taken over by the Americans two years ago after kickstarting the British film revival with Elizabeth, Four Weddings and a Funeral and Notting Hill.

Led by the several of Polygram's former executives, Momentum claims it will "make films in the Polygram spirit" that brought in Oscars for Fargo and the kind of international success British films had not seen for decades.

Managing director David Kosse, who worked on Being John Malkovich and Angela's Ashes, said he was not afraid of risking half the $60m he had set aside for new films on The 51st State.

"We have the talent and infrastructure in Britain to build our own Hollywood here," he said. "We shouldn't be afraid of bigger budget films - Polygram proved that. This is just a fantastic script. Every aspect of the story is remarkable. I have never known a first-time writer ever to get the go ahead on a film this big, and I think that says it all about the story."

Pavlou, who until recently lived with his Greek-born mother, a home help in Rochester, Kent, sent nearly 20 ideas to Jackson, the cult star of Pulp Fiction, who is said to have jumped up and said: "This guy is me!" when he read the outline of his character, a drug smuggler who tries to double cross his bosses when they invent a new drug.

But the fairytale had another twist for Pavlou. For the man who applied for 600 jobs in media and publishing without success after getting his degree from Liverpool University, has also landed a lucrative deal with publishers Simon & Schuster for his first book, Decipher, a thriller in the John Grisham mode. He has now given up the day job.

fields.headline: Keegan names preliminary squad
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan dropped a few surprises this afternoon as he named his preliminary squad for Euro 2000. The list includes recalls for Everton's Nick Barmby and David James of Aston Villa, as well as a total of six strikers - one of whom will not make it to Belgium and Holland.
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan dropped a few surprises this afternoon as he named his preliminary squad for Euro 2000. The list includes recalls for Everton's Nick Barmby and David James of Aston Villa, as well as a total of six strikers - one of whom will not make it to Belgium and Holland.

The 28 named today will play in friendlies against Brazil and the Ukraine later this month as well as Malta on June 3. Keegan must name a final squad of 22 by June 1.

The most surprising addition is Nick Barmby, who has not featured for England since scoring in a World Cup qualifying match against Moldova in September 1996. "He's been picked for the form he's in, it's as simple as that," said Keegan of the Everton midfielder. "His form throughout the season has been very consistent."

The same could be said of David James, who has forced his way into the preliminary squad alongside three other keepers: David Seaman, Nigel Martyn and Richard Wright. The former Liverpool man has rediscovered his form since moving to Villa Park and is likely to feature in one of the two upcoming games.

Keegan has not yet resolved the conundrum of which five strikers to take to the tournament, however. He named both Andy Cole and Robbie Fowler in the provisional squad (along with Alan Shearer, Michael Owen, Emile Heskey and Kevin Phillips) although it is widely expected that only one of the two will travel. Keegan's decision seems to suggest that the jury is still out on the fitness, and temperament, of Liverpool striker Fowler after he was dropped for the Reds' defeat against Bradford yesterday.

The 28-man England squad to face Brazil on May 27, Ukraine on May 31 and Malta on June 3: Seaman (Arsenal), Martyn (Leeds), Wright (Ipswich), James (Aston Villa), P Neville (Man Utd), G Neville (Man Utd), Ferdinand (West Ham), Campbell (Tottenham), Adams (Arsenal), Keown (Arsenal), Southgate (Aston Villa), Beckham (Man Utd), Wise (Chelsea), Ince (Middlesbrough), Redknapp (Liverpool), Dyer (Newcastle), Barmby (Everton), Parlour (Arsenal), Scholes (Man Utd), Wilcox (Leeds), Gerrard (Liverpool), McManaman (Real Madrid), Shearer (Newcastle), Owen (Liverpool), Cole (Man Utd), Heskey (Liverpool), Phillips (Sunderland), Fowler (Liverpool).
