webTitle: So long and thanks for all the programmes

fields.headline: So long and thanks for all the programmes
fields.trailText: So that's it then. Independent producers had a glorious history from the inception of Channel 4 in the early 80s, via the 25% production quota, to a position of creative dominance. But, according to a number of wishful thinkers, it's all coming to an end. Several large indies are losing their status after being bought by broadcasters. A single ITV in England would no longer need a network centre with outside commissions. And the new director-general of the BBC is reviving in-house production at the expense of pedlars outside the city walls. Meanwhile, we're told, the new media maelstrom will sweep away such old fashioned nostrums as the 1988 quota.
fields.body:
So that's it then. Independent producers had a glorious history from the inception of Channel 4 in the early 80s, via the 25% production quota, to a position of creative dominance. But, according to a number of wishful thinkers, it's all coming to an end. Several large indies are losing their status after being bought by broadcasters. A single ITV in England would no longer need a network centre with outside commissions. And the new director-general of the BBC is reviving in-house production at the expense of pedlars outside the city walls. Meanwhile, we're told, the new media maelstrom will sweep away such old fashioned nostrums as the 1988 quota.

There is the possibility of a short-term fix by rethinking the definition of an independent producer. But since I must declare an interest in this process I will leave that debate for now. Precisely what the role of indies should be in the medium term is just as pressing. There is a white paper (with greenish edges) on communications reform due in six months. The Department of Culture is asking for views by June 23. So this is a good time to ask why we should have independent producers.

A new book by Charles Leadbetter, Living on Thin Air, has been making waves, not least because it carries an endorsement from Tony Blair on the front cover (" . . . an extraordinarily interesting thinker . . . raises critical questions about Britain's future"). Among other things, Leadbetter pinpoints the importance of the creators of intellectual property in the new economy. He explores the benefits that will accrue from a system that encourages and rewards good ideas in an age of intangible assets. This is a theme that was foreshadowed in a book by the culture minister himself, Chris Smith. It is a truism, and an important one, that Brits as a race are particularly creative. Our ideas will determine a good deal of the wealth along with many of the jobs and the exports that we need to generate in the next century. Intellectual property in the media has an added importance in terms of culture and sheer entertainment.

The existing 25% quota may be something of a blunt instrument but it has shown how independence is a powerful spur to innovative ideas. It also succeeded in driving devious practices out of the fat, lethargic broadcasters. But it never led to genuinely healthy competition. How can real diversity of supply be guaranteed in the future? We need to move on from the quota but only if we can find more effective instruments.

The emergence of content-hungry new media players will have a dramatic effect in time. But the quota was aimed at the cash-rich terrestrial broadcasters. What should their responsibility be? The BBC's new licence fee settlement has just kicked in. It is now the happy recipient of £2.4 bn of public money a year. To hear the BBC talk you would think it is their money. It is not. It is ours. So how do we think it should be deployed for maximum public benefit? Certainly a good proportion should be invested in stimulating a healthy creative sector beyond the BBC's pale. We will need to specify how much.

What of the commercial networks? They will be more lightly regulated in the future. But their possession of a network is still a considerable privilege for which they should make pledges in return. Richard Holme at the broadcasting standards commission points to one way forward - the way in which large companies such as BP or Unilever publicly commit to their social responsibilities. The commercial broadcasters would need to do the same for their viewers. It should include their contribution to the creative economy at its broadest, not just via their vertically integrated businesses.

There will, of course, be a very important role for the competition authorities. I hope the new "Ofcom", which will take shape after the next election, applies a gimlet eye to the business of intellectual property creation. Hitherto it has been virtually ignored.

What would the role of the independent producers' association, Pact, be in this exciting new market? It would be much more important than before. There is an opportunity for Pact to espouse the interests of intellectual property creators in general. This is a vital task that the government will need to ensure is done. Indies were meant to merge rapidly and their numbers decline. In fact Pact's membership is rising year on year and currently stands at 1,100. I look forward to the day when its membership is 11,000 and includes creators of all sorts working in all manner of media.

Peter Bazalgette is creative director of GMG Endermol Entertainment, an independent production company part-owned by the Guardian Media Group

fields.headline: Rosie glows at Daily Express
fields.standfirst: One paper is attracting a better class of reader
fields.trailText: After celebrating its centenary, the Daily Express appears to be experiencing a new lease of life. It recorded its second successive monthly increase, selling almost 4% more than the previous month. Editor Rosie Boycott can also take heart from readership statistics which show that the paper has had a good year.
fields.body:
After celebrating its centenary, the Daily Express appears to be experiencing a new lease of life. It recorded its second successive monthly increase, selling almost 4% more than the previous month. Editor Rosie Boycott can also take heart from readership statistics which show that the paper has had a good year.

According to the latest National Readership Survey (NRS), the Express was read by more than 2.6m people a day during the six months from October 1999, a 4.2% increase on the same period the year before.

Better still for a paper which has been transforming its content and approach, the quality of its readership is also improving. Its ABC1 audience rose by 12.5% year on year, greater than any other daily or Sunday national title.

The Express can now boast an ABC1 profile of almost 64%, a major help in attracting advertising and a vindication of the way in which the paper has gradually changed its editorial stance.

But it is too early for the staff at Ludgate House to uncork the champagne. However good the news, it must be seen in context. Despite the bounce in sales last month, it still sold fewer than in April last year. The paper's six-monthly average is more than 4% down on the previous year. Its figures were helped by price-cutting, with some 280,000 sold below cover price, and it remains too reliant on bulk sales. So there is a long way to go.

Even so, for a paper which looked in danger of falling below the magic million, it appears to have steadied itself and that, given its recent history, is no mean feat.

I doubt that Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre will be concerned. His paper's 2.3m sales a day look as steady as a rock. Despite the fact that about a third of the Mail's readers vote Labour, and might therefore be expected to enjoy the Express's New Labour agenda, there is no sign of them switching their habit.

It is difficult to convince people nowadays to take a paper just because of its party allegiance. That, after all, was the whole point of the revolution launched by the Daily Mail's founder, Lord Northcliffe, at the end of the 19th century.

Previously, papers had viewed themselves almost as part of the political process. Northcliffe realised that readers had so many other interests, most of them much less serious, and constructed a paper to feed those appetites. All modern papers adopt that approach now, including the broadsheets, but it has to be said that the Mail is still far and away the most professional package among the daily tabloids.

That's a big challenge for the Express, and for other putative rivals, such as the Mirror and the Sun, which have both attempted to "reposition" themselves in the past couple of years.

Neither of the red-tops has yet found a wholly convincing way of straddling the fence to attract a slightly more upmarket, aspirational audience while holding on to their traditional core readers. They continue their gentle downward slide, with the Sun dropping slightly faster.

But the paper which stands out in this month's chart is Scotland on Sunday. Between March and April it lost a fifth of its sales, falling from 105,000 to 84,000. In April last year it was selling 118,000, some 28.5% more than last month.

The reason for the sudden fall is that the paper cut its price to the bone for one issue and the auditors, ABC, decided to omit it from the final total. Despite that technicality, it is further evidence of the crisis at Press Holdings. Scotland on Sunday is losing sales to the Sunday Herald, now selling about 50,000. The Scotsman's apparent rise is entirely due to 5,000 bulk sales to British Airways. Even its successful Sunday Business, having doubled its cover price, lost sales for the second successive month. Publisher Andrew Neil is under siege.

Despite the bounce in sales last month, it still sold fewer than in April last year. The paper's six-monthly average is more than 4% down on the previous year. Its figures were helped by price-cutting, with some 280,000 sold below cover price, and it remains too reliant on bulk sales. So there is a long way to go. Even so, for a paper which looked in danger of falling below the magic million, it appears to have steadied itself and that, given its recent history, is no mean feat. I doubt that Daily Mail editor Paul Dacre will be concerned. His paper's 2.3m sales a day look as steady as a rock. Despite the fact that about a third of the Mail's readers vote Labour, and might therefore be expected to enjoy the Express's New Labour agenda, there is no sign of them switching their habit. It is difficult to convince people nowadays to take a paper just because of its party allegiance. That, after all, was the whole point of the revolution launched by the Daily Mail's founder, Lord Northcliffe, at the end of the 19th century. Previously, papers had viewed themselves almost as part of the political process. Northcliffe realised that readers had so many other interests, most of them much less serious, and constructed a paper to feed those appetites. All modern papers adopt that approach now, including the broadsheets, but it has to be said that the Mail is still far and away the most professional package among the daily tabloids. That's a big challenge for the Express, and for other putative rivals, such as the Mirror and the Sun, which have both attempted to "reposition" themselves in the past couple of years. Neither of the red-tops has yet found a wholly convincing way of straddling the fence to attract a slightly more upmarket, aspirational audience while holding on to their traditional core readers. They continue their gentle downward slide, with the Sun dropping slightly faster. But the paper which stands out in this month's chart is Scotland on Sunday. Between March and April it lost a fifth of its sales, falling from 105,000 to 84,000. In April last year it was selling 118,000, some 28.5% more than last month. The reason for the sudden fall is that the paper cut its price to the bone for one issue and the auditors, ABC, decided to omit it from the final total. Despite that technicality, it is further evidence of the crisis at Press Holdings. Scotland on Sunday is losing sales to the Sunday Herald, now selling about 50,000. The Scotsman's apparent rise is entirely due to 5,000 bulk sales to British Airways. Even its successful Sunday Business, having doubled its cover price, lost sales for the second successive month. Publisher Andrew Neil is under siege.

webTitle: Lazio the heroes in blockbuster finale

fields.headline: Lazio the heroes in blockbuster finale
fields.trailText: Serie A
fields.body:
Serie A

When Fabio Cannavaro's last-minute header for Parma was inexplicably disallowed by referee Massimo De Santis last week, Juventus looked certain to snatch their second Serie A title in three years.

But after a climax which the Gazetto Dello Sport equated to a Hollywood blockbuster, it was Lazio who were crowned Serie A champions after Juve's Scudetto hopes sank in the torrential rain.

"Lazio - An Oscar-Winning Title" the Gazetto reported. "It's been an incredibly intense season, full of emotion, which has culminated in a finale worthy of any great film."

And for once they were right. For the final day drama exceeded even the previous week's excitement for heart-stopping action and controversy.

When Juventus's match against sixth from bottom Perugia was suspended at half time because of a waterlogged pitch, Lazio were already 2-0 ahead against Reggiana, after goals from Simone Inzaghi and Juan Veron.

Juve and Perugia were then forced to wait in the dressing room for an hour while the referee Pierluigi Collina waited to see if the game could restart. By the time he'd given the go ahead, the pitch was a like a paddling pool and Lazio had beaten Reggiana 3-0.

And within four minutes of the restart it got even worse for Juventus when Alessandro Calori gave Perugia the lead against the run of play. For the last 40 minutes Juve, who knew that a point would send them into a Scudetto play-off, bombarded the Perugia goal, only to find Andrea Mazzantini in superb form.

Even when after substitute Gianluca Zambrotta was sent off, Juve kept up the pressure. But when Filippo Inzaghi fired over from six yards after Darko Kovacevic flicked on Edgar Davids' long through ball, their chance had gone.

"I never thought it would be this beautiful," proclaimed Lazio manager Sven-Goran Eriksson afterwards. "The other titles I won elsewhere in Europe cannot compare to this."

But Juventus general manager Luciano Moggi was less gracious, and hit out at those who had speculated about his influence over referees. "Now that Juventus have lost the title everyone will be happy," he said bitterly. "With it ending like this no one will have anything to say about the championship.

"Only if Juventus had won would the title have been invalid. Congratulations. They've all got what they wanted. There you are. Those are my special powers."

Milan secured third place after a 4-0 rout of Udinese, during which Andrei Shevchenko scored his 24th goal of the season. "I am very happy," the Ukranian said afterwards. "It's been a long hard season, even more difficult than I imagined my first Serie A season to be. I didn't set myself a target but 24 goals is normal."

Internazionale and Parma will play off for the fourth Champions League spot after final-day victories. Internazionale beat Cagliari 2-0 and Parma beat Lecce 4-1.

Primera Liga

Deportivo La Coruna are on the verge of their first ever Primera Liga title after they drew 0-0 away at Racing Santander, while Barcelona could only do the same at relegation-threatened Real Sociedad.

With just one game remaining, Deportivo are on 66 points - three points clear of Barcelona and Real Zaragoza. A draw next week at home to Espanyol will give them the title, but having choked twice in the last decade, fans of the Northern side won't be taking anything for granted.

Real Zarazoga have an outside chance of La Liga after Savo Milosevic's last-minute goal clinched a dramatic 3-2 comeback victory at home to Malaga. Malaga were 2-1 ahead with just five minutes remaining, but Yordi snatched the equaliser and Milosevic grabbed the winner.

Real Madrid moved into fourth after a 2-0 win at Real Betis after goals from Roberto Carlos and Nicholas Anelka. The result - combined with Oviedo's 2-1 victory at Rayo Vallecano means Betis are relegated.

Bundesliga

In their 96-year history, Bayer Leverkusen have never won the German title. But all that looks likely to change after their 4-1 thrashing of Eintracht Frankfurt 4-1 on Saturday.

After a scrappy first half, Leyerkusen went on the rampage and goals from Oliver Neuville, Ulf Kirsten, Paulo Rink and Stefan Beinlich put them 4-0 ahead. Thorsten Kracht grabbed a late consolation for Eintracht.

They are three points clear and need just a point in their visit to SpVgg Unterhaching next Saturday to be crowned league champions.

Sadly, they look like losing their brilliant Brazilian Emerson to Roma. After the match he unveiled a T-shirt which said "Bayer Leverkusen - thank you very much for everything."

Bayern Munich, who have secured Champions League football for next season, kept up the pressure by beating relegated Bielefeld 3-0 after goals from Salihamidzic and Elber (2). Their final game is against already-relegated MSV Duisburg.

Hamburg stay in third after goals from Martin Groth, Soner Uysal and Roy Praeger secured a comfortable 3-0 victory SpVgg Unterhaching.

webTitle: Two films, one title on personal column theme

fields.headline: Two films, one title on personal column theme
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: A variation of the lonely hearts column has drawn a cult following and spawned not one, but two films.
fields.body:
A variation of the lonely hearts column has drawn a cult following and spawned not one, but two films.

I Saw You, a column that appears separately in Venue and The List, magazines published in Bristol and central Scotland, plays on readers' fascination for being fancied. Each advert begins with the same three words and describes a situation that only two people could recognise. "I saw you on the No 7 bus, me reading Tolstoy, you with high heels," a typical ad might read.

Two sets of film-makers have latched on to the idea, giving their productions the same title: I Saw You.

Christine Langan, executive producer of one film, said yesterday that personal columns were an ideal starting point for a television drama, summing up "the coincidental nature of the people you encounter who can form important relationships in your life".

I Saw You adverts were wittier than ordinary personals, she said, but "there is still something of baring your soul, no matter how you dress it up."

John Dingwall, co-writer of the other film, said he had had no idea that another drama had been made. His version, made for Scottish Television with help from Scottish Screen, is about the darker side of I Saw You. A woman becomes aware that a daily ad is being placed by someone aware of her every move.

Langan's film, written by David Nicholls and starring Fay Ripley, will be shown on ITV on May 22. The second, co-written by Euan Morrison, will be screened in Scotland later this year.

The thorny issue of the identical titles is yet to be settled. While Langan's version is to be screened first, Dingwall's was written earlier.

fields.headline: Figgis slams 'children's storyteller' Lucas
fields.trailText: Maverick British director Mike Figgis has attacked Star Wars supremo George Lucas on the issue of digital film-making
fields.body:
Maverick British director Mike Figgis has attacked Star Wars supremo George Lucas on the issue of digital film-making. Figgis, who recently released Time Code 2000, a film shot entirely with handheld digitial videocams in real time, cast serious aspersions on Lucas's claims to be a technological pioneer.

Chatting with the Boston Globe newspaper, Figgis declared: "[Lucas] is really not interested in putting a camera in his pocket and running around with it. His camera will cost in the region of £100,000, will compete with the finest 35mm camera, and will require the equivalent of a team of brain surgeons to maintain it. The revolution is not going to come from that particular citadel."

Warming to his theme, the bearded Leaving Las Vegas auteur got provocative: "I mean, with all due respect, who's George Lucas? He's basically a very rich phenomenon who's interested in a certain kind of technology and children's storytelling."

fields.headline: Paying the school bills
fields.standfirst: Concern over the expanded role of private sector investment in state schools may not be justified, writes education correspondent Rebecca Smithers
fields.trailText: Concern over the expanded role of private sector investment in state schools may not be justified, writes education correspondentRebecca Smithers.
fields.body:
The government's love affair with the private sector in education will move forward by leaps and bounds on Wednesday, when ministers announce a significant expansion of the list of approved contractors who will be given the opportunity to take over failing state schools.

Critics, already unnerved by the fact that Labour ministers are relying heavily on the private sector to take over the problems of state education from poorly-performing local education authorities, may be alarmed by the presence of new entrants such as the security organisation Group 4.

Yet upon further investigation it emerges that the organisation - which had a tricky and highly-publicised start in prison outsourcing - will have only a limited role as part of a consortium called the Tribal Group.

The widening of the "net" of approved contractors shows that not only is the government extremely serious about getting the private sector involved in education, but that it wants to tap into a wider range of expertise.

Until now the market has been dominated by specialist education providers and consultants such as Nord Anglia and Cambridge Education Associates. Clearly the Department for Education and Employment cannot afford to have all its eggs in one baskets and to see a relatively small number of players pick up large numbers of lucrative contracts.

Local education authorities with a good track record are also being encouraged to spread their good practice. The new contractors being named on Wednesday include Camden local education authority.

The chief inspector of schools Chris Woodhead revealed recently that his inspectors had "serious concerns" about nearly 40% of the local education authorities in England they had visited - 23 out of 59.

So far, services have been put out to the private sector in the London boroughs of Islington and Hackney. Significant intervention has also been signalled in Leeds, one of the biggest education authorities in England.

The government has been able to argue that in some cases - after a highly critical Ofsted report, for example - the mere threat of intervention has been enough to encourage poor-performing authorities to pull their socks up.

fields.headline: In the line of fire
fields.standfirst: Chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour on the pressures faced by the new defence secretary Geoff Hoon in the Sierra Leone crisis
fields.trailText: Monday, 1.30pm: Chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour on the pressures faced by the new defence secretary Geoff Hoon in the Sierra Leone crisis
fields.body:
Geoff Hoon, the new defence secretary, is starting to learn what it is like oversee British forces in military combat. He has already had a secure phone line installed in his Midlands home and he is now learning to operate with less than five hours sleep. The bags under his eyes are likely to get a lot bigger before the war in Sierra Leone comes to an end.

For Hoon is under growing political pressure to explain precisely what British paratroopers are doing in Sierra Leone, their terms of engagement and the likely length of their stay.

It is one thing for the prime minister to pronounce grandly on the need for a new interventionist world order in speeches in Washington: it is quite another for a British defence secretary to have to implement these principles in the sometimes grubby world of west African politics.

For most members of the public, Sierra Leone is more likely to be mistaken for a car model off a Ford assembly line, and as to the competing virtues of rebel leader Foday Sankoh, or President Kabbah, fewer than one in 100,000 could even pretend to have an opinion.

As Blair decided early on in Kosovo, it is necessary to give the British public the most simple and lurid descriptions of the enemy in the shape of President Milosevic. In the case of Sierra Leone, most people have no idea even who the enemy actually is.

So the British intervention has inevitably been couched in the most limited terms. Hoon initially explained British troops had been despatched to Freetown to secure the airport and ensure British nationals were free to leave.

Since then, he has given repeated promises that British forces will not be involved in combat either alongside the UN troops or under UN command.

Yet the reality on the ground - primarily the shortfall in UN troops, their poor equipment and the absence of high-quality military advice - has lured the Foreign Office and the Ministry of Defence into blurring the mission. Downing Street is unable to confirm that British troops will return by mid-June, or that they will operate under UN command.

The arrival of the Chief of the Defence Staff General Sir Chalres Guthrie in the region and the stationing of 800 Royal Marines suggests Britain is planning for other more interventionist options.

Conservatives, quite naturally, are starting to ask more and more pointed questions. For the moment Hoon will not shift his position, but few doubt that if the position deteriorates, and the rebels make more ground, Britain is prepared to act.

webTitle: Arms inspectors meet the key players

fields.headline: Arms inspectors meet the key players
fields.standfirst: The archbishop of the Church of Ireland calls for loyalists paramilitaries to reciprocate the provisionals' gesture as attempts to revive the peace process continue
fields.trailText: The archbishop of the Church of Ireland calls for loyalists paramilitaries to reciprocate the provisionals' gesture as attempts to revive the peace process continue
fields.body:
Two respected international statesmen today assumed their new role as arms inspectors that could restore momentum to peace efforts in Northern Ireland.

Former president Martti Ahtisaari of Finland and former African National Congress secretary general Cyril Ramaphosa of South Africa spent the first day on the job by meeting key players. The round of introductory meetings began with a discussion at Downing Street with prime minister Tony Blair and continued at Stormont with Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, and Irish foreign minister Brian Cowen.

The two weapons inspectors said they hoped their work would be to "the enduring benefit" of all the people of Northern Ireland. In a statement, Mr Ramaphosa and Mr Ahtisaari - who played a pivotal role in ending the war in Kosovo - said their meetings represented the first step towards achieving the putting of arms beyond use, a euphemism for IRA disarmament.

"We are well aware of the crucially important nature of the responsibilities which have been entrusted to us. Our mandate is to inspect the contents of a number of IRA arms dumps and, having done so, to report on this to the independent international commission on decommissioning," the two statesmen said. "We will regularly re-inspect these dumps to ensure that the weapons have remained secure"

Though many details of their mission remain to be worked out, Mr Ahtisaari and Mr Ramaphosa are expected to be escorted by IRA intermediaries to at least three arms bunkers within the next month. British and Irish anti-terrorist officials have spent decades searching for the sites, most of them in remote rural parts of the Irish republic.

Britain and Ireland now hope that the IRA's unprecedented promise will allow Mr Mandelson to transfer powers back next week to Northern Ireland's suspended government, the centrepiece of the Good Friday agreement. The historic coalition of Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein was put together in December before it was suspended by the British government because of the IRA refusal to disarm,.

But the issue of reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary is still dogging the British government. Mr Blair is coming under Unionist pressure to let the RUC retain its name in order to keep the peace process on track. Senior Ulster Unionists claimed moves towards the re-establishment of the Stormont assembly is possible, provided the RUC's name stayed. David Burnside, one of the 860 delegates to the party's ruling council, which meets in Belfast on Saturday to consider the IRA's offer to put their guns beyond use, said: "If that compromise is possible there's a chance we move forward."

As Mr Ahtisaari and Mr Ramaphosa began their work, Archbishop Robin Eames, the head of the Church of Ireland, called on loyalist paramilitaries to reciprocate the provisionals' gesture.

"The recent response to political proposals by the IRA represents radical change when viewed from within Irish republicanism," said the archbishop. "But there are other paramilitary organisations in the equation. We look for movement from loyalist sources as well. An end once and for all to terrorism is essential to progress in Ireland. Both unionist and nationalist need confidence-building measures - but they need them in equal measure. The time for terror is over. The time for peace is here."

The archbishop, addressing hundreds of clerics at the church's general synod in Belfast, also called for an end to loyalist and republican paramilitary punishment attacks.

"This is terrorism under a different name," he said. "No organisation has the right to act as judge and jury and inflict on men, women and children barbaric injury. Sooner or later, punishment will produce murder. It has got to stop and stop now."

David Burnside, one of the 860 delegates to the party's ruling council, which meets in Belfast on Saturday to consider the IRA's offer to put their guns beyond use, said: "If that compromise is possible there's a chance we move forward." As Mr Ahtisaari and Mr Ramaphosa began their work, Archbishop Robin Eames, the head of the Church of Ireland, called on loyalist paramilitaries to reciprocate the provisionals' gesture. "The recent response to political proposals by the IRA represents radical change when viewed from within Irish republicanism," said the archbishop. "But there are other paramilitary organisations in the equation. We look for movement from loyalist sources as well. An end once and for all to terrorism is essential to progress in Ireland. Both unionist and nationalist need confidence-building measures - but they need them in equal measure. The time for terror is over. The time for peace is here." The archbishop, addressing hundreds of clerics at the church's general synod in Belfast, also called for an end to loyalist and republican paramilitary punishment attacks. "This is terrorism under a different name," he said. "No organisation has the right to act as judge and jury and inflict on men, women and children barbaric injury. Sooner or later, punishment will produce murder. It has got to stop and stop now."

fields.headline: Gay fathers back off surrogacy
fields.trailText: The first gay British couple to father surrogate children had their twins baptised yesterday, but said despite having 24 embryos in storage they   were unlikely to have any more surrogate children.
fields.body:
The first gay British couple to father surrogate children had their twins baptised yesterday, but said despite having 24 embryos in storage they were unlikely to have any more surrogate children.

After having their five-month-old twins Aspen and Saffron baptised, millionaires Tony Barlow, 35, and Barrie Drewitt, 30, spoke of the difficulties of the last year.

Outside church in Danbury, Essex, Mr Drewitt said, "I would not recommend anyone to do surrogacy."

The couple paid a surrogate mother in California, where the surrogacy laws are more relaxed, to carry children produced from the egg of a second woman and sperm from one of the men. They spent an estimated £200,000 and made history when a US court ruled that both could appear on the birth certificate as fathers.

When they returned to Britain in January the children were refused entry, because UK laws did not recognise the men as parents. The Home Office later allowed the children to stay temporarily. Mr Drewitt said: "We still want more children, but it has been traumatic. We are going to have to talk about it."

fields.headline: Naming, Blaming and Complaining
fields.trailText: KOOGAN'S CRUNCH TIME
fields.body:
KOOGAN'S CRUNCH TIME

Kelvin Koogan today slipped on a blindfold, stuck his hand 28 times into a box marked All Living Englishmen and named a provisional squad for the Euro 2000 championships in Holland and Belgium. His real squad is likely to be announced after the friendly against Ukraine at the end of this month. Which gives Andy Cole three weeks to say something unwise to the papers and get himself dropped.

Cole, against the expectations of most, has made it to the final 28 and is still in with a shout for a trip to the lowlands. The 22-goal Manchester United striker is named alongside Robbie Fowler in a list of six strikers and has an opportunity to benefit from the Liverpool man's lack of fitness and mysterious non-falling out with Gerard Houllier at the weekend. What could famous disciplinarian Houllier and 'reformed' Fowler not have fallen out over, we wonder?

Even better news arrived for David James and Nick Barmby, who have returned to the squad after two and three respective years in the wilderness. There are also places for Steven Gerrard and Steve McManaman. Despite the changes in personnel and continuing lack of left-footers - Barmby is the latest to be mooted for left-midfield - Koogan insisted there will be "no experimenting" from now on. Which presumably means England will continue to play both 4-4-2 and 3-5-2 this summer.

England squad to face Brazil on May 27, Ukraine on May 31 and Malta on June 3: Seaman (Arsenal), Martyn (Leeds), Wright (Ipswich), James (Aston Villa), P Neville (Man Utd), G Neville (Man Utd), Ferdinand (West Ham), Campbell (Tottenham), Adams (Arsenal), Keown (Arsenal), Southgate (Aston Villa), Beckham (Man Utd), Wise (Chelsea), Ince (Middlesbrough), Redknapp (Liverpool), Dyer (Newcastle), Barmby (Everton), Parlour (Arsenal), Scholes (Man Utd), Wilcox (Leeds), Gerrard (Liverpool), McManaman (Real Madrid), Shearer (Newcastle), Owen (Liverpool), Cole (Man Utd), Heskey (Liverpool), Phillips (Sunderland), Fowler (Liverpool).

Oh, if you get a incomprehensible mail back, blame our software. As long as the word 'succeeded' appears on it, everything's fine, me hearties!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WIMBLE WIBBLE

The citizens of Bradford will celebrate their Premiership survival by shaving all the hair off of Rodney Marsh - a punishment for the super pundit's pre-season prediction that the Bantams were bound for the drop. Sadly there will be no civic celebrations for Wimbledon, as they have been relegated. Not to be outdone though, the plucky Dons have opted to stick the boot in - a time-honoured tradition in South London.

Wimbledon's caretaker manager Terry Burton today confirmed that he wants to take the job full-time, but insisted that he won't be alone in carrying the can for the Dons' demise. "We have a responsibility to the fans. We are the people who took this club down and it is our responsibility to take it back up," he said today. Spotting Jason Euell, Neil Sullivan and Carl Cort trying to escape from Selhurst Park disguised as an elk, Burton added: "The players under contract will only leave when it's right for the club."

Speaking of things incongruously Norwegian, Bjorn Rune Gjelsten, owner of the Dons, followed the trend this afternoon and had a pop at, er, himself. "We should have probably understood the cultural differences earlier on with the Norwegian management team we brought in," Bjorn told the Evening Standard today while planting one on his own kisser. "I think that is one big thing we could have done differently," he said. True, Bjorn, but at least you've got a full head of hair.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"The only reason he stayed out so long was because he wanted to thank the fans for another season of their loyal support." George Graham explains away Sol Campbell's solo lap of honour after Spurs' win over Sunderland yesterday.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WATCH OUT! THERE'S A DAVID ABOUT

There was some good news for traditionalists and producers of premium lager today, as it was suggested that regular Auld Enemy matches between Scotland and England could be played again as early as 2002. It seems that last year's violence-free Euro 2000 play-offs convinced the FA and SFA that it is possible to revive the fixture, and both parties have agreed in principle to its return [note to sub: please check "principle" - does this have footballing context?].

"I know there are a lot of people who are very keen to see it brought back both here and at the SFA," said FA chief executive Adam Crozier. "It is a real possibility and something we are due to discuss at our next joint meeting later this year," continued the Scottish administrator (who really is Scottish). Kelvin Koogan has also put the weight of his bouffant behind the plan, saying today: "I would like to see that fixture back on the calendar."

But, as they say in bad movies, things were going well, almost too well. And sure enough, the FA's David Davies opened his mouth and knacked everything up. "The problem is we have a fixture list coming up with top countries stretching to 2002," he reasoned as he enjoyed the sound of his own voice. "The point remains, where would we fit it in?" he asked, without bothering to wait for any suggestions. Davies also found an ally in SFA spokesman Andy Mitchell, who said much the same thing. Although in fairness to the SFA man, it should be pointed out that he didn't use the phrase "fixture list coming up with top countries" in a pathetic attempt to impress people.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Wimbledon goalkeeper Neil Sullivan has been in talks with Tottenham, according to the Evening Standard. Liverpool are monitoring the situation.

Marseille want Egil Olsen to take over as their manager. Olsen has denied any approach has been made, however: "This is totally unknown to me. I haven't heard anything about this. They were in contact with me at least a year ago. After that I haven't heard anything."

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Leeds have agreed an £8.3m fee with Lens for 25-year-old midfielder Olivier Dacourt. "We have reached an agreement with Lens for the signing of Olivier Dacourt. He has passed a medical and the personal terms shouldn't be a problem," a Leeds spokesman said today.

Sir Alex Ferguson has won the Carling Manager of the Year award. It is the fifth time in seven years he has been awarded the trophy.

The redevelopment of Wembley is almost certain to go ahead after London mayor Ken Livingstone pledged £25m to upgrade the transport infrastructure round the site. "By lending his support for this project, Ken Livingstone has effectively tied a ribbon around a world-class present not just for the people of Brent and London but for the nation as a whole," said Brent Council leader Paul Daisley.

Jorg Albertz has signed a new three-year deal with Rangers. "It was never in my plans or my intention to leave this great club and I look forward to many more successful seasons," he said today.

Spaniard Jose Antonio Lopez Nieto has been appointed to referee Wednesday's Euro-Vase final between Arsenal and Galatasaray.

Relegated Wimbledon are being quoted at 6-1 by William Hill to go down again next season - and at 7-2 to bounce back into the Premiership at the first attempt. But Bradford are already being tipped for relegation next season, with Hills quoting them at 1-2 to go down, or 6-4 to survive.

Any English fans caught causing trouble at Euro 2000 will receive a 10-year ban from following any English club in Europe.

Hearts have confirmed their Scotland under-21 international forward Gary Wales suffered a broken leg when tackled by Arthur Numan during Saturday's defeat at Rangers.

Motherwell have given Yugoslavian midfielder Sasa Curcic a free transfer after his unsuccessful spell with the Fir Park club.

BBC1: Panorama (10pm)
Will the current TV negotiations lead to a fairer deal for the average supporter? Will it come as a surprise if the penniless BBC comes to the conclusion that they will not?

ITV: Uefa Big Cup Weekly (12.35am)
Looking backwards and forwards at the same time, like an in-bred.

Cup? What cup?

Oh that one.

World Football Show (7pm, 11.30pm)
If you think it's nice, then watch it twice.

Monday Night Football Special (8pm, 12.15am)
Not without a live match it isn't, pal.

British Eurosport: Eurogoals (11pm)
You're not helping your cause, you know.

Football (12.30pm)
Oh come on, now you're just being awkward.

fields.headline: Happy families
fields.standfirst:
The faces change, but not the ideal

Blairs' baby: special report
fields.trailText: Britain may have the highest divorce rate in Europe, but we seem to have a deeply romantic yearning for happy family life.
fields.body:
Britain may have the highest divorce rate in Europe, but we seem to have a deeply romantic yearning for happy family life. The secret of the success of the first half of the Queen's reign was to play out that fantasy; we were treated to photos of the family's barbecues, picnics and church outings. As we know all too well, it all fell disastrously apart as the fantasy split from any basis in reality. Our disillusionment has even reached the great-grandmother of the nation, the Queen Mother herself, whose birthday pageant the BBC decided last week not to screen, on the grounds that it would not attract enough viewers.

But our national appetite for images of happy family life has survived intact. We have shifted the focus to the nearest available alternative candidates: we had five pages in a tabloid paper last week with pictures of Victoria and David Beckham and their 18-month-old son Brooklyn visiting Disneyland in California. And the media interest in the new arrival at No 10 is now growing so intense as to match that surrounding the birth of Princes William or Harry. Like it or not - and the Blairs give every appearance of not - the images of the first few months of their baby's life will be published and broadcast everywhere. And they cannot but assume iconic status. Will we or won't we see him holding the baby?

Jumping ahead of the game, the New York Times has not even waited for the baby's arrival. It used on its front cover yesterday an oil painting of Blair, beaming with a notional baby over his shoulder, to illustrate a serious and highly favourable profile of the prime minister as a world leader. Whether it is Beckham looking after the baby while his wife has a work meeting, or the prime minister combining the red boxes with winding the baby while Cherie prepares a case, we are looking to these celebrity families to pioneer models of fatherhood and sexual equality - and most of us are fascinated.

fields.headline: Crunch time for David Trimble
fields.standfirst: As the Ulster Unionist Council prepares its response to the IRA's latest decommissioning offer, the Guardian's former Northern Ireland correspondent, Derek Brown, assesses the chances of saving the peace deal
fields.trailText: As the Ulster Unionist Council prepares its response to the IRA's latest decommissioning offer, the Guardian's former Northern Ireland correspondent, Derek Brown, assesses the chances of saving the peace deal
fields.body:
Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble has just five days in which to make the most momentous choice of his political career.

On Saturday, his party's ruling council will deliver its judgment on the IRA's latest and almost certainly final offer on arms decommissioning. Much will depend on what Mr Trimble recommends.

Acceptance of the ingenious but convoluted disarmament formula will open the door to resumption of power-sharing devolved government in Belfast, reform of the Royal Ulster Constabulary and the establishment of ground-breaking all-Ireland institutions.

Rejection could finally destroy the Good Friday peace process and stoke fears of resumed paramilitary violence.

The unionist leader is under intense pressure to grasp what most commentators believe to be the last and only hope of salvaging the peace deal. But, like any astute politician, Mr Trimble is striving to extract further concessions as the price of compliance.

In talks with the British prime minister, Tony Blair, Mr Trimble is seeking "clarification" on several key issues. He wants more details of what exactly the IRA is proposing, with its offer to open arms caches to international inspectors, and eventually to put its weapons "beyond use".

Barry White, among the most astute of Northern Ireland commentators, notes in his latest Belfast Telegraph column that the wording of the IRA offer is vague, and the extent of its commitment to disarmament remains unclear. But he also points out that its proposal is the only game in town.

Mr Trimble will also be pressing for police reform proposals to be trimmed, as a sweetener for the hardline rejectionists in his own party. He wants the RUC to retain its name and crown-and-harp badge, as powerful symbols of the union.

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president, has warned that last-minute haggling by the unionists could scupper the entire process. The Irish Times, too, has urged the British and Irish governments to stand by their pledge for wholesale reforms of the police service. To retain the force's royal title, says the paper, would be as unacceptable as renaming it the Republican Ulster Constabulary.

But the highly respected Dublin daily acknowledges that Mr Trimble should not be sent empty-handed to face his party council on Saturday. It suggests that a generous offer to compensate wounded and traumatised police officers could help to assuage loyalist opinion.

As the arguments swirl, there are more tangible signs that the new disarmament formula is taking shape. The two international observers with the formidable task of inspecting and sealing the IRA's weapons dumps are already on their way to Belfast, after talks in Downing Street with Mr Blair and Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson.

Cyril Ramaphosa, former secretary general of the African National Congress and Martti Ahtisaari, former president of Finland, are due to meet the head of the arms decommissioning body, Canadian General John de Chastelain.

They could start their ultra-sensitive task as early as next week - but only if the 860-strong Ulster Unionist Council swallows its scruples and its pride, and lifts its veto on power-sharing.

To retain the force's royal title, says the paper, would be as unacceptable as renaming it the Republican Ulster Constabulary. But the highly respected Dublin daily acknowledges that Mr Trimble should not be sent empty-handed to face his party council on Saturday. It suggests that a generous offer to compensate wounded and traumatised police officers could help to assuage loyalist opinion. As the arguments swirl, there are more tangible signs that the new disarmament formula is taking shape. The two international observers with the formidable task of inspecting and sealing the IRA's weapons dumps are already on their way to Belfast, after talks in Downing Street with Mr Blair and Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson. Cyril Ramaphosa, former secretary general of the African National Congress and Martti Ahtisaari, former president of Finland, are due to meet the head of the arms decommissioning body, Canadian General John de Chastelain. They could start their ultra-sensitive task as early as next week - but only if the 860-strong Ulster Unionist Council swallows its scruples and its pride, and lifts its veto on power-sharing. fields.headline: Hayden Christensen confirmed as Anakin
fields.trailText: 19-year-old Canadian actor Hayden Christensen has been confirmed by Lucasfilm as the star of the next two Star Wars films, and has been talking about the moment when he knew he was to be an international star
fields.body:
19-year-old Canadian actor Hayden Christensen has been confirmed by Lucasfilm as the star of the next two Star Wars films (as rumoured on May 5) , and has been talking about the moment when he knew he was to be an international star.

The unknown actor, who was selected from 442 candidates tapped for the part, recalls that "it was only about a week ago that it started to hit me that I was testing for Anakin - Darth Vader! It's just been sort of hard to grasp. Of course, it's petrifying, especially coming from the position I was in prior to Star Wars. It'll be a change and you deal with it as it comes along and just hope you can cope". Big brother Tove seems likely to keep Hayden's feet on the ground. "He's like, 'You're not Darth Vader. Come on! I just kicked your ass last week!'".

Says beardie mogul George Lucas of his new charge: "He is very talented, has a great command of his craft, and I know that he has the physical and emotional attributes to play Anakin Skywalker at perhaps the most complex stage of Anakin's life."

Casting director Robin Gurland adds: "There is something so interesting going on behind those eyes; you just want to know more. He is just an amazingly seductive and intriguing actor."

 The film begins shooting in Australia next month.

webTitle: Ben Hollioake inspires Surrey - at last

fields.headline: Ben Hollioake inspires Surrey - at last
fields.standfirst: Ben Hollioake, still only 22, is a Surrey and England allrounder - who  hasn't pulled on an international shirt for over a year. He won a  Championship medal last season, missed selection for either England tour,  and spent his winter playing for South Perth in Australian grade cricket. He  finished third in the club's batting averages and also worked on his  fitness. The wet start to the English season suited his bowling better than  his batting, and the Benson and Hedges Cup quarter-final against Yorkshire  gave him his first big chance to show the fruits of the winter. He put in an  excellent allround performance in Surrey's seven-run victory, scoring 44 off  66 balls and having a hand in four dismissals. Hollioake takes up the story.

fields.body:
"We wanted to win the toss, but that didn't go to plan so we had to bat first. We were looking to get a good total to build up the pressure, but we were under the cosh early doors and the pressure was on us instead. It was hard to tell what a good total would be; the wicket there [at Headingley] can be different, depending on whether the sun's out or it's cloudy. On Tuesday it was overcast. At one stage we were 70-odd for five and were looking to get in the region of 150. When I went out to bat, I was just looking to use up our allotted overs; as long as Stewie [Alec Stewart] stayed at the other end I knew we would do all right.

"I survived an appeal when I was on two. I didn't think I was out - I hit my pad at the same time - and Stewie said I wasn't out. Now I know I was out: TV proved otherwise. Though sometimes the TV can be deceiving: later on, Darren Lehmann was out but he didn't look it.

"At first I was just looking to get singles. I wanted to make sure I didn't lose my wicket early and I tried to get Stewie on strike. I hadn't batted much before this season and had only one innings in one-day cricket. Then, last weekend [May 6] I got 45 against Durham. As we went on, I felt more comfortable. I thought if I stayed in for the slog, we could get to about 210. In the end I was caught trying to hit out. Stewie stayed though, and we got just under 200. We were confident about defending that.

"When I bowled, I struggled a bit in my first over. But I came on during a stalemate spell and the batsmen couldn't get me away easily. I came back later on and had a very good second spell. I got Matthew Wood [Yorkshire's top scorer, with 59] out with a slower ball. I signalled to get Stewey [keeping wicket] closer and it came off [Wood got an inside edge to an offbreak and was caught behind].

"I think the pitch got easier to bat on a quarter of the way through the game, but that didn't really worry us. We've got a good attack and a good record. We knew that Yorkshire were very inexperienced after Lehmann. They're top-heavy with experience, so we just had to apply pressure.

"I ran out Gavin Hamilton with a direct hit from the covers. I was pleased with that. I practise my fielding a lot - I get too bored just standing there not being involved. I got a couple of catches too [at gully]. Getting [Craig] White was important. He hit it quite hard to me. The second catch [to dismiss Richard Blakey] probably looked harder, but White's was tougher.

"It was a big game, and twice we looked like we were going to lose it. But the first time we came back to get an OK total, then, the second time, they needed about 75 with seven wickets left. It was easily the best day of the season so far for me and for the team.

"I'm happy with both my batting and bowling at the moment. I think there are some big performances just around the corner."

Ben Hollioake was talking to Matthew Hancock. My Day In The Sun is on wisden.com and cricketunlimited every Monday. Click here for previous editions: Nicky Peng (Durham), Steffan Jones (Somerset), Stephen Peters (Essex), Michael Burns (Somerset).

webTitle: May 15: In brief and casting news

fields.headline: May 15: In brief and casting news
fields.trailText: Gladiator takes top spot again, Chewbacca rumours abound, and Jeremy Irons, Gwyneth Paltrow and Ralph Fiennes on the casting couch
fields.body:
 For the second consecutive week, Ridley Scott's Gladiatior put its competition to the sword at the US box office, accruing an estimated $24.3m. Taking the number two slot was the John Travolta sci-fi bonanza Battlefield Earth, with an estimated $12.3m. The second world war submarine flick U-571 brought up the rear with $5.8m.

 Might Han Solo's hairy sidekick Chewbacca return in the second Star Wars prequel? Actor Peter Mayhew thinks so, according to rumours haunting the web's Star Wars fan community. Appearing at a convention in Florida, Mayhew is reported as saying: "They have said if and when they do use him that they can't digitalize him, because they can get a certain amount of character, but they can't get the true character doing it that way." Mayhew adds, "[Chewbacca]'s two hundred years old so he will fit nicely into (episodes) Two and Three" - which may be a broad hint, or may be wishful thinking on the actor's part.

 Jeremy Irons has committed to star in an adaptation of Tennessee Williams' play Night of the Iguana, with Kirk Douglas and Thora Birch in negotiations to co-star.

 Cannes favourite Neil
LaBute is to direct an adaptation of AS Byatt's Booker-winning novel
Possession. Gwyneth Paltrow and Ralph Fiennes are believed to have committed to star. The swan-necked starlet will play Maud
Bailey, a researcher who stumbles upon an academic mystery while studying an obscure poetess, and falls for brainy Roland Michell, who can help unravel
the intrigue.

fields.headline: Moms on the march
fields.trailText: By the time you finish reading the Guardian today, four Americans will have been shot dead - in their homes, on the streets, out shopping, at school. By the end of the day, 45 will have died, six of them children. I'm assuming you spend a happy hour with the Guardian; the mortality rate from bullets is 90 every 24 hours, 12 of them youngsters. Why should it need a Million Mom March to get guns under control? The answer lies in some misapprehension and corruption.
fields.body:
By the time you finish reading the Guardian today, four Americans will have been shot dead - in their homes, on the streets, out shopping, at school. By the end of the day, 45 will have died, six of them children. I'm assuming you spend a happy hour with the Guardian; the mortality rate from bullets is 90 every 24 hours, 12 of them youngsters. Why should it need a Million Mom March to get guns under control? The answer lies in some misapprehension and corruption.

The Republican majority in Congress, and GW Bush, the Republican candidate for the presidency, won't hear of anything which interferes with "a citizen's right to bear arms". Not since Clive of India (1725-74) stood amazed at his own moderation in taking gifts, has bribery been defended with such impudence. The plain fact is the Congressmen are on the take from the gun lobby, the National Rifle Association (NRA), which spends 80% of its multimillion dollar war chest on GOP campaigns, but they present themselves as tribunes of the Second Amendment. The reverence of the gun lobby and their pawns in Congress for the Second does not extend to reading it. It is all of 27 words: "A well-regulated militia, being necessary to the security of a free state, the right of the people to keep and bear arms, shall not be infringed." They always have difficulty remembering the first 13 words, which just happens to be the historic heart of the matter.

The amendment was a compromise among the framers of the constitution, between the federalists who wanted a standing federal army and the antifederalists who feared it might be used to suppress liberty. So the compromise was agreed, that states could arm citizen militias as a check on the federal government. And so they did. They are the National Guard.

The hundreds of thousands who turned out on the Mall on Mother's Day have been caricatured by the Second Amendment crowd as "Million Moms for Muggers". An attempt was made to rouse other women to join an Armed Informed Mothers' March accusing the gun controllers of wanting to deprive women of self-defence against abusive husbands, rapists and intruders. They do not. They appreciate that a ban on guns would be hard to sell in a country that has about 200m of them, shared in some unknowable proportion between citizens, cops, hunters, marksmen, collectors and criminals. All the Moms plead is for licensing and registering of handguns, with waiting periods and trigger locks on new weapons. Such laws won't soon stop the mayhem, but they would do something to reduce accidents, help track weapons used in crime, and keep guns out of the hands of kids, criminals and the demented.

The Million Mom march ought to help Gore against Bush. Women, far more than men, are for stricter gun laws (67%, only 28% among men). To a single-issue woman voter there should be no choice. Gore is with them without weasel words. Bush is not. He talks of "voluntary" restraint, of preferring to enforce existing laws. Bush, in fact, has always been an NRA man. In 1997 he approved a law in Texas preventing the prosecution of people who brought guns to church. When two years later seven worshippers in a Fort Worth Baptist church were shot to death, Gore called for a ban on the kind of automatic assault weapons used in the massacre. Bush wrung pious hands. "I don't know of a law," he said, "that will put love in people's hearts."

The march has left two questions: will the Moms help to make guns a single issue? Support for stricter laws has recently been ebbing in the wake of a clever NRA advertising campaign putting the focus on enforcement of existing laws. And will Gore's support for the Moms win him enough votes to offset losses among white men where he already trails by double digits?

Some Democrats don't think it is worth Gore taking the risk. Party men in pivotal "hunting" states such as Ohio and Pennsylvania want him to back off because he has been shedding male voters without gaining women. Bush, a rightwing libertarian at heart, is now doing his best to muddle things by imitating a moderate progressive. On the eve of the march, he announced he would vote for funds to provide free trigger locks. He has also been coming out with social policy initiatives that have the patina of reform, and his boyish charm has gone down well on TV talk shows. Women have in the past few months been wooed from a 48-42% preference for Gore in March to a 47-43% preference for Bush now. Boyish charm and bullets don't mix, but we'll soon see how far America's women have fallen for it.

Harold Evans is the author of The American Century.

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Now all the dust has settled, let us vacuum it up into a bag
fields.trailText: Leeds striker Alan Smith is a £5m target for Manchester City. But Leeds have denied the story, with chairman Peter Ridsdale explaining: "David O'Leary and I had a long chat on the coach coming back from West Ham last night, including the players we might be prepared to let go if we received acceptable bids; Smithy does not fit into that category."
fields.body:
Leeds striker Alan Smith is a £5m target for Manchester City. But Leeds have denied the story, with chairman Peter Ridsdale explaining: "David O'Leary and I had a long chat on the coach coming back from West Ham last night, including the players we might be prepared to let go if we received acceptable bids; Smithy does not fit into that category."

West Ham will bid for Nigel Winterburn if Arsene Wenger allows the player to leave Highbury during the summer. But it won't be the start of a spending spree. "The club have to build the new grandstand so money is tight," Harry Redknapp told the Evening Standard. "I'm going to have to try and sign a couple of players on Bosman during the summer but that's about it."

Coventry manager Gordon Strachan has lined up highly-rated Brentford midfielder Martin Rowlands as a replacement for Liverpool-bound skipper Gary McAllister, reports Teamtalk. The Republic of Ireland under-21 international would cost in the region of £3m. Charlton and Wimbledon are also interested.

Kevin Phillips has hinted that he may leave Sunderland in search of honours, according to Opta Soccer. "I am an ambitious man. I want to see medals on my table when I hang up my boots and I may have to re-assess the situation at Sunderland in the future," he said.

fields.headline: Sushi
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about raw fish on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about raw fish on the net
fields.body:
1. Sushi today is not what it used to be: so tiny have catches become in its native Japan that raw fish aficionados are forced to import their favourite morsels from all over the world.

2. The irony could not be greater since sushi started as a way of preserving excess fish in salt.

3. Naresushi, as the delicacy was called, was not considered ready for eating until the fish had fermented for a few months. By then, it would smell.

4. Change came in the 18th century when chef Yohei Hanaya decided to forego the fermentation and serve sushi in something resembling its present form. Two styles then developed: edo from Tokyo (typically fish on sticky rice) and small seafood packages known as kansai from Osaka.

5. Sushi's crisis is compounded because raw seafood - called sashimi, or nigiri sushi if served with rice - must be absolutely fresh. If not, you risk a dissatisfying dining experience and even food poisoning.

6. The most dangerous morsel remains the liver of the fugu blowfish. Its taste is said to be divine but, if improperly prepared, contains a deadly neurotoxin that kills in minutes.

7. Fish stocks are in decline the world over, but Japan suffers acutely as it consumes a sixth of the global total. One third of this figure passes through the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo.

8. The seafood-rich Tokyo Bay gave the Japanese a taste for almost anything that came out of the salt waters. Japanese chefs know the ideal seasons for serving hundreds of fish and the best ways to cook and prepare them.

9. Two common misconceptions about sushi are that it must be raw and it must be fish. Neither are true: freshwater fish must be cooked to kill parasites while even vegetables and meat teamed with vinegared rice are called sushi.

10. Fish or no fish, Japanese food is not just about your stomach. Etiquette is crucial, so take the test to see if your table manners are up to scratch.

fields.headline: Jack Nicholson sued for assault
fields.trailText: That aging Lothario Jack Nicholson has been hit with a lawsuit alleging that he promised a prostitute $1,000 for sex and then assaulted her when she asked for the money
fields.body:
That aging Lothario Jack Nicholson has been hit with a lawsuit alleging that he promised a prostitute $1,000 for sex and then assaulted her when she asked for the money. Catherine Sheehan has already received a £32,000 settlement from Nicholson, but now insists that that sum is insufficient and that her injuries from the incident are "actually killing her."

webTitle: Over 130 UN captives set free by Sierra Leone rebels

fields.headline: Over 130 UN captives set free by Sierra Leone rebels
fields.standfirst: British government to announce military role this afternoon
fields.trailText: More than 130 of 500 UN peacekeepers held captive by Sierra Leone's rebel movement have been  released into Liberian custody, Liberia's president Charles Taylor said last night.
fields.body:
More than 130 of 500 UN peacekeepers held captive by Sierra Leone's rebel movement have been released into Liberian custody, Liberia's president Charles Taylor said last night.

Taylor said 15 of the 139 freed captives were flown by a government-chartered helicopter to Liberia's capital, Monrovia, on Sunday evening while the remaining 124 were waiting to be evacuated from the Liberian border town of Foya, some 130 miles to the north.

A UN spokesman in Sierra Leone's capital said he was unaware of the reported releases and officials at the UN headquarters in New York were also unable to immediately confirm the report.

However, Taylor briefly introduced an Associated Press reporter to two smiling but tired-looking men wearing new uniforms whom the president said were freed Kenyan and Zambian peacekeepers.

West African and UN officials including secretary general Kofi Annan's envoy to Liberia, Felix Downes-Thomas, stood by silently during the meeting in the living room of Taylor's presidential mansion. Taylor, the region's closest ally to the Sierra Leone's Revolutionary United Front rebels, had been asked by regional leaders to mediate with the renegades to obtain the UN captives' release.

He warned that continued attacks by Sierra Leone's pro-government forces against the rebels "threaten the lives" of the remaining UN personnel held captive by the renegades, adding he was trying to obtain their release. "The attacks on the Revolutionary United Front could not only hamper the mediation work by the Liberian team but also end the lives of the hostages," he said.

Meanwhile, the government is expected to make a statement clarifying the precise rules of engagement for Britain's forces in Sierra Leone today, after criticism that it has not been clear about its intentions.

Defence secretary Geoff Hoon will tell the House of Commons that there has been no change in the 600-strong contingent's status since its arrival in Freetown a week ago.

fields.headline: Milosevic cracks down on dissent
fields.trailText: The Yugoslav government yesterday announced a major crackdown on the country's main opposition groups, accusing them of masterminding the murder of a senior official in President Slobodan Milosevic's ruling Socialist party on behalf of Nato.
fields.body:
The Yugoslav government yesterday announced a major crackdown on the country's main opposition groups, accusing them of masterminding the murder of a senior official in President Slobodan Milosevic's ruling Socialist party on behalf of Nato.

A day after Bosko Perosevic, 43, head of the Vojvodina provincial government and chief of a Socialist party branch there, was shot dead at a trade fair, the government claimed the student organisation Otpor and the Serbian Renewal Movement were behind the attack and would be punished.

"All who perform activities against the state will be treated in accordance with the law. The time of their street actions is over," the informa tion minister, Goran Matic, said.

Police said they had found "beyond doubt" that the suspected gunman, Milivoj Gutovic, 50, was an activist with Otpor and the Serbian Renewal Movement.

Mr Gutovic, a security guard at the Novi Sad exhibition, allegedly approached Perosevic at an agricultural fair on Saturday, pressed a gun to his head and pulled the trigger. He was immediately arrested.

Both groups have denied links with the killing or the gunman.

Mr Matic said Nato was behind the killing. "This was not a work of a single maniac, but an organised murder with a deep political background, with the aim to destabilise Yugoslavia," he said.

He said a number of arrests had been made in connection with the murder, but would not say how many. Asked if opposition activists who are expected to hold a rally in Belgrade today would face arrest, he said: "That is correct."

In a speech at a memorial service for Perosevic attended by Mr Milosevic yesterday, the secretary general of the ruling Socialists, Gorica Gajevic, called Otpor "ordinary Nato mercenaries".

An Otpor activist in Belgrade, Ivan Marovic, said yesterday that a number of the groups' activists have been arrested in several towns, but some were released after lengthy questioning.

webTitle: High fees and no guarantees on the net recruitment frontier

fields.headline: High fees and no guarantees on the net recruitment frontier
fields.trailText: If there is one thing that constrains new internet businesses it is the struggle to recruit good quality people.
fields.body:
If there is one thing that constrains new internet businesses it is the struggle to recruit good quality people.

Having recently secured funding for Rools, a debit facility enabling people to shop online, a priority is to recruit high calibre employees to supplement the existing staff. This is essential for three reasons: first, having more people means we can get more done; second, the quality of the work should improve as gaps are filled and the pool of talent and experience deepens - a larger skills pool should also ensure a steady flow of ideas that will help focus development; and third, it will meet the need to demonstrate the quality of the management team to others, including investors.

The problem is that there are hundreds of companies with similar needs to ours. Although the profile of dot.com businesses, the attractions of entrepreneurial environments and the lure of financial rewards have increased, demand still outstrips the supply of good quality people.

As a result funded start-ups are short of staff and the expectations of potential candidates are becoming excessive. In addition, recruitment agency fees are gradually rising. One agency charges a hefty 30% of the recruit's first year's salary, even if the recruit leaves the business within the first week - and it happens. Another start-up we know recruited an expensive head of operations who left just two days into the job.

They will also grab 30% of the salary of any recruitment facilitated by the original employee. It sounds like a good business to be in.

However, we have seen signs that the recent shake-up of internet stocks may help make things a little easier. As with investors, potential candidates are now carefully examining the companies they join.

As well as the practical things, such as a competitive salary and options package, they look for sustainable business models and that ambitions are backed up by the ability to deliver results. What is the value of your options if the business ceases to exist, for instance? As we begin to see the first start-ups stumble there should be an influx of higher quality candidates into the market.

But professional experience is not the sole criteria for selection.

Initial recruits have a massive impact on the values and feel of small, early stage business, so it is important that there is a good cultural fit with the existing team. It is this experience and compatibility combination that many start-ups are finding so difficult to achieve.

Our approach until recently has been to use our personal and business networks to identify potential candidates for specific roles. We have had some success, and found that services such as the First Tuesday jobs bulletin board can be helpful.

However, our big push for new people starts now, and although we expect it to be a costly and time consuming process, we know that if we get it right it will pay off hugely in the long run.

webTitle: Crucial week for peace process begins

fields.headline: Crucial week for peace process begins
fields.trailText:
Two international inspectors arrive in the province today to examine IRA arms dumps
Special report
fields.body:
The two international inspectors given the task of examining IRA arms dumps as part of the plans for the restoration of devolved government to Northern Ireland arrive in the province today.

Their inspection marks the start of a crucial week for Northern Ireland as Ulster Unionists decide whether to accept IRA arms pledges and go back into the power-sharing administration with Sinn Fein.

Former secretary general of the African National Congress, Cyril Ramaphosa, and former Finland president, Martti Ahtisaari, will report to the head of the international decommissioning body, General John de Chastelain, on the arms stores.

They will arrive in Belfast for talks with Northern Ireland secretary Peter Mandelson and the Irish foreign affairs minister after brief discussions in London with prime minister Tony Blair this morning.

Their appointment was one of the pieces of the jigsaw put together by Mr Blair and Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern as part of their plan to get the Stormont assembly and ministerial executive up and running again next week.

Crucial to that was last weekend's IRA statement which offered to put its weapons "beyond use" and to allow independent observers to inspect a number of its arms dumps and to return regularly for reinspections to confirm that they had not been used.

The inspections will go ahead "come what may", Sinn Fein's chief negotiator Martin McGuinness said. It was not dependent on the resumption of the devolved power-sharing administration.

The 860-strong ruling Ulster Unionist Council meets on Saturday in Belfast to consider developments, but it is still unclear whether Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble will recommend they vote to go back into government.

There will be intensive negotiations between Mr Trimble and the government and other parties ahead of the council meeting. If he is to sell the Hillsborough arms and devolution deal to a sceptical party, he is intent on getting further clarification from republicans on what exactly the IRA means by putting its weapons "beyond use".

He is determined also to press for assurances the RUC's name will be kept in the title of the new police service of Northern Ireland and that the flying of the Union flag in the province will continue on special occasions - such as the Queen's birthday - in line with the rest of the UK. Mr Trimble said: "If I am to table a motion to return to government - and I haven't said I will - it will depend on having my expectations fulfilled in the course of the week."

Sinn Fein is against the flying of the Union flag but Mr McGuinness said he was ready to see the Union flag flying alongside the Irish tricolour on public buildings.

But he was not ready to accept any compromise that would dilute Chris Patten's recommendations on renaming and reconstituting the Royal Ulster Constabulary. "The community that I come from wants to be policed. The community I come from have rejected the RUC as effectively the military wing of unionism."

Mr McGuinness said that the IRA statement had "effectively broken the deadlock" and that it was now up to the unionists to take the decision to return to the institutions set up by the Good Friday Agreement.

Unionists were outraged during their brief stint in devolved government between December and February when Sinn Fein ministers Mr McGuinness, education, and Bairbre de Brun, health, banned the flying of the Union flag over their departmental buildings.
