webTitle: Back to basics after false start at failing school

fields.headline: Back to basics after false start at failing school
fields.standfirst:
In September, Fresh Start was supposed to revitalise an inner-city comprehensive. But things went wrong

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: In September, Fresh Start was supposed to revitalise an inner-city comprehensive. But things went wrong
fields.body:
Today will seem like an ordinary day for the pupils of Islington arts and media school in north London. They will arrive at 8.45am, have a register and then a lesson on personal, social and health education.

But there will be something unusual in that ordinariness. For the previous two weeks, while other schools began their summer term, the school was closed to most of its pupils.

About 200 pupils came in at some point for revision or GCSE exams in science, art and foreign language orals; and more than 400 stayed at home.

That was to allow the acting principal, John Hudson, to carry out "a major training programme" with the 40 staff. Stinging criticism from school inspectors had to be addressed, he said in a letter to parents. "We know that this is a very unusual step but we have done what we can in terms of 'instant' solutions."

The school used to be George Orwell comprehensive, a delapidated inner city comprehensive near Finsbury Park with a good reputation for teaching challenging children but a history of poor results, high truancy, and poverty.

In September it became Islington arts and media school, one of nine "Fresh Start" schools, with a government-backed "superhead", Torsten Friedag, on £70,000 a year and a specialism in arts and media.

But September turned out to be a false start. The school once described as failing because only 10% of pupils won five A to Cs at GCSE is heading on best estimates for even less - 7-8% - this summer.

Even before the school opened, there were problems. Mr Friedag argued that the school should close for a year while the building programme was completed. Not possible, Islington council said, our other schools are already full.

Phase one of the programme - a new entrance, library and canteen - went ahead. During the summer, the builders discovered asbestos. Then they ripped up seven science laboratories by mistake.

When the school opened in September, it was still a building site. There was no hot water until November, and no hot food, so packed lunches were handed out; no locks anywhere in the school. "I don't think there was a toilet that wasn't damaged," a teacher said.

And there were other issues. A byelection in December turned a Labour council into a Liberal Democrat one and with it came a different attitude to Fresh Start. Cambridge Education Associates (CEA) took over Islington schools in the first major privatisation of school services, a measure announced in January though not operational until April.

Today Mr Friedag is looking for work, splitting time between his London flat and his family home in Sudbury, Suffolk, where he was once head at Great Cornard upper. He still believes in Fresh Start and is still deeply fond of IAMS. "I think Fresh Start schools can be successful if everybody from the governors to the local government and all the services pull together."

He has had many nice letters from children and parents, he says. That rings true. Parents speak fondly of him. Last Friday, a mix of Turkish and Kurdish boys hanging out after revision classes did not have a bad word to say about him.

But their understanding of why he left - "He couldn't handle it, I heard," says Ahmet, 14 - is the one that is gaining widest currency. Mr Friedag is the fall guy. They say he did not know how to cope with inner-city kids.

Mr Friedag knows the accusations, and reluctantly will rise to correct some claims. The scale of the problems in the school surprised him, he admits. But it is not true that he was found hiding under his desk - he is too big to fit under it. It was not true that the timetable was changed more than 20 times. He says there was one major revision.

He still believes in policies such as having no central staff room but a series of smaller rooms to discourage "staff room culture". He defends making redundant all but six of the George Orwell staff, who had a reputation for being militant, to change the atmosphere.

He defends opening the school to the media. It worked, the coverage was more sympathetic, but the cameras were there not just for the official opening by David Blunkett, the education secretary, but also for a riot involving 40 children, sparked by a row between two girls over a bag of chips.

As Mr Friedag's revolution began, parents and officials liked him. But then they started to worry and complain. Truancy was rife. Lunch breaks ran over three shifts (later reduced to two), disrupting lessons. School reports were being issued which bore no relation to the child's achievements.

There was more violence between pupils. Teachers complained of poor management, poor discipline. There were problems with cleaning and security staff. One parent says her son went to five classrooms looking for the right lesson, and then gave up.

In February, after a fraught meeting between the council and the school's governing body, Islington started to take on Mr Friedag. Council officials began day-to-day monitoring. John Leovald, the former head of Acton high, west London, was given direct responsibility for sorting out behaviour. Specialist subject advisers were drafted in to meet heads of faculty.

Mr Friedag was asked not to leave the school during normal hours. Officials complained Mr Friedag was not keeping them in the picture.

In turn, an unhappy Mr Friedag complained about a lack of support from the governors, and from local and central government. There were unrealistic expectations, the political will was not there when things got tough. He felt powerless to exclude some disruptive pupils. There was not enough help for the pupils of some 29 national cultures.

The critical view of Mr Friedag virtually became the official version when school inspectors visited 17 days after he resigned. When Dr Hudson arrived, the inspector delivered a stinging letter to him, which was precised in his letter to parents.

"In the view of HMI there were no clear management systems in place, strategic leadership was weak and there was poor communication at all levels. There is no school development plan nor a clear strategy to develop a distinctive ethos to reflect an arts and media school. Systems which could help the management of the school are weak or dysfunctional. Students' behaviour is unsatisfactory overall."

Explaining why he needed to close the school for two weeks, Dr Hudson said: "We need time to make sufficient progress for a substantial change to take place. Students at the school deserve a great deal better than this."

Under the chairmanship of Richard Rieser, formerly a leftwing activist for the National Union of Teachers, the new board of governors produced a position statement, with strong views on the previous regime. They criticised the decision to get rid of the former teachers. They accused Mr Friedag of having "misled" them and accused Islington council of "gross mishandling" of the redevelopment programme. And they demanded that the new controllers write off a budget deficit which may reach £800,000.

There is some sunlight. The governors like Dr Hudson, a methodical planner. He wants to "keep the temperature low".

The fresh Fresh Start will be, for good or ill, a return to traditional ways. Less ambitious. Back to basics, some say. "We are going back to being an inner-city, neighbourhood comprehensive," says Mr Rieser.

One parent says her son went to five classrooms looking for the right lesson, and then gave up. In February, after a fraught meeting between the council and the school's governing body, Islington started to take on Mr Friedag. Council officials began day-to-day monitoring. John Leovald, the former head of Acton high, west London, was given direct responsibility for sorting out behaviour. Specialist subject advisers were drafted in to meet heads of faculty. Mr Friedag was asked not to leave the school during normal hours. Officials complained Mr Friedag was not keeping them in the picture. In turn, an unhappy Mr Friedag complained about a lack of support from the governors, and from local and central government. There were unrealistic expectations, the political will was not there when things got tough. He felt powerless to exclude some disruptive pupils. There was not enough help for the pupils of some 29 national cultures. The critical view of Mr Friedag virtually became the official version when school inspectors visited 17 days after he resigned. When Dr Hudson arrived, the inspector delivered a stinging letter to him, which was precised in his letter to parents. "In the view of HMI there were no clear management systems in place, strategic leadership was weak and there was poor communication at all levels. There is no school development plan nor a clear strategy to develop a distinctive ethos to reflect an arts and media school. Systems which could help the management of the school are weak or dysfunctional. Students' behaviour is unsatisfactory overall." Explaining why he needed to close the school for two weeks, Dr Hudson said: "We need time to make sufficient progress for a substantial change to take place. Students at the school deserve a great deal better than this." Under the chairmanship of Richard Rieser, formerly a leftwing activist for the National Union of Teachers, the new board of governors produced a position statement, with strong views on the previous regime. They criticised the decision to get rid of the former teachers. They accused Mr Friedag of having "misled" them and accused Islington council of "gross mishandling" of the redevelopment programme. And they demanded that the new controllers write off a budget deficit which may reach £800,000. There is some sunlight. The governors like Dr Hudson, a methodical planner. He wants to "keep the temperature low". The fresh Fresh Start will be, for good or ill, a return to traditional ways. Less ambitious. Back to basics, some say. "We are going back to being an inner-city, neighbourhood comprehensive," says Mr Rieser.
